item.name: Adverb
item.descr: An adverb, narrowly defined, is a part of speech whose members modify verbs for such categories as time, manner, place, or direction. An adverb, broadly defined, is a part of speech whose members modify any constituent class of words other than nouns, such as verbs, adjectives, adverbs, phrases, clauses, or sentences. Under this definition, the possible type of modification depends on the class of the constituent being modified.

item.name: Noun
item.descr: A noun is a broad classification of parts of speech which include substantives and nominals.

item.name: Pro-form
item.descr: A pro-form is a part of speech whose members usually substitute for other constituents, including phrases, clauses, or sentences, and whose meaning is recoverable from the linguistic or extralinguistic context.

item.name: Pronoun
item.descr: A pronoun is a pro-form which functions like a noun and substitutes for a noun or noun phrase.

item.name: Verb
item.descr: A verb is a part of speech whose members typically signal events and actions; constitute, singly or in a phrase, a minimal predicate in a clause; govern the number and types of other constituents which may occur in the clause; and, in inflectional languages, may be inflected for tense, aspect, voice, modality, or agreement with other constituents in person, number, or grammatical gender.

item.name: Demonstrative
item.descr: A demonstrative is a determiner that is used deictically to indicate a referent's spatial, temporal, or discourse location. A demonstrative functions as a modifier of a noun, or a pronoun.

item.name: Adjective
item.descr: An adjective is a part of speech whose members modify nouns. An adjective specifies the attributes of a noun referent. Note: this is one case among many. Adjectives are a class of modifiers.

item.name: Interjection
item.descr: An interjection is a part of speech, typically brief in form, such as one syllable or word, whose members are used most often as exclamations or parts of an exclamation. An interjection, typically expressing an emotional reaction, often with respect to an accompanying sentence, is not syntactically related to other accompanying expressions, and may include a combination of sounds not otherwise found in the language.

item.name: Information Sources
item.descr: Human Relations Area Files (HRAF) are sources of information about the people in an area. Descriptions of Anthropology Categories can be found at https://hraf.yale.edu/resources/reference/outline-of-cultural-materials/.

Universe, creation
item.descr: Use this domain for general words referring to the physical universe. Some languages may not have a single word for the universe and may have to use a phrase such as 'rain, soil, and things of the sky' or 'sky, land, and water' or a descriptive phrase such as 'everything you can see' or 'everything that exists'.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to everything we can see?
questionGroup.words: universe, creation, cosmos, heaven and earth, macrocosm, everything that exists
questionGroup.sentences: In the beginning God created <the heavens and the earth>.

item.name: Sun
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the sun. The sun does three basic things. It moves, it gives light, and it gives heat. These three actions are involved in the meanings of most of the words in this domain. Since the sun moves below the horizon, many words refer to it setting or rising. Since the sun is above the clouds, many words refer to it moving behind the clouds and the clouds blocking its light. The sun's light and heat also produce secondary effects. The sun causes plants to grow, and it causes damage to things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the sun?
questionGroup.words: sun, solar, sol, daystar, our star

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to how the sun moves?
questionGroup.words: rise, set, cross the sky, come up, go down, sink

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the time when the sun rises?
questionGroup.words: dawn, sunrise, sunup, daybreak, cockcrow
questionGroup.sentences: We got up before <dawn>, in order to get an early start.

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the time when the sun sets?

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to when the sun is shining?
questionGroup.words: shine, sunny, bright, give light, be sunshiny, daytime

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to the sun shining through the clouds?
questionGroup.words: come out, break through (the clouds), go behind (a cloud)

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe where the sun is shining?
questionGroup.words: sunlit, be (out) in the sun, lit by the sun, shine on, be in the sunlight, sunny (spot)

questionGroup.question: (9) What words describe when or where the sun doesn't shine?
questionGroup.words: shade, eclipse of the sun, sunless, shady, shadow, eclipse (v)

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to the light of the sun?

questionGroup.question: (11) What words describe the brightness of the sun?

questionGroup.question: (12) What refer to the sun heating things?

questionGroup.question: (15) What do people use to protect themselves from the sun?

item.name: Moon
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the moon. In your culture people may believe things about the moon. For instance in European culture people used to believe that the moon caused people to become crazy. So in English we have words like "moon-struck" and "lunatic." You should include such words in this domain.

item.name: Planet
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to planets (large objects that circle the sun, looking like bright wandering stars in the sky), comets (objects that circle the sun, looking like a star with a tail), meteors (small objects that come from space and burn up when they hit the earth's atmosphere, causing a streak of light across the sky), and asteroids (small objects that circle the sun), planetary moons (large objects that circle the planets). Some cultures do not study the stars and will have few or no words in this domain. Others cultures that study the stars will have many words. There are only five planets that people can see in the sky--Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. The others are only known from the scientific study of astronomy.

questionGroup.words: planet, planetary, wandering star

item.name: Wind
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the wind. Some words refer to when the wind begins and ends. The wind changes in speed, so some words refer to how fast the wind is moving. Try to rank these on a scale from very slow to very fast. These words may also be distinguished by what the wind does, since a fast wind does more things. These words may also be distinguished by how long the wind blows. Some words refer to the speed of the wind becoming faster or slower. Some words distinguish a steady wind from a wind in which the speed keeps changing. Some words refer to when the speed of the wind becomes faster for a short time. A steady wind moves in a particular direction, so there are words that include the direction of the wind. The direction of the wind may refer to the points of the compass, a neighboring geographical feature or area, or the direction in which the speaker is moving. Some words refer to a wind that moves in a small circle, making a pillar of dust or a funnel-shaped cloud. Some words refer to what the wind does, such as when it moves or damages something. People can feel the wind, so some words refer to how it feels. The wind makes noise, so there are words that refer to the sound of the wind. In some cultures there is a relation between the wind and spirits, so some words may refer to the activity of the spirits in the wind, or that the wind brings disease.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to the wind?
questionGroup.words: wind, windy, wind current

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a wind that only lasts a short time?
questionGroup.words: breath of air, puff of wind, gust, blast, flurry

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a steady wind?
questionGroup.words: steady wind, trade wind, monsoon winds

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a wind that comes and goes?
questionGroup.words: intermittent, gusty, blustery

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to a warm or cold wind?
questionGroup.words: Chinook, sirocco

questionGroup.question: (10) What words describe when the wind begins?

questionGroup.question: (11) What words describe when the wind stops?
questionGroup.words: drop, die down, calm, still

questionGroup.question: (12) What words describe the direction of the wind?
questionGroup.words: north/south/east/west wind, northeaster, wind off the ocean, ocean breeze, wind from the mountains, mountain breeze, wind from the desert, updraft, downdraft, head wind, tail wind, following wind, cross breeze, windward, lee, prevailing

questionGroup.question: (13) What does the wind do?
questionGroup.words: blow, knock down (things), rip, tear off, bend, puff out, billow out (sail), push (boat), raise (waves), fan flames, push snow into drifts, ventilate a house

questionGroup.question: (14) What words describe something being blown by the wind?

questionGroup.question: (16) What sounds does the wind make?

item.name: Earthquake
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to earthquakes. In some languages earthquakes are thought of as moving somewhere. In Amele (PNG) they say "mim nen" which means 'the earthquake came down (from above)'. In Northern Embera an earthquake is a "house-shaking". They say "a house-shaking went."

item.name: Plant
item.descr: Use this domain for general words for all plants. Use a book of pictures to identify plant names and the scientific name. Languages divide plants into various domains that are not always comparable from language to language. Criterial features may be characteristics (trees and bushes are distinguished by size and number of trunks) and use (grass and weeds are distinguished by their desirability). A common distinction is between trees and non-trees, with trees described as being big, woody, and having a life expectancy of several years, while non-trees are small, non-woody, and have a life expectancy of typically not more than one year (Heine, Bernd and Karsten Legere. 1995. Swahili plants. Rudiger Koppe Verlag: Koln.). Agricultural societies will divide plants into wild and cultivated. However most plants for which there are names have some use. Therefore it does not seem helpful to divide plant names into domains for useful and non-useful plants. Since only parts of plants are eaten, edible parts of plants are listed under the domain 'Food'. Some languages may have more domains than are used in this list, others may have fewer. The classification system used here does not agree entirely with the system used by botanists. For instance botanists do not classify all the tree species together. The palm trees belong to the class Monocotyledoneae and are classified with lilies, bananas, and orchids. Apple and cherry trees belong to the class Dicotyledoneae and are classified in the rose family along with roses and blackberries. The acacia tree also belongs to the class Dicotyledoneae and is classified in the pulse family along with lupines and beans. However most folk taxonomies bring all the trees together. The scientific classification system for plants and animals is taken from: Carruth, Gorton, ed. 1989. The Volume Library, Vols. 1 and 2. The Southwestern Company: Nashville.

questionGroup.words: angiosperm, annual, aquatic, biennial, bracken, brake, creeper, deciduous, edible, flower, greens, herbaceous, hybrid, leafy, legume, luscious, parasite, perennial, plankton, pulse, sedge, succulent, tropical, vegetable, vine, weed, woody, wort

item.name: Tree
item.descr: Use this domain for trees--flowering plants with roots, stems, and leaves, which are large and have a wooden trunk (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae). Also include the evergreen trees (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Gymnospermae). Evergreen trees do not have flowers, but have cone like fruits (pinecones) that contain seeds. Their leaves are shaped like needles and are retained for over a year.

item.name: Grass, herb, vine
item.descr: Use this domain for small plants that have roots, stems, flowers, and seeds, but do not have a wooden trunk (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae). Also include the seedless plants, such as ferns (phylum Pteridophyta, class Filicineae), horsetails (phylum Pteridophyta, class Equisetineae), and club mosses (phylum Pteridophyta, class Lycopodineae). Plants of the Pteridophyta phylum have no flowers or seeds. Ferns have large, divided, feather-like leaves, or fronds. Club mosses are small (rarely over one meter) evergreen plants with simple leaves resembling pine or hemlock needles. Sometimes they grow upright, but often trail on the ground, where they propagate by means of runners. Horsetails send up tall, vertical, jointed stalks with branches covered with scale like leaves.

item.name: Moss, fungus, algae
item.descr: Use this domain for mosses (phylum Bryophyta, class Musci), liverworts (phylum Bryophyta, class Hepaticae), fungi (phylum Thallophyta, subdivision Fungi), algae (phylum Thallophyta, subdivision Algae), and lichens. These plants do not have true roots, stems, or leaves. The mosses are small, green, flowerless plants that grow in moist environments and look like velvety or feathery growths carpeting the ground, tree trunks, and rocks. The liverworts are similar to the mosses with a flat and branching growth pattern. The algae possess green chlorophyll. They vary from one-celled organisms, which sometimes live in colonies such as pond scum, to complex organisms such as seaweed. The fungi do not possess chlorophyll and feed off of other organic material. Lichens consist of a fungus and an algae growing together. They commonly grow on trunks of trees and rocks. Some are flat and leafy, and some are moss like.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to all animals?
questionGroup.words: animal, fauna, creature, critter, organism, wildlife

item.name: Types of animals
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing types of animals. Use a book of pictures to identify each species and its scientific name. This section is organized according to the scientific, biological classification of animals. It may not correspond to the local classification of animals (folk taxonomy), which are often based on how people relate to animals (tame/wild, edible/work). Use this domain for words referring to large classes of animals that do not correspond to the scientific classification. For instance this would be the place for a word like 'flying animal', which includes birds, bats, and flying insects.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to types of animals?
questionGroup.words: phylum, class, order, family, genus, species, chordate, vertebrate, invertebrate, crustacean, rodent, insect, arthropod, mollusk, echidna, protozoa, protozoan, protozoon, amoebic, amoeba, bacteriophage, cold-blooded, warm-blooded, multicellular, single-celled, unicellular, microorganism, germ, virus, viral, purebred, hybrid, quadruped, biped, two-footed, four-footed, diurnal, nocturnal, beast, brute, vermin, varmint, albino

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to wild animals?
questionGroup.words: wild (animal), untamed, feral, wildlife, beast

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to tame animals?
questionGroup.words: tame (animal), tamed, domesticated, livestock, pet

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the process of taming an animal?
questionGroup.words: tame, domesticate, break (a horse)

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to animals that eat certain things?
questionGroup.words: carnivore, carnivorous, meat eater, meat eating, predator, predatory, insectivore, insectivorous, herbivore, herbivorous, plant eating, omnivore, omnivorous, scavenger, parasite

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to whether or not an animal can be eaten?
questionGroup.words: edible, non-edible, clean, unclean, kosher

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to where an animal lives?
questionGroup.words: amphibian, aquatic, arboreal, barnyard, tropical

item.name: Animal movement
item.descr: Use this domain for ways in which animals move. Only include words specific for the movement of animals. For the movement of people use the domains under Movement. It is necessary to think through how each type of animal moves, especially the important ones.

questionGroup.question: (1) How do mammals move?
questionGroup.words: gallop, trot, hop, crawl, fly, soar

questionGroup.question: (2) How do cows move?
questionGroup.words: walk, trot, wander, lie down, charge

questionGroup.question: (3) How do dogs move?
questionGroup.words: trot, run, wag its tail

questionGroup.question: (4) How do horses move?
questionGroup.words: run, gallop, trot, canter, buck, kick, race, charge

questionGroup.question: (5) How do lions move?
questionGroup.words: walk, stalk, charge, run down, prowl

questionGroup.question: (6) How do whales move?
questionGroup.words: breach

questionGroup.question: (7) How do birds move?
questionGroup.words: fly, flutter, soar, dive, swoop, bank, turn, (hummingbird) hover, hop, roost, hang in the air, ride the wind, alight, land

questionGroup.question: (8) How do snakes move?
questionGroup.words: slither, glide

questionGroup.question: (9) How do fish move?
questionGroup.words: swim, leap

questionGroup.question: (10) How do insects move?
questionGroup.words: fly, hover, dive-bomb, crawl

questionGroup.question: (11) How do worms move?
questionGroup.words: crawl, inch along, creep

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to the annual migration of animals?
questionGroup.words: migrate, migration, fly south

questionGroup.question: (13) What words refer to animals moving in a group?
questionGroup.words: herd (v), flock (v), swarm (v), herd instinct, fly in formation, move as a herd

questionGroup.question: (14) What words refer to animal tracks?
questionGroup.words: track

item.name: Animal eating
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to animals eating. Because animals often eat in very different ways from people, many languages will have words that are specific to the way an animal eats.

questionGroup.question: (1) How do mammals eat?
questionGroup.words: graze, feed, chew the cud

questionGroup.question: (2) How do carnivores eat?
questionGroup.words: devour, gorge, tear (prey)

questionGroup.question: (3) How do birds eat?
questionGroup.words: peck

questionGroup.question: (4) How do snakes eat?
questionGroup.words: swallow

questionGroup.question: (5) How do insects eat?
questionGroup.words: suck blood, bloodsucking, chew (holes in leaves)

item.name: Animal home
item.descr: Use this domain for animal homes. It is necessary to think through the homes of each type of animal, especially the important ones.

item.name: Animal group
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to groups of animals.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a group of mammals?
questionGroup.words: herd (of cattle), drove (of cattle), kennel (of dogs), pack (of dogs), pride (of lions), pod (of whales)

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a group of birds?
questionGroup.words: flock (of birds), bevy, colony, covey, flight, flock, gaggle

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a group of fish?
questionGroup.words: school (of fish), shoal

questionGroup.question: (4) What is a group of insects called?
questionGroup.words: swarm (of insects), plague of locusts

questionGroup.question: (5) What is a group of small animals called?
questionGroup.words: culture

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to the leader of a group of animals?
questionGroup.words: alpha male

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to the followers in a group of animals?
questionGroup.words: harem

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to a group of baby animals?
questionGroup.words: brood, clutch (of eggs), kit, litter (of kittens), farrow (of pigs)

questionGroup.question: (9) What other words relate to groups of animals?
questionGroup.words: herd instinct

item.name: Male and female animals
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to male and female animals. Most languages have special words for the male and female of a species only for domesticated animals. Sometimes there will be a word for the male and not the female, and vice versa (male dog, bitch). Sometimes the word for one is also used generically (cow for both female and generic).

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a male or female animal?
questionGroup.words: male, female, bitch, tom, tomcat, bull, bullock, cow, heifer, ram, ewe, billy goat, nanny goat, boar, sow, stallion, mare, filly, stag, buck, hart, doe, vixen, lioness, tigress, bull elephant, rooster, cock, hen, drake, peacock, peahen

item.name: Nature, environment
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to nature and the environment--the world around us. Include words that refer to how people damage or protect nature.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the world around us?
questionGroup.words: world, nature, environment, environmental

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to damaging the environment?
questionGroup.words: pollute, pollution, pollutant, acid rain, smog, deforestation, global warming, greenhouse effect

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to protecting the environment?
questionGroup.words: conserve, conservation, recycle, biodegradable

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the study of the environment?
questionGroup.words: ecology

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to a person who studies or tries to protect the environment?
questionGroup.words: environmentalist, conservationist, ecologist, Green Party

item.name: Natural
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something that is natural--something in the world around us, as opposed to something that has been made or changed by people.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe something that is natural?
questionGroup.words: natural, naturally, wild (animals, country), raw (materials), virgin (forest), untamed, organic

item.name: Person
item.descr: Use this domain for general words for a person or all mankind.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a single member of the human race?
questionGroup.words: person, human being, man, individual, figure

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person when you aren't sure who the person is?
questionGroup.words: someone, somebody

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to more than one person?
questionGroup.words: people, folks, population, the public, populace

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the entire human race?
questionGroup.words: man, men, mankind, the human race, humanity, humankind

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something characteristic of all people?
questionGroup.words: human (adj), human nature

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something characteristic of one person?
questionGroup.words: personal, personally

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to no person?
questionGroup.words: no one, nobody

item.name: Body
item.descr: Use this domain for general words for the whole human body, and general words for any part of the body. Use a drawing or photo to label each part. Some words may be more general than others are and include some of the other words. For instance 'head' is more general than 'face' or 'nose'. Be sure that both general and specific parts are labeled.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the body?
questionGroup.words: body

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the shape of a person's body?
questionGroup.words: build, figure, physique

questionGroup.question: (3) What general words refer to a part of the body?
questionGroup.words: part of the body, body part, anatomy, appendage, member, orifice

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something about your body?
questionGroup.words: physical, physically, bodily

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to cells?
questionGroup.words: cell, cellular, chromosome, protoplasm

item.name: Female organs
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the female reproductive organs and a woman's monthly menstrual cycle. Some of these terms may be taboo. Care must be exercised in which terms are included in the dictionary. A group of women should decide which terms are 'public' and can go in the dictionary, and which would be considered taboo, overly crude, or embarrassing. For example some societies have been afraid that their women will be taken advantage of if these terms are known.

Some languages may not distinguish some of these senses, and some languages may have words for other senses. There are also other senses that animals have. item.name: Dazed, confused
item.descr: Use this domain for words that describe the state of the mind when a person's mind is not working well or when he is not thinking very well.

questionGroup.words: be dazed, confused, disoriented, unsure, out of it, befuddled, bewildered, spaced out, incoherent, dull (minded), stupor

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to express an extreme case of these conditions?

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a person's mind is working well?
questionGroup.words: think clearly, be clear headed, be sharp (mentally)

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to causing someone to be dazed or confused?
questionGroup.words: daze, confuse, disorient, befuddle, shock, stupefy

item.name: Vision, hallucination
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to having a vision--when a person sees something that isn't there because something unusual has happened to their mind. Include unusual, abnormal, and paranormal states of consciousness, visions, hallucinations, and spiritually induced trances.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to beginning an unusual state of consciousness?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the state of being in an unusual state of consciousness?
questionGroup.words: be in a trance, have a vision, hallucinate

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to one person causing another to be in an unusual state of consciousness?
questionGroup.words: hypnotize

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe regaining normal consciousness?
questionGroup.words: come out of the trance

questionGroup.question: (6) What people deal with unusual states of consciousness?

questionGroup.question: (7) What causes someone to be in an unusual state of consciousness?
questionGroup.words: be possessed by a spirit, drugs

item.name: Arrange a marriage
item.descr: Use this domain for all the words related to arranging a marriage. Cultures vary widely in their practices. In some cultures marriages are arranged by the parents. In other cultures a man must seek a wife for himself. Some cultures allow either practice or a combination of the two. So some of the questions below may be inappropriate to your culture.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the thing that is chosen?
questionGroup.words: choice, selection, preference, decision

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the things that could be chosen?
questionGroup.words: alternative, option, selection, candidate

item.name: Cast lots
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to casting lots--to make a decision by chance.

questionGroup.question: (1) What is the general term for making a decision by chance?
questionGroup.words: cast lots [in English and many languages there isn't a generic term; 'cast lots' is archaic]

questionGroup.question: (2) What methods are used for making a decision by chance?
questionGroup.words: roll a die, flip a coin, draw straws, pick names out of a hat, rock-paper-scissors, pick a card (out of a deck), count off, decide who goes first

questionGroup.question: (3) What kind of decisions are made by these methods?
questionGroup.words: deciding who goes first in a game, deciding who dies (e.g. who gets the life preserver), deciding who is guilty

questionGroup.question: (4) What do people say when a decision has been made?
questionGroup.words: X team has won the toss. OK, John goes first. I win. The Lord's will be done. It is the will of the gods. The gods have spoken.

questionGroup.question: (5) What is the validating principle behind these methods?
questionGroup.words: fate, chance, God's will, social consensus

item.name: Intend
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to intending to do something--to do something intentionally and not by accident.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to intending to do something?
questionGroup.words: intend, aim, expect, mean to do something, plan, purpose, resolve, be set on

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is intended?
questionGroup.words: intent, intention, impulse, aim, purpose, resolution

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that someone intended to do?
questionGroup.words: intentional, intentionally, on purpose, because I wanted to

item.name: Deliberately
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to doing something deliberately--to intend to do something, as opposed to doing something accidentally.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to doing something deliberately?
questionGroup.words: deliberately, on purpose, intentionally, pointedly, make a point of, knowingly, consciously, willfully, mean to do something

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is done deliberately?
questionGroup.words: deliberate, intentional, conscious, calculated, premeditated

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to not doing something deliberately?
questionGroup.words: accidentally, by accident, by mistake, unintentionally, not mean to do something, inadvertently, unconsciously

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that is not done deliberately?
questionGroup.words: accidental, unintentional, unconscious, involuntary

item.name: Determined
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being determined to do something--deciding to do something and not letting anything stop you.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being determined to do something?
questionGroup.words: determined, aspire, be intent on, be set on, set your mind on, be resolved, mean business, purposefully, tenacious, put yourself into

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a person who is determined?
questionGroup.words: determined, adamant, committed, driven, hard headed, inexorable, inflexible, obdurate, persevering, pertinacious, single-minded, steadfast, strong-willed, stubborn, tenacious, uncompromising

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a person's behavior that is determined?
questionGroup.words: stubborn, steadfast, resolute, dogged, wholehearted

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to being so determined that you are even willing to do something bad?
questionGroup.words: go to any lengths, be hell-bent on, whatever the cost, ruthless, stop at nothing

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the quality of being determined?
questionGroup.words: determination, ambition, commitment, drive, endurance, perseverance, pertinacity, resolve, spirit, fighting spirit, steadfastness, sticktoitiveness, tenacity, will, willpower

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to becoming more determined?
questionGroup.words: stiffen your resolve, set your mind on, commit

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to persevering in a task?
questionGroup.words: persevere, give it your best, keep on, hang in there, endure, persist, plod, plug

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to not being determined?
questionGroup.words: apathetic, indifference, indifferent, listless, lethargic, neutral, nonchalant, uncaring

item.name: Stubborn
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being stubborn--to be unwilling to change a decision; to be unwilling to do something someone wants you to do; or to do what you want to do, even though other people do not want you to do it.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe someone who is stubborn?
questionGroup.words: stubborn, adamant, bull-headed, conservative, dogged, enduring, hardened, hardheaded, headstrong, immovable, impenitent, incorrigible, indomitable, inflexible, intractable, mulish, obdurate, obstinate, persistent, pig-headed, recalcitrant, relentless, stiff-necked, strong-willed, stubborn, as stubborn as a mule, tenacious, unbending, uncompromising, ungovernable, unmanageable, unrepentant, unyielding, willful

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a stubborn person?
questionGroup.words: stubborn fool, mule, bulldog

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to being stubborn?
questionGroup.words: refuse to obey/listen, won't listen to reason, stick to your guns

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the quality of being stubborn?
questionGroup.words: stubbornness, inflexibility, obstinacy, tenacity, sticktoitiveness

item.name: Lust
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to lusting for something--to want something bad or forbidden.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to lusting for something?
questionGroup.words: desire, lust, avarice, burn, covet, crave, grasping, greed, inflamed

item.name: Request
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to requesting something--to ask for something, or ask someone to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to saying something in order to acquire something from the other person?
questionGroup.words: request, make a request, ask for something, ask somebody to do something, appeal, make an appeal, petition, requisition, solicit, apply, consult

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is said when someone makes a request?
questionGroup.words: appeal (n), petition (n), request (n), solicitation, question

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a person who makes a request?
questionGroup.words: petitioner, suppliant

questionGroup.question: (4) What special words do people use when they want to make a polite request?
questionGroup.words: please, if you wouldn't mind, would you mind?

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to asking for something when you are desperate to get it?
questionGroup.words: implore, plead, beseech, entreat, importune

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to what is said when a person pleads?
questionGroup.words: plea, entreaty

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe a person who pleads?
questionGroup.words: importunate

item.name: Agree to do something
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to agreeing to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to agreeing to do something?
questionGroup.words: agree to do something, accept, approve a plan, consent to, give your consent, grant someone's request, jump at the chance, jump at the opportunity, OK something, give your OK, say yes, give something the thumbs up, take on

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the act of agreeing to do something?
questionGroup.words: agreement, consent

questionGroup.question: (3) What do people say when they agree to do something?
questionGroup.words: All right, Yes you can, Sure, Of course, Help yourself, Be my guest

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that you are doing something that someone has asked you to do?
questionGroup.words: at someone's request, at the request of

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to agreeing to do something after first refusing?
questionGroup.words: give in, bow to, accede to

item.name: Refuse to do something
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to refusing to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to refusing to do something?
questionGroup.words: refuse, refusal, flatly refuse, refuse point-blank, not agree to, will not, say no, decline, shake your head, turn down, dig your heels in, slam the door in someone's face, draw the line at, have none of

questionGroup.question: (2) What do people say when they refuse to do something?
questionGroup.words: not likely, nothing doing, no way, and that's that

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to refusing to give something?
questionGroup.words: refuse, deny, withhold

item.name: Intercede
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to interceding for someone--to say something to someone because you want them to do something good for someone else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to requesting that someone do something for someone else?
questionGroup.words: intercede, intercession, intercessory, intervene on behalf of, interpose, mediate

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person who intercedes?
questionGroup.words: intercessor, go-between, intermediary, mediator, peacemaker

item.name: Willing
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being willing to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being willing to do something?
questionGroup.words: willing, acquiescent, agreeable, compliant, disposed, fain, free, game, kindly, morale, offer, readily, ready, ungrudging, volition, volitional, voluntary, volunteer, will, willful

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to being unwilling to do something?
questionGroup.words: unwilling, unwillingness, forced, grudging, involuntary, loath, pressured, reluctant

item.name: Influence
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to influencing someone--to do something because you want someone to change his thinking.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to influencing someone to change his thinking or decision?
questionGroup.words: influence, sway, bias, pull strings, work on, affect, impact, make an impression on, prejudice, bribe, bring into line, lead by the nose

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to your ability to change another's mind or decision?
questionGroup.words: have influence, be influential, carry weight, have a hold on

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the influence you have on another's mind or decision?
questionGroup.words: influence, impact, weight, pressure, power, sway, control, leverage, pull

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a person who has influence?
questionGroup.words: influential

item.name: Suggest
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to suggesting something--saying that something might be good.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to suggesting something to someone?
questionGroup.words: suggest, make a suggestion, float, recommend, propose, propound, submit

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to formally suggesting something to a person in authority?
questionGroup.words: propose, recommend, put forward, put something before someone, submit, present

questionGroup.question: (3) What words do people use when suggesting something?
questionGroup.words: I suggest, can I suggest, can I make a suggestion, let's, how about, what about, why don't you, you could always, we may as well, we might as well

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to suggesting someone for a job?
questionGroup.words: suggest, recommend, nominate, propose, put someone's name forward

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to something that someone suggests?
questionGroup.words: suggestion, proposal, recommendation, proposition, submission

item.name: Advise
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to giving someone advice or counsel, for instance recommending a wise course of action.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to giving someone advice?
questionGroup.words: advise, say someone should do something, give advice, recommend, urge, offer advice, advocate, commend, counsel, present, promote, propose, recommend a course of action, guide, instruct, submit, make a motion, exhort

questionGroup.question: (2) What words do people use when giving advice?
questionGroup.words: if I were you, you should do something, you ought to, you'd be better off, take my advice, take it from me, you'd be well advised to do something, on no account, you'd better, I would

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to asking for advice?
questionGroup.words: ask someone's advice, seek advice, consult, ask for advice, request advice, turn to for advice

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to doing what someone advises?
questionGroup.words: take someone's advice, follow someone's advice, listen to advice, act on someone's advice, accept advice, adopt

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the advice that a person gives?
questionGroup.words: advice, tip, recommendation, guidance, counseling, counsel, instructions, idea, proposal, charge

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to someone who gives advice?
questionGroup.words: adviser, counselor, consultant, guru, mentor, coach

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to a group of people who give advice?
questionGroup.words: council, board, committee, advisory (board)

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to needing advice?
questionGroup.words: need advice, don't know what to do

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to not knowing what to advise?
questionGroup.words: don't know what to tell you

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to not accepting advice?
questionGroup.words: refuse advice, ignore advice

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to giving advice when the person doesn't want it?
questionGroup.words: meddle, kibitz, kibitzer

questionGroup.question: (12) What words describe good or bad advice?
questionGroup.words: good, wise, bad, bum steer, advisable, helpful, constructive, positive

item.name: Persuade
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to persuading someone--to try to get someone to do something or to change his thinking.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to trying to persuade someone to change his thinking or decision?
questionGroup.words: advocate, promote, persuade, convince, encourage, encouragement, urge, sway

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a person who can persuade others?
questionGroup.words: convincing, persuasive

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to someone being persuaded to change his thinking or decision?
questionGroup.words: come around to (someone's) view, see it (someone's) way, be won over

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to persuading someone not to do something?
questionGroup.words: dissuade

item.name: Insist
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to insisting--to say strongly or repeatedly that someone must do something, because the other person does not want to do it.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to insisting that someone do something?
questionGroup.words: insist, be insistent, at someone's insistence, put your foot down, demand, be adamant, won't take no for an answer, won't hear of, maintain, be resolute

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a person who insists?
questionGroup.words: insistent, importunate, resolute

item.name: Compel
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to compelling someone to do something--to cause or force someone to do something that they do not want to do.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to forcing someone to do something?
questionGroup.words: compel, blackmail, browbeat, bully (v), coerce, constrain, drive, force someone to do something, use force, force something on, insist, impel, impose your will on, make someone do something, oblige, press, pressure, put pressure on, push, use strong-arm tactics, use strong-arm methods, under duress, be breathing down someone's neck

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a situation forcing someone to do something?
questionGroup.words: force, make someone do something, drive, compel someone to do something, leave someone with no choice, leave someone with no option, be condemned to

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to forcing someone to accept something?
questionGroup.words: force something on, impose, inflict something on

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the act of forcing someone to do something?
questionGroup.words: compulsion

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that someone is forced to do?
questionGroup.words: forcible (eviction), forcibly, compulsory (education)

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to something someone does in order to force someone to do something?
questionGroup.words: coercion, pressure, high-pressure tactics, strong-arm tactics

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to someone who forces people to do things?
questionGroup.words: bully

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe someone who forces people to do things?
questionGroup.words: bossy, coercive, pushy

item.name: Control
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to controlling someone--to force someone to do what you want them to do by ordering them to do it, or by doing something so that they have no choice. Also use this domain for words related to controlling something, for instance to control a machine, so that it does what you want it to do.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to controlling someone or something?
questionGroup.words: control, be in control, manipulate, pull strings, call the shots, be in the driver's seat, steer, regulate, govern, dominate, monopolize, have a monopoly, have a stranglehold, have a hold over, wrap someone around your finger, hold sway, be the boss, be domineering, oppress, keep someone down, repress, walk all over

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to being under someone's control?
questionGroup.words: be under someone's control, be in someone's power, be under someone's spell, be at someone's mercy, be a doormat

item.name: Warn
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to warning someone--saying something to someone so that he will not do something bad.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to warning someone?
questionGroup.words: warn, forewarn, admonish, advise against, discourage someone from doing something, dissuade

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is said when someone is warning someone?
questionGroup.words: warning, admonition, alarm, alert, caution, caveat, discouragement, forewarning

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that should not be done?
questionGroup.words: inadvisable

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something that makes a sound to warn people?
questionGroup.words: alarm, bell, buzzer

item.name: Threaten
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to threatening someone--to say that you will do something bad to someone if they don't do what you want them to do.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to threatening someone?
questionGroup.words: threaten, menace, intimidate, terrorize, frighten, cow, bully, browbeat, blackmail, extort, warn

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the act of threatening or to what is said?
questionGroup.words: threat, menace, intimidation, terrorism, blackmail, extortion, warning

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a person who threatens?
questionGroup.words: threatening, menacing, intimidating, bullying

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a person who threatens?
questionGroup.words: bully, terrorist, blackmailer, extortionist

item.name: Ask permission
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to asking permission to do something. This domain is part of a scenario: You have authority over me. I want to do something. I ask you for permission to do it. You give permission or refuse permission. I obey you or disobey you.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to asking permission to do something?
questionGroup.words: ask, ask someone's permission

questionGroup.question: (2) What words do people use when they are asking permission to do something?
questionGroup.words: can I, may I, do you mind if, would you mind if, is it all right if

item.name: Give permission
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to giving someone permission to do something. This domain is about a scenario: You have authority over me. I want to do something. I ask you for permission to do it. You give permission or refuse permission.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to giving someone permission to do something?
questionGroup.words: give permission, agree to, allow, authorize, consent to, give your consent, grant permission, let, permit, say someone can do something, not stand in someone's way, sanction, suffer, give someone the go-ahead, okay something, give someone the green light, give leave
questionGroup.sentences: John <allowed> us to use his shovel.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words do people use when they give someone permission?
questionGroup.words: go ahead, be my guest, feel free, help yourself

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to being allowed to do something?
questionGroup.words: get permission, can, be allowed, be free to do something, may

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to allowing something to happen by not making any effort to prevent it?
questionGroup.words: let, allow, not stand in someone's way, unchecked

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to allowing someone to do whatever they want?
questionGroup.words: give someone complete freedom, give someone a free hand, give someone carte blanche, give someone the run of

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to permission to do something?
questionGroup.words: permission, authorization, consent, clearance, someone's say-so, license, green light, the okay, the go-ahead

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to an official document that gives someone permission to do something?
questionGroup.words: permit, license, warrant

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to giving someone permission to do something that is not usually allowed?
questionGroup.words: bend the rules, make an exception, concession, excuse, exempt, waive

questionGroup.question: (9) What words describe something that people are allowed to do?
questionGroup.words: be allowed, allowable, permissible, acceptable

item.name: Refuse permission
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to refusing to permit someone to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to refusing to give someone permission to do something?
questionGroup.words: refuse permission, deny permission, forbid, prohibit

item.name: Exempt
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being exempt from a law or obligation.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being exempt from a law or obligation?
questionGroup.words: exempt, free, not bound by, not answerable to, immune from prosecution, privileged, excused

item.name: Prevent
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to preventing someone from doing something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to preventing someone from doing something.
questionGroup.words: prevent someone from, keep someone from, avert, avoid, check, frustrate, nip in the bud, obviate, preempt, preemption, prevention, prohibit, stave off, stop, stopping, constrain, impose, hinder, impede, limit, overcome, prevail
questionGroup.sentences: The rain <prevented> John <from> finishing his work.; John <kept> us <from> losing our way.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something that prevents someone from doing something?
questionGroup.words: check, constraint, impediment, limitation, restriction

item.name: Free to do what you want
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to freedom--when you can do the things that you want to do.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being free to do something?
questionGroup.words: free, freely, be at liberty to do something

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a person who is free?
questionGroup.words: free, freedman, liberated, freeborn, freeman

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe an activity that is free?
questionGroup.words: free, open, open-ended, unrestricted

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the state or right to be free?
questionGroup.words: freedom, liberty, autonomy, latitude, license, scope

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to becoming free?
questionGroup.words: gain your freedom, gain your liberty, win your freedom

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to freeing someone?
questionGroup.words: free someone, set free, liberate, emancipate

item.name: Offer
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to offering to do something for someone.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to offering to do something for someone?
questionGroup.words: offer to do something (for someone), volunteer, come forward, let me, proffer, tender, make an overture

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to offering to give something to someone?
questionGroup.words: offer someone something, offer something to someone

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to holding something out to someone so that they can take it if they want it?
questionGroup.words: offer, hold something out

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to offering someone money for something you want?
questionGroup.words: offer someone (money) for something, make an offer, bid

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the act of offering something to someone?
questionGroup.words: offer

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to what is offered?
questionGroup.words: bid

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to taking back an offer?
questionGroup.words: take back an offer, withdraw an offer

questionGroup.question: (8) What expressions do people use when they are offering something?
questionGroup.words: Would you like...? Can I...? Shall I...? Have a/some.... Help yourself to....

item.name: Accept
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to accepting something such as an offer, invitation, or request.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to accepting an offer?
questionGroup.words: accept, be acceptable to, be receptive to, take, take up, take someone up on something

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the act of accepting an offer?
questionGroup.words: acceptance

item.name: Reject
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to rejecting something such as an offer, invitation, or request.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to rejecting an offer?
questionGroup.words: reject, not accept, refuse, decline, turn down, take a rain check, have nothing to do with, turn up your nose at, throw out, say no to, veto, vote against, give something the thumbs down, dismiss, rebuff

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the act of rejecting an offer?
questionGroup.words: refusal, rejection

item.name: Emotion
item.descr: Use this domain for general words related to feelings and emotions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to feeling something?
questionGroup.words: feel, experience

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the part of a person that enables him to feel emotions?
questionGroup.words: feelings, emotions, heart

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a feeling?
questionGroup.words: feeling, emotion, sentiment

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a feeling?
questionGroup.words: heart-felt, strong, powerful, deep, shallow, passing

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to feeling something very strongly?
questionGroup.words: be gripped by

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to a strong feeling?
questionGroup.words: strong feeling, strong emotion, passion

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe someone who has strong emotions?
questionGroup.words: emotional, sensitive, sentimental, passionate, intense, intensity

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to feeling something for a long time?
questionGroup.words: attitude, mood, state of mind, frame of mind, spirits, morale

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to causing someone to feel something?
questionGroup.words: make you feel, stimulate, stir, arouse, raise, touch

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to something that causes someone to feel something?
questionGroup.words: stimulation

questionGroup.question: (11) What words describe something that causes someone to feel something?
questionGroup.words: stimulating, rousing, touching, emotional

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to doing something to show a feeling?
questionGroup.words: emote, express, show, act out, display

questionGroup.question: (13) What words describe someone who does not show many emotions?
questionGroup.words: unemotional, dispassionate, unfeeling, insensitive, unsentimental

questionGroup.question: (14) What words refer to controlling your feelings?
questionGroup.words: control yourself, self-control, restrain yourself, restraint, contain yourself, keep your temper

questionGroup.question: (15) What words describe a person whose emotions are so strong that they lose control?
questionGroup.words: hysterical, have hysterics, go to pieces, fall apart, break down, have an emotional breakdown, go berserk, snap, crack, crack up, give in to, get carried away, have a fit

questionGroup.question: (16) What words refer to controlling your feelings again after losing control?
questionGroup.words: snap out of it, get a grip on yourself, pull yourself together

item.name: Feel good
item.descr: Use this domain for general words related to positive emotions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to feeling good?
questionGroup.words: feel good, feel up

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to good feelings?
questionGroup.words: good feelings, positive emotions, good attitude

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe someone who feels good?
questionGroup.words: up, high

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to feeling very good?
questionGroup.words: exhilarated

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to feeling good for a long time?
questionGroup.words: happy

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to causing someone to feel good?
questionGroup.words: cheer, hearten, entertain, brighten your day

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe something that causes someone to feel good?
questionGroup.words: cheerful (thought)

item.name: Like, love
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to liking something or someone, or liking to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to liking something?
questionGroup.words: like, have a liking for, adore, enjoy, be fond of, proud of someone, fancy something, have a fancy for, take a fancy to, care for, have affection for, admire, look up to, think highly of, approve, pleased, admire, appeals to you, be to your liking, go down well, savor (v), luxuriate, be happy with, feel good toward, feel good about

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to liking someone?

questionGroup.words: worry someone, alarm (v), bother, concern (v), cause someone concern, disturb, trouble (v), bother, prey on your mind, cause concern, be a cause for concern, weigh on your mind, disquiet

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to something that causes someone to feel worried?
questionGroup.words: worry (n), alarm (n), burden, concern (n), trouble (n), care, stresses and strains, hang-up, complex, weight

questionGroup.question: (10) What words describe something that causes someone to feel worried?
questionGroup.words: worrying, worrisome, alarming, anxious, bothersome, disturbing, nerve-racking, stressful, tense, niggling, alarmist

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to someone who worries a lot?
questionGroup.words: be a worrier, worrywart, neurotic, hypochondriac

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to not being worried?
questionGroup.words: not worried, unworried, not concerned, unconcerned, unperturbed, not lose sleep over, don't care, without a care in the world, carefree, philosophical

questionGroup.question: (13) What words refer to not being worried about something that you were worried about before?
questionGroup.words: relief, relieved, be a weight off your mind, relax

questionGroup.question: (14) What words refer to helping someone stop worrying?
questionGroup.words: reassure, reassuring, reassurance, put your mind at rest, put someone at their ease, put someone out of their misery

questionGroup.question: (15) What do people say when they don't want someone to worry?
questionGroup.words: Don't worry. There's nothing to worry about. Rest assured. Never mind.

questionGroup.question: (16) What do people say when they don't need to worry anymore?
questionGroup.words: Thank God! Thank goodness! What a relief!

questionGroup.question: (17) What do people do when they are worried?
questionGroup.words: wring your hands, bite your lip

item.name: Nervous

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to feeling nervous?

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the feeling of being nervous?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe someone who feels nervous?
questionGroup.words: nervous, apprehensive, edgy, fidgety, flustered, ill at ease, jittery, restless, tense, uneasy, uneasily, uptight

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to feeling very nervous?
questionGroup.words: agitated, be a bundle of nerves, excited, have the jitters, be jittery, jumpy, nervous wreck, panicky, be in a state

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe someone who is often nervous?
questionGroup.words: nervous, high-strung, of a nervous disposition

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to causing someone to feel nervous?
questionGroup.words: make someone nervous, fluster, unsettle, unnerve, psych out, put someone on edge

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to something that causes someone to feel nervous?
questionGroup.words: strain

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe something that causes someone to feel nervous?
questionGroup.words: tense, strained, uneasy, nail biting, charged, nerve-racking

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to causing someone to not feel nervous?
questionGroup.words: reassure, reassuring, reassurance, reassuringly

item.name: Shy, timid

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to feeling shy?

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the feeling of shyness?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe someone who feels shy?
questionGroup.words: shy, timid, uncomfortable, bashful, coy, diffident, reserved, withdrawn, introverted, inhibited

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to causing someone to feel shy?
questionGroup.words: inhibit, intimidate, make you feel uncomfortable

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to something that causes someone to feel shy?
questionGroup.words: intimidation

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something that causes someone to feel shy?
questionGroup.words: inhibiting, intimidating, uncomfortable

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to not being shy?
questionGroup.words: come out of your shell, come out of yourself, open up

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to helping someone to not be shy?
questionGroup.words: bring someone out of their shell, bring someone out, put someone at ease

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to something that causes someone to feel confused?
questionGroup.words: distraction, puzzle (n), mystery

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe something that causes someone to feel confused?
questionGroup.words: confusing, puzzling, bewildering, baffling

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to starting to talk about something else instead of what you are supposed to be talking about?

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is announced?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that has been communicated to many people?

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to describing an event?
questionGroup.words: describe, talk about, write about, give an account of, tell of

questionGroup.words: description, descriptive, portrayal, profile, account, report, commentary, characterization, definition, redefinition, depiction, representation

questionGroup.question: (2) What words do people use when they start to explain something?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to explaining how something works or how to do something?

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to explaining something difficult using simple language?

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to explaining something completely?
questionGroup.words: set out

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to what you say when you explain something?
questionGroup.words: explanation, account, instructions, directions

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is said when you introduce something?

item.name: Repeat
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to repeating something--saying something a second time.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to saying something many times?
questionGroup.words: say it over and over, keep saying

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to repeating an important part of a speech?
questionGroup.words: go over, recap, review

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to repeating what someone else said?
questionGroup.words: repeat, quote, echo, parrot, regurgitate

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to what is said a second time?

questionGroup.sentences: Sorry? Pardon? Excuse me? What? What did you say? Would you mind repeating that? Could you say that again? Repeat after me.

item.name: Summarize
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to summarizing what you have said or what someone else has said.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a brief description of the major points or features of something?
questionGroup.words: summarize, summary, synopsis, overview

item.name: Emphasize
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to emphasizing something--to say something in a way that other people know that you think this thing is important.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the placing of importance on something?
questionGroup.words: emphasize, stress

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the importance placed on something?
questionGroup.words: emphasis, stress, importance
questionGroup.sentences: The <emphasis> is on efficiency.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is emphasized?
questionGroup.words: important, stand out, be conspicuous, be prominent

item.name: Be about, subject
item.descr: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something (said, written, thought, or made) depicts or is about a subject, or that something is logically related to some topic. Also use this domain for words that mark the topic or subject of what is being thought about, talked about, or written about. Verbs of thinking, knowing, or speaking (including other types of expression) can take a 'topic' role. We can think of a 'topic' as the main idea. Use this domain also for the important thing in a picture.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being about something or someone?
questionGroup.words: be about something, concern, deal with, be concerned with, center on, focus on, address, cover, depict, discuss, dwell on, present, portray, treat
questionGroup.sentences: The book <is about> the President.; The meeting <is about> the schedule.; The story <depicts> the life of the President.; The story <presents> a view of the President.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate what something is about?
questionGroup.words: about, on, concerning, on the subject of, regarding, re, with regard to, in, of
questionGroup.sentences: John was talking <about> the new seed he bought.; I read <about> John in the newspaper.; a book <about> the President; the book <on> the President; the picture <of> the President; an experiment <concerning> growing rice; a course <in> history

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the thing something is about?
questionGroup.words: subject, topic, theme, issue, question, matter, business, thing
questionGroup.sentences: The <subject> of the book is the President.; The <topic> of the discussion is efficiency.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is not true?

item.name: Thank

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the act of expressing thanks?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a person who feels thankful?

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the feeling of wanting to thank someone?

questionGroup.question: (5) What do people say when they thank someone?
questionGroup.sentences: Thank you. Thanks. That's very kind of you. That's very good of you. I appreciate it. You shouldn't have, You've saved my life. I'd like to thank. Many thanks. Bless you. Blessings on you. Much obliged. I'm indebted to you. I'm in your debt. I'm beholden to you.

questionGroup.question: (6) What do people say when someone thanks them?
questionGroup.sentences: Don't mention it. That's all right. That's OK. You're welcome. My pleasure. Not at all. Think nothing of it. It was nothing. No problem.

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe a person who does not thank someone?

questionGroup.question: (10) What words describe someone that no one thanks?

item.name: Obscenity
item.descr: Use this domain for obscene words related to sex, defecation, death, damnation, and other taboo or offensive subjects. It is important to check the appropriateness of including obscene words in the dictionary. It should be the choice of the speakers of the language whether a word should be included or excluded. Obscene words included in the dictionary should be clearly marked as such. Obscenity is often used to heighten the emotion of an expression, and is often used when someone is angry. Obscenity is often associated with sex or defecation. Cursing is often associated with God, religion, or the afterlife. Insults often involve equating a person with an animal that is associated with an undesirable characteristic, questioning someone's parentage/legitimacy, questioning someone's character, or questioning someone's intelligence/sanity.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to speech that is considered offensive or improper?
questionGroup.words: bad language, strong language, swear word, four letter word, curse, obscenities, profanity, swearing, unprintable

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to using obscenity?
questionGroup.words: swear, curse, cuss

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used in an obscene way?
questionGroup.words: damn, damn it, God damn, Hell, shit, screw, fuck, bastard, son of a bitch, bitch

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe speech or actions that are obscene?
questionGroup.words: obscene, coarse, crude, dirty, filthy, improper, indecent, lewd, naughty, profane, risqué, rude, saucy, suggestive, vulgar

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe someone who uses obscenities a lot?

item.name: Laugh

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe the way a person laughs?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to laughing a little or quietly?
questionGroup.words: laugh silently, chuckle, giggle, ripple of laughter, titter, twitter

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to laughing a lot or loudly?
questionGroup.words: roar with laughter, laugh uproariously, howl with laughter, shriek with laughter, hearty laugh, peals of laughter, laugh helplessly, laugh your head off, laugh hysterically, have hysterics, roll in the aisle, almost die laughing, double up, convulsed with laughter, split your sides

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to laughing for a long time?
questionGroup.words: can't stop laughing, have the giggles, fall over/about laughing, have a good laugh, laugh till the tears roll down your cheeks

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to laughing at someone because they did something wrong?
questionGroup.words: laugh at, mock, titter, snicker, snigger

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to beginning to laugh?
questionGroup.words: start laughing, burst out laughing, burst of laughter, dissolve into laughter

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to causing someone to laugh?
questionGroup.words: make someone laugh, amuse, crack someone up, have someone in hysterics, have someone in stitches, tickle, ticklish

questionGroup.question: (9) What words describe someone or something that causes people to laugh?
questionGroup.words: laughable, amusing, comic, comical, absurd, facetious, humor, humorous, sense of humor

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to the sound of a person makes when he is laughing?
questionGroup.words: ho ho ho, ha ha ha

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to trying not to laugh?
questionGroup.words: (try to/can't) keep a straight face, stifle a laugh

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to smiling?
questionGroup.words: smile, smile at, grin, wide grin, big smile, half smile, slight smile, smirk, crack a smile, beam

questionGroup.question: (13) What other ways do people show they feel good?

item.name: Unity

item.name: Proud

questionGroup.words: snobbish, snobby, haughty, snooty, snotty, superior, stuck-up, class-conscious

item.name: Deserve
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to deserving something--if you do something, either good or bad, something can happen to you as a result of what you did. For instance you can receive a reward for doing good, or a punishment for doing wrong. If what happened to you is like what you did, people can think it is right that this thing happened to you.

item.name: Fight
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to fighting someone. The words in this domain describe a situation in which two people or groups of people fight each other over something or in order to reach some goal. A fight can use words, various kinds of weapons, or other actions. For fights that only use words use the domain 'Quarrel'.

questionGroup.words: fight (n), brawl (n), fracas, fray, free-for-all, melee, scrap, scuffle (n)

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to someone who is fighting?
