item.name: God
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to God--the supreme being in the universe. Each theological system will have different beliefs concerning the existence and nature of God. Our purpose here is to collect and define the terms used to refer to the supreme deity. If there is no such person in the theological system, then use this domain for other terms for the pantheon of gods, ultimate reality, nirvana, and similar concepts. However most theological systems, even atheism, have the concept of a supreme God and use words to refer to him.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the supreme being in the universe?
questionGroup.words: God, the Lord, Yahweh, Elohim, Allah, Theos, Deus, Sky God, supreme being, supreme deity

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what people believe about God?
questionGroup.words: theology, monotheism, polytheism, pantheism, atheism

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something to do with God?
questionGroup.words: divine

item.name: Supernatural being
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to supernatural beings--gods, spirits, other types of beings, which normally cannot be seen and do not belong to this world. Some people accept the existence of certain supernatural beings and not others. Mythological beings are those that were believed in during previous times but that are no longer believed in. Fictional beings are those that no one has ever believed in. An indication of whether most people believe in the supernatural being should be put in the definition.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to supernatural beings?
questionGroup.words: supernatural being, spirit

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to lesser gods?
questionGroup.words: god, goddess, the gods, pantheon, deity

questionGroup.question: (3) What types of good supernatural beings are there?
questionGroup.words: angel, angelic being, cherub, seraph, saint

questionGroup.question: (4) What types of evil supernatural beings are there?
questionGroup.words: demon, devil, Satan, the Devil, Beelzebub

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the spirit of a dead person?
questionGroup.words: spirit, ghost, specter, apparition, phantom, shade, ghoul

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to supernatural beings that are considered to be mythological or fictional and not real?
questionGroup.words: Santa Claus, elf, fairy, giant, dwarf, sprite, genie, dragon, monster, Cyclops, vampire, alien

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe something like or related to a supernatural being?
questionGroup.words: divine, angelic, demonic, Satanic, devilish, diabolical, ghost like, ghoulish, monstrous, alien

item.name: Theology
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to theology--the study of God and what people believe about God.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the study of God and religion?
questionGroup.words: theology

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something you believe about God?
questionGroup.words: doctrine, tenet, dogma, belief

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to disagreement over doctrine?
questionGroup.words: heterodoxy, sect, denomination, dissent

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to foolish or ignorant beliefs about religion?
questionGroup.words: superstition

item.name: Sacred writings
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to sacred writings. Examples are only given for the Christian sacred writings. However you should include words referring to the holy books of all religions .

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: sacred writings, Scripture, Bible, the Good Book, Gospel

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a part of the sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: chapter, verse, text, Old/New Testament, Law, Prophets, Gospels, Epistles, Apocalypse

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to God's role in producing sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: inspire, inspiration, revelation

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe the sacred writings or a text from the sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: inspired, holy, scriptural, biblical, sacred, prophetic, apostolic

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe whether or not a book should be considered a part of the sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: canon, canonical, apocryphal

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to a book that is revered but not considered part of the sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: Apocrypha

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to the interpretation of sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: interpretation, exegesis

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to a book that interprets the sacred writings?
questionGroup.words: commentary

item.name: Miracle, supernatural power
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to miracles--the use of supernatural power to do something good.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to supernatural power?
questionGroup.words: supernatural power, miraculous power, might, force, omnipotence, almighty, all-powerful

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to performing a miracle?
questionGroup.words: perform a miracle, produce a miracle, do a miracle

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the event of a miracle?
questionGroup.words: miracle, miraculous event, sign, wonder, magic

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a miracle?
questionGroup.words: miraculous

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to a person who can perform miracles?
questionGroup.words: miracle worker, prophet

item.name: Sorcery
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to sorcery--the use of supernatural power to do something bad.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to doing something using sorcery?
questionGroup.words: practice sorcery, do magic, work magic, cast a spell, put a spell on, put a curse on, bewitch, conjure, invoke, enchant, bedevil, entrance (v), mesmerize, wave a wand, jinx

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the practice of sorcery?
questionGroup.words: sorcery, magic (n), witchcraft, black magic, voodoo, voodooism, witchery, wizardry, occult, necromancy

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to something that someone does using sorcery?
questionGroup.words: spell, curse, hex, enchantment, charm, incantation

questionGroup.question: (4) What is a person called who practices sorcery?
questionGroup.words: sorcerer, magician, witch, wizard, shaman, witchdoctor, conjurer, necromancer, warlock, charmer, medicine man, alchemist, medium

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe someone or something that can do magic?
questionGroup.words: have magical powers, magic (adj), magical, supernatural, occult, mystic, weird

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe someone who has been bewitched?
questionGroup.words: charmed, bewitched, spellbound, haunted

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to protecting someone from sorcery?
questionGroup.words: ward off

questionGroup.question: (8) What things are used when performing sorcery?
questionGroup.words: charm, amulet, evil eye, talisman, fetish, wand, rod, divining rod, magic ring, philosopher's stone, magic carpet, cauldron

questionGroup.question: (9) What words are used when performing sorcery?
questionGroup.words: abracadabra, open sesame

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to malevolent supernatural power?
questionGroup.words: malevolent power, evil force, Satanic force, demonic power, black magic

item.name: Demon possession
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to demon possession--when a demon or spirit influences or controls the behavior of a person. Use this domain for all words related to the relationship between spirits and people, including communication between people and spirits. Also use this domain for words referring to casting out demons--causing a demon to stop influencing or controlling a person.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being influenced or controlled by a demon?
questionGroup.words: be possessed, be demonized, go into a trance

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what demons do to people?
questionGroup.words: possess, inhabit, demonize, torture, haunt, trouble

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to casting out a demon?
questionGroup.words: cast out a demon, exorcise, drive out, expel, deliver/free/release from demonic power/influence

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a person who casts out demons?
questionGroup.words: exorcist

item.name: Bless
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to blessing someone--saying something that causes something good to happen, or requests God to do something good to someone.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to blessing someone?
questionGroup.words: bless, pronounce a blessing, give a blessing, bestow a blessing, invoke

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is said in blessing?
questionGroup.words: blessing, benediction

item.name: Curse
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to cursing someone.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to cursing someone?
questionGroup.words: curse, put/place a curse on, be under a curse, be cursed

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the curse place on someone?
questionGroup.words: curse, anathema

item.name: Destiny
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to destiny--decisions and actions by God, spirits, or by impersonal forces that determine or influence what happens to a person.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the decisions God makes concerning what happens to a person?
questionGroup.words: God's will, providence

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to an impersonal force that determines what happens to a person?
questionGroup.words: destiny, fate, fortune, luck, chance, throw of the dice

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to something to which a person or thing is destined?
questionGroup.words: destiny, fate

item.name: Prophecy
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to speaking for God, including foretelling the future through divine knowledge.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being able to speak for God or deliver a message from God?
questionGroup.words: prophesy, foretell the future, predict the future

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to what is said?
questionGroup.words: prophecy, prediction, prophetic utterance

questionGroup.question: (3) What is a person called who speaks for God or foretells the future?
questionGroup.words: prophet, prophetess

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something said in prophecy?
questionGroup.words: prophetic

item.name: Omen, divination
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to supernatural knowledge.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to supernatural knowledge?
questionGroup.words: supernatural knowledge, foreknowledge, supernatural insight, ability to interpret dreams

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to being able to divine secrets?
questionGroup.words: divine, read the signs, foretell the future

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the practice of divining secrets?
questionGroup.words: divination, palmistry, fortune telling, astrology

questionGroup.question: (4) What is a person called who can divine secrets?
questionGroup.words: diviner, fortuneteller, astrologer

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe someone who can divine secrets?
questionGroup.words: clairvoyant

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to something showing what will happen in the future?
questionGroup.words: augur, betoken, bode, forebode, foreshadow, foretell, foretoken, ominous, portend, prefigure, presage

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to something that shows or tells a secret?
questionGroup.words: omen, sign, harbinger, portent, presage, foreshadowing, message from the beyond

questionGroup.question: (8) What methods are used to divine secrets?
questionGroup.words: interpret dreams, read palms, read tea leaves, read cards, read the stars, consult your horoscope, look into a crystal ball, play with a Ouija board, examine the entrails of an animal

item.name: Practice religion
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to practicing religion.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to practicing religion?
questionGroup.words: practice your religion, serve God

item.name: Devout
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being devout.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe someone who practices his religion with devotion?
questionGroup.words: devout, devoted, devotion, committed, pious, religious, zealous, saintly, holy

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe someone who is not devout?
questionGroup.words: uncommitted, nominal, lukewarm

item.name: Pray
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to praying--talking to God.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to praying to God?
questionGroup.words: pray, talk to God, beseech

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to prayer?
questionGroup.words: prayer, supplication, intercession, petition, thanksgiving, grace, benediction

questionGroup.question: (3) What actions or postures symbolize prayer?
questionGroup.words: bow your head, kneel, fold your hands

item.name: Worship
item.descr: Use this domain for personal expressions of devotion to God, in whatever ways the religion defines and expresses it.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to relating to God or to the spirits?
(2) What words refer to acts of worship toward God?
questionGroup.words: worship, adore, revere, reverence, lift up your heart, pay homage

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the act of worship?
questionGroup.words: worship, adoration, devotion, homage, service, reverence, veneration, deification, idolization

questionGroup.question: (4) What actions or postures symbolize worship?
questionGroup.words: bow, kneel, genuflect, prostrate oneself

questionGroup.question: (5) What types of actions make up worship?
questionGroup.words: prayer, singing hymns, praising God

item.name: Religious ceremony
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to religious ceremonies.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to performing a religious ceremony?
questionGroup.words: perform a religious ceremony, hold communion

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a religious ceremony?
questionGroup.words: religious ceremony, worship service, church service, time of prayer, prayer meeting, Bible study, liturgy, invocation

item.name: Offering, sacrifice
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to offering a sacrifice.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to offering a sacrifice?
questionGroup.words: sacrifice, offer a sacrifice, offer up, burn on the altar, devote, consecrate

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to offering a sacrifice?
questionGroup.words: sacrifice, offering, devotion, consecration

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to what is sacrificed?
questionGroup.words: sacrifice, offering, burnt offering, votive offering, gift

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a sacrifice?
questionGroup.words: sacrificial (giving, lamb), devoted, consecrated

item.name: Religious purification
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to religious purification.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to purifying someone or something for religious purposes?
questionGroup.words: purify, purification, cleanse, cleansing, wash, washing, sprinkle, sprinkling, baptize, baptism

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that has been purified?
questionGroup.words: be pure, undefiled, unpolluted, washed, sprinkled

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that has not been purified?
questionGroup.words: be impure, defiled, polluted, unwashed

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something that causes impurity?
questionGroup.words: impurity, defilement, pollution

item.name: Taboo
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to things that are taboo--something to be avoided; a religious, social, or cultural restriction on behavior, as opposed to a government law.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a cultural restriction on behavior?
questionGroup.words: taboo, prohibition

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to making something taboo?
questionGroup.words: make taboo, forbid, prohibit, ban

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is taboo?
questionGroup.words: taboo, forbidden, prohibited, untouchable, inviolable, banned, off-limits, avoided

item.name: Salvation
item.descr: Use this domain for the primary goal or goals of a religion, for instance in Christianity salvation from sin, death and Hell. Each religion has different beliefs about salvation. Our purpose here is not to preach or argue, but to list those words that people use to talk about this topic.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to what God does to save a person?
questionGroup.words: save, salvation, sanctify, redeem, justify, regenerate

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person who saves another?
questionGroup.words: savior

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to what a person does to be saved?
questionGroup.words: believe, repent, return (to God), receive, work, earn

item.name: Dedicate to religious use
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to dedicating someone or something to religious use.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to dedicating something to religious use?
questionGroup.words: dedicate, consecrate, anoint, sanctify, devote, hallow, baptize, circumcise

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that has been dedicated?
questionGroup.words: holy, consecrated, sanctified, sacred, devoted, baptized

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that has not been dedicated?
questionGroup.words: unholy, common

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to improperly using something that has been dedicated?
questionGroup.words: desecrate

item.name: Fasting
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to fasting--to not eat for a period of time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to not eating for a period of time?
questionGroup.words: fast, deny (oneself)

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person who denies himself for religious purposes?
questionGroup.words: ascetic

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the general practice of denying oneself something?
questionGroup.words: asceticism

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a time when a person fasts or denies himself in some other way?
questionGroup.words: fast, Lent, Ramadan

item.name: Heaven, hell
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to heaven and hell--the place where people go after they die.

questionGroup.question: (1) What is the place or home of God called?
questionGroup.words: Heaven, the highest heaven, the abode of God, the throne of God

questionGroup.question: (2) What is the place called where dead people are?
questionGroup.words: Hades, Sheol, the place of the dead, the grave, the other side, the beyond, underworld, nether world

questionGroup.question: (3) What is the place called where believers (good people) go when they die?
questionGroup.words: heaven, paradise, your reward

questionGroup.question: (4) What is the place called where unbelievers (bad people) go when they die?
questionGroup.words: hell, the pit, fire and brimstone, eternal damnation

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to going to heaven or hell?
questionGroup.words: pass on, go to heaven, go to hell

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something belonging to heaven or hell?
questionGroup.words: celestial, heavenly, hellish

item.name: Resurrection
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to resurrection--life after death, or living again after dying.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to coming back to life?
questionGroup.words: come back to life, come back from the grave, come to life, resurrection

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to causing someone to come back to life?
questionGroup.words: resurrect, raise from the dead, bring back to life, bring back from the dead

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the condition or state of living forever?
questionGroup.words: live forever, (have) eternal life, life everlasting, immortality, life after death

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to reincarnation?
questionGroup.words: reincarnation, reincarnated

item.name: Religious organization
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to official religions, groups within a religion, and religious meetings. Each religion will have different names for its groups. Answer each question for each religion.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to an official religion?
questionGroup.words: religion, faith

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the names of the official religions?
questionGroup.words: Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Judaism, animism, paganism

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a group within a religion?
questionGroup.words: sect, denomination, party

questionGroup.question: (4) What are the names of the sects?
questionGroup.words: Catholic, Protestant, Baptist, Presbyterian, Methodist

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to a group of believers in a particular place?
questionGroup.words: church, congregation, diocese, parish

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to beginning to believe in a religion or changing from one religion to another?
questionGroup.words: convert, conversion

item.name: Religious person
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to religious practitioners--people who practice a religion, who are members of the religion, believe in the religion, leaders of the religion, and followers of the religion. Each religion has its own terms for religious practitioners. List these terms separately for each religion. The examples given below are for the Christian religion.

questionGroup.question: (1) What is a person called who believes in a religion?
questionGroup.words: believer, member (of the faith), adherent, follower, practitioner

questionGroup.question: (2) What is a person called who believes in the (Christian) religion?
questionGroup.words: Christian, brother, fellow believer, saint

questionGroup.question: (3) What is a leader of the (Christian-Protestant) religion called?
questionGroup.words: pastor, minister, parson

questionGroup.question: (4) What is a leader of the (Christian-Catholic) religion called?
questionGroup.words: priest, father, bishop, archbishop, Cardinal, pope, man of the cloth

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the profession of being a religious leader?
questionGroup.words: pastorate, priesthood, ministry

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refers to all religious leaders?
questionGroup.words: clergy

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to followers of a religion who are not leaders?
questionGroup.words: laity, layperson, flock

item.name: Christianity
item.descr: Use this domain for words used in Christianity.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to talk about Christianity?
questionGroup.words: Christian, Christianity, Jesus Christ, the Virgin Mary, the Trinity, the Father, the Son of God, the Holy Spirit, Lord, cross, crucify, crucifixion, resurrection, Bible, Biblical, Scripture, Old Testament, New Testament, Gospel, apostle, church, chapel, churchgoer, priest, vicar, minister, pastor, service, Communion, Mass, sacrament, baptize, baptism, christen, christening, Christian name, confession, Christmas, Good Friday, Easter, crucifix, make the sign of the cross, saint, patron saint, Roman Catholic, Catholic, Pope, papal, Orthodox Church, Reformation, Protestant Church, Protestant, Anglican, Baptist, Methodist, Lutheran, Presbyterian

item.name: Islam
item.descr: Use this domain for words used in Islam.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to talk about Islam?
questionGroup.words: Islam, Islamic, Muslim, Allah, Mohammad, the Prophet, Koran, Kaaba, mosque, sharia, Ramadan, hajj

item.name: Hinduism
item.descr: Use this domain for words used in Hinduism.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to talk about Hinduism?
questionGroup.words: Hinduism, Hindu, New Age, Vishnu, Vedic, guru, reincarnation

item.name: Buddhism
item.descr: Use this domain for words used in Buddhism.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to talk about Buddhism?
questionGroup.words: Buddhism, Buddhist, Buddha, temple, pagoda, nirvana, enlightenment, monk

item.name: Judaism
item.descr: Use this domain for words used in Judaism.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to talk about Judaism?
questionGroup.words: Judaism, Jew, Jewish, Israel, Torah, Mishna, rabbi, synagogue, kosher, Passover, Hanukkah, Messiah, Mosaic Law

item.descr: Use this domain for words used in Animism--the belief in spirits.

questionGroup.words: Animism, paganism

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to someone who believes in Animism?
questionGroup.words: Animist, pagan

item.name: Religious things
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to a religious object.

questionGroup.question: (1) What types of religious objects are there?
questionGroup.words: altar, altar of sacrifice, altar of incense, censer, candle, church bells, totem pole

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to objects with supernatural power?
questionGroup.words: amulet, charm, fetish

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to clothes worn by priests and other religious people?
questionGroup.words: (priest's) robes, habit, cloth, vestments, frock, cassock, cowl, hood, clerical collar, skullcap, surplice, miter

item.name: Idol
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to idols and their use.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to an object that represents a god?
questionGroup.words: idol, image, icon

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the practice of making and worshiping idols?
questionGroup.words: idolatry

item.name: Place of worship
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to places of worship. Each religion has different types of places of worship. These questions must be answered according to the practices of each religion and for each separate type of place.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a place that is dedicated to God?
questionGroup.words: house of God, church, temple, synagogue, mosque, shrine, god house, sanctuary, tabernacle

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the parts of a church?
questionGroup.words: pew, altar, pulpit, choir loft, baptismal font, stained glass window, steeple

questionGroup.question: (3) What are the parts of a temple?
questionGroup.words: courtyard, holy place, holy of holies, altar, laver, lamp stand

questionGroup.question: (4) Where are idols placed?
questionGroup.words: god shelf, shrine

questionGroup.question: (5) Where do religious leaders live?
questionGroup.words: monastery, convent, parsonage

item.name: Irreligion
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to thinking and acting against God or religion.

questionGroup.question: (1) What is a person called who does not believe in a religion?
questionGroup.words: unbeliever, pagan, gentile, heathen, atheist, agnostic, irreligious, godless

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a religious group, which the official religion considers to be false?
questionGroup.words: false religion, sect

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a belief, which the official religion considers to be false?
questionGroup.words: heresy, heretical, heretic, false doctrine/teaching

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to thinking against God?
questionGroup.words: disbelieve, unbelief, lack of faith, doubt, skepticism, agnosticism, atheism, paganism

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to speaking against God?
questionGroup.words: blaspheme, scoff, profane, irreverent

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to acting against God?
questionGroup.words: sin, impiety, ungodly, godlessness, desecrate, sacrilege

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe someone who is against God?
questionGroup.words: impious, irreligious, profane

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to turning away from God?
questionGroup.words: apostasy, backsliding, reprobate

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to pretending to be religious?
questionGroup.words: hypocrisy, hypocrite

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to extreme beliefs that are evil?
questionGroup.words: fanatic, fanaticism, bigot, bigotry

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to religious practices that are done in ignorance?
questionGroup.words: superstition

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to allowing other people to practice their religion?
questionGroup.words: tolerance, intolerance

questionGroup.words: put things away, store, open a drawer, close a drawer, put things on a shelf

item.name: Household decoration
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to household decorations.

item.name: Prepared food
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to prepared food. Cultures vary widely in the number and types of foods they prepare, and in how they classify them. For instance the English distinction between main dish and side dish is not found in the classification system of other languages. If your language has well-recognized subcategories, you can set up a separate subdomain for each. The questions below are based on the main ingredient in the dish.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to prepared food?
questionGroup.words: cooked food, prepared food, dish, course

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a major class of prepared food?

questionGroup.question: (3) What general words refer to a food made primarily from meat?

questionGroup.question: (6) What types of bread are there?
questionGroup.words: bread, pastry, brown bread, white bread, biscuit, muffin, roll, sweetbread, sandwich, tortilla, toast, loaf

questionGroup.question: (7) What foods are made primarily from fruit?
questionGroup.words: cranberry sauce, applesauce, fruit salad

questionGroup.question: (8) What foods are made primarily from vegetables?
questionGroup.words: side dish, vegetable, carrot sticks, onion rings

questionGroup.question: (9) What foods are made primarily from leaves and stems?
questionGroup.words: salad, tossed salad, green salad, coleslaw

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to foods that contain a lot of water and are boiled?
questionGroup.words: soup, tomato soup, split green pea soup, clam chowder, broth, stew, gravy

questionGroup.question: (11) What types of condiments are there (foods that people only eat a little of, because they are expensive, strong tasting, or are added to other foods to flavor them)?

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to sweet foods?

item.name: Clothes for special occasions

It is necessary to think through all the various special occasions in the culture and think of any special clothes worn on those occasions. Two examples are given below for work and graduation, but there are many others.

item.name: Naked
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being naked--not wearing any clothes, and for words referring to how a person feels about being naked. It is a part of universal human experience that people do not want to be naked. So there are words that refer to feeling bad if one does not have enough clothes on (shame). Other words refer to wanting to have enough clothes (modest). Other words refer to how people feel about other people who do not wear enough clothes (indecent).

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to being naked?
questionGroup.words: be naked, nakedness, nude, nudity, unclothed, nothing on, not have anything on, stripped, bare, expose (oneself)

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to not wearing enough clothes?
questionGroup.words: dress immodestly, immodest, impropriety, indecent

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to not wanting to be naked?
questionGroup.words: modest, propriety, decent

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to feeling bad if you are naked?
questionGroup.words: shame, embarrassed, blush

item.name: Fire
item.descr: Use this domain for general words that refer to fire and for words referring to types of fire. These words may be specific for what is being burned (forest fire 'a fire burning a forest'), the size of the fire (inferno 'a very large hot fire'), or the place where the fire burns (hellfire 'the fire in hell').

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to a fire?
questionGroup.words: fire, combustion

questionGroup.question: (2) What types of fire are there?
questionGroup.words: fireball, torch, firebrand, fireworks, firecracker, burn a field before planting

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to what is being burned?
questionGroup.words: house fire, forest fire, grass fire, wood fire, oil fire

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the size of the fire?
questionGroup.words: spark, flame, flicker, finger, tongue, flare, blaze, conflagration, inferno, raging inferno

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to where the fire is?
questionGroup.words: campfire, hellfire

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to a fire started by accident?
questionGroup.words: blaze, the flames

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to a fire started on purpose?
questionGroup.words: cook fire, bonfire, controlled fire

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to deliberately burning something?
questionGroup.words: burn something, set something on fire, set fire to, torch (v)

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to the crime of burning someone's house or field?
questionGroup.words: arson, arsonist

questionGroup.question: (10) What words describe something that burns easily?
questionGroup.words: flammable, inflammable, combustible

questionGroup.question: (11) What words describe something that will not burn?
questionGroup.words: fireproof, unburnable, fire-resistant, unquenchable

item.name: Light a fire

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something beginning to burn?

questionGroup.question: (3) What things are used to start fires?

questionGroup.question: (4) What materials are used as kindling?

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to restarting a fire that has died down?

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to taking something out of a fire?

item.name: Extinguish a fire

questionGroup.words: extinguish, put out (a fire), fight (a fire), stub out (a cigarette)

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used of stopping a fire with water?
questionGroup.words: douse (a fire), quench (a fire)

questionGroup.question: (7) What equipment is used to stop a fire?
questionGroup.words: fire engine, fire truck, fire extinguisher

item.name: Burn

questionGroup.question: (11) What words describe something that has been burned?

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to staying awake and not going to sleep?

item.name: Try, attempt
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that someone is trying to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to trying to do something?
questionGroup.words: try, attempt, make an attempt, experiment, test, make a stab at it, give it a go, try it out, see if it works, make an effort, aim to do something, assay, endeavor, essay, seek to do something, strain, struggle, undertake, venture, give it a whirl, have a try, try and do something, see if you can do something
questionGroup.sentences: John <tried> to bake bread.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to trying hard to do something?
questionGroup.words: do your best, try your best, put your mind to it, make an effort, be at pains to do something, strive, to the best of your ability, do the best you can, as best you can, give something your best
questionGroup.sentences: John is <striving> to earn enough money to buy a bicycle.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to doing all you can when you are trying to do something?
questionGroup.words: try for all your worth, do your utmost, do everything you can, do all you can, give your all, pull out all the stops, struggle to do something, go to great lengths to do something

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to trying to do something, even though you are unlikely to succeed?
questionGroup.words: have a go, have a stab at, give it a go, put up a good show

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to trying hard to get something that you really want?
questionGroup.words: try for, go for, try out for, shoot for, make a bid for, struggle for, go all out, go after

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to trying hard to do something for someone?
questionGroup.words: bend over backwards to do something, go out of your way to do something, take the trouble to do something

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to doing something in order to try to do something else?
questionGroup.words: try and do something, in an effort to do something, in an attempt to do something

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to an attempt to do something?
questionGroup.words: attempt (n), endeavor (n), try (n), campaign, drive
questionGroup.sentences: The <attempt> was unsuccessful.

item.name: Posture
item.descr: Use this domain for general words indicating the posture or stance of a person's body. Use the domains in this section for specific words for postures and for moving parts of the body. Many of these words have two meanings. One meaning is stative, indicating that the body is in a particular posture, but not moving. The other meaning is active, indicating that the person is moving his body into a particular posture. Some of these words can be used of animals or even things, if the things are perceived as being similar in posture to that of a human body.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to a person's posture?
questionGroup.words: posture, stance, pose, position

questionGroup.question: (2) What general words refer to changing your posture?
questionGroup.words: change your posture/stance, pose, shift, squirm

item.name: Bow
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to bowing to someone--to face someone and lower your head or bend at the waist so that your upper body is lowered. The words in this domain should all be symbolic acts, that is, the culture assigns a meaning and significance to the physical action. Some cultures define it as a greeting, as an act of respect, or as an act of submission. For instance in ancient middle eastern culture bowing was an act of submission done in the presence of the king. Failure to bow was an act of rebellion punishable by death. In far eastern culture it is a greeting. In African culture it is an act of respect or done to welcome a visitor. Cultures define how a person is to bow, for instance how they are to hold their hands. A person may bow while standing, or may kneel, or even prostrate himself flat on his face. Whether both people bow is also significant. The depth of the bow can have significance. In Japan the person of lower social rank must bow deeper. In European culture a performer bows to acknowledge applause.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to bowing?
questionGroup.words: bow, bow down, bow to/before someone

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe how a person bows?
questionGroup.words: sweeping bow, bow low, deep bow, slight bow, bow your head, his head fell, incline your head, nod, curtsy, genuflect, kowtow, prostrate, grovel

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate the significance of the bow?
questionGroup.words: obeisance, worship, bow in submission/reverence/greeting

item.name: Move
item.descr: Use this domain for intransitive verbs of movement referring to moving your whole body to a different location. There are many components of meaning involved in verbs of movement. They can include a source location (from), a goal location (to), a path (along), manner (walk, run), speed (race, crawl), direction (forward, back, side, up, down, toward, away from), shape of the path (straight, curve, circle, angle), relationship to some object or objects (on, hang, against, between, across, through, into, out of, onto, off of, around), proximity (near, far), multiple movements (back and forth, return, bounce), inclusion with other objects or parts of objects (join, leave, collect, disperse, unite, separate), volition (go versus drift), intransitive versus transitive (move versus move something). Some verbs of movement do not involve moving from one place to another, but express bodily movement.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to moving your body to a different location?
questionGroup.words: move, movement, change position, maneuver, jockey for position, budge

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to beginning to move?
questionGroup.words: stir, make a move

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is moving?
questionGroup.words: moving, be in motion

item.name: Turn
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to turning and changing the direction in which one is moving.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to turning around and moving in the opposite direction?
questionGroup.words: turn around, reverse direction, retreat, go back, retire to the rear

item.name: Move in a circle
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to continually changing the direction you are facing in until you are once again facing in the same direction, e.g. moving in a circle, moving around something, or rotating.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving around in a circle?
questionGroup.words: move in a circle, curve, circulate, turn around, swing, cycle

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to moving around something?
questionGroup.words: move around, surround, encircle, revolve, swivel, pivot

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to rotating?
questionGroup.words: rotate, spin, wheel, twirl, whirl, gyrate, roll, gyrate, revolve, swivel

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to rolling something?
questionGroup.words: roll, turn, rotate, spin

item.name: Move back and forth
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to moving back and forth.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving back and forth?
questionGroup.words: move back and forth, rock, rock back and forth, wave, swing

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something moving back and forth quickly?
questionGroup.words: flutter, shake, quiver, tremble

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to shaking oneself?
questionGroup.words: shake, shiver, wiggle, wriggle, squirm, writhe

item.name: Move straight without turning
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to moving straight without changing direction.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving straight?
questionGroup.words: go straight, in a straight line, direct, as the crow flies

item.name: Move toward something
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to moving toward, in the direction of, or near something or some place. The words in this domain should refer to moving in the direction of a place, but should not require that the person actually arrived. Some languages (such as German and Polish) distinguish 'go on foot' from 'go in a vehicle'.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving toward a place?
questionGroup.words: move toward, go toward, head toward, go in the (general) direction of

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to moving near something?
questionGroup.words: approach, move near, come near, move in on

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to two things moving toward each other?
questionGroup.words: converge, be on a collision course
questionGroup.sentences: They didn't know it, but their paths were converging.; The two ships were on a collision course.

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the place toward which a person is moving?
questionGroup.words: destination, goal

item.name: Move away
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to moving away from a place.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving away from something?
questionGroup.words: move from/away/away from, go away, get away, retreat, back off, run away, come from

item.name: Go
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to moving away from the speaker. In Australian languages many movement words are marked for direction toward or away from the speaker.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving away from the speaker?
questionGroup.words: go (away), leave here/this place, get out of here

questionGroup.question: (2) What do people say when they want someone to go away?
questionGroup.sentences: Go away!; Leave me alone!; Get out of my sight!

item.name: Come
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to moving toward the speaker.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving toward the speaker?
questionGroup.words: come, come here

questionGroup.question: (2) What do people say when they want someone to come?
questionGroup.sentences: Come here!; Get over here!

item.name: Wait
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to waiting in a place, waiting to do something, or waiting for something to happen. The basic idea of waiting is for someone to not do anything for a period of time, because he expects something to happen that will cause him to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to waiting?
questionGroup.words: wait, wait for, wait up for, wait on, await, hang on, stand by, wait around, hang around, hold off, wait your turn, sit something out, cool your heels, bide your time, sit tight, sweat it out, hesitate, hesitation, wait and see, wait behind, lie in wait, waiting room, waiting list

questionGroup.question: (2) How do you tell someone to wait?
questionGroup.words: Wait! Wait up. Just a minute. Just a moment. I'll be right with you. Hold on. Hang on. Please hold.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to waiting in a line of people?
questionGroup.words: line up, queue, stand in line, cut in line

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe how a person feels when he must wait?

questionGroup.words: (no words in English)

item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to gathering things into a group. The basic idea of this domain involves a situation in which two or more things are not together, and someone moves them so that they are together.

questionGroup.words: gather, accumulate, amass, assemble, bring together, bunch up, collect, compile, concentrate, consolidate, cumulate, group (v), heap, heap up, herd together, layer (v), mass together, pile, rally, round-up, stack, stack up, load

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to things gathering?

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe things that have been gathered?
questionGroup.words: gathered, collected, concentrated, crowded, crowding, cumulative, massed together, massing, togetherness, heaped, loaded, piled

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a group of things that have been gathered together?
questionGroup.words: gathering, assemblage, bunch, collection, concentration, group, heap, huddle, mass, pile, stack

item.name: Separate, scatter
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to separating things into groups, and scattering things. The basic idea of this domain involves a situation in which two or more things are together, and someone moves them so that they are no longer together.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to separating or scattering things?
questionGroup.words: separate, separation, scatter, disperse, dispersion, dispersal, spread out, spray, move apart, move away from each other, put space between, to space (things), space out, place at intervals, divide, division, blow apart, distribute, sow, strew, sift

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used of separating people?
questionGroup.words: separate fighting people, disperse troops

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe the condition of things when they are separated?
questionGroup.words: separation, dispersion, dispersal, the spread of, division

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a group of things that have been separated?
questionGroup.words: a scattering (of something), Diaspora

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe things that have been scattered?
questionGroup.words: be scattered, thrown apart, resettled, thinly spread, spread out, far flung, flung, dispersed

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to taking something away and putting it aside, separate from the others?
questionGroup.words: set aside, put aside, separate from the others, keep separate, keep special, reserve, pull out

item.name: Organize
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to organizing things, people, events, and ideas--to think about and decide on the pattern a group of things should be arranged in, and then doing whatever is necessary to arrange them so that they can be used for some purpose. This domain is like the domain 'Arrange' except that 'Arrange' emphasizes physically moving the things, and the domain 'Organize' emphasizes the logical system. 'Organize' does not require that the things be moved, only that the logical pattern is specified.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to organizing things?
questionGroup.words: organize, dispose, structure, get together, get it together, get your act together, chart, marshal, put in a chart, put in a table, put in a matrix, sort, sort out, systematize, tabulate

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the pattern in which things are organized?
questionGroup.words: organization, ad hoc, alignment, apparatus, cycle, framework, hierarchy, mechanism, network, order, ordering, pattern, row, sequence, set-up, structure, system

questionGroup.question: (3) What tools and methods are used for organizing things?
questionGroup.words: table, matrix, chart, organizational chart, flow chart, grid, cubbyhole, pigeonhole, in basket, out basket

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to organizing things a second time, or organizing things after they have been disorganized?
questionGroup.words: reorganize, reorganization, adjust, reform, reorder, reordering

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe things that have been organized?
questionGroup.words: organized, ordered, well-ordered, orderly, in order, harmonious, shipshape, structured, systematic, tidy, everything in its place

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe a person who organizes things well?
questionGroup.words: organized, methodical, neat, together

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to when everything is organized?
questionGroup.words: order

item.name: Kick
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to kicking--to hit something with your foot. The words in this domain may be distinguished by the way in which the foot moves, either in a swinging motion, or by first bending the leg and then quickly straightening it. They may also be distinguished by whether the foot moves horizontally or vertically, whether the effect is to move something or damage it, or how hard the person kicks.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to kicking something?
questionGroup.words: kick, give something a kick, kick in (a door), boot, punt, stamp, stomp on, stub your toe on something
