questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to a season of the year?
questionGroup.words: season

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a season related to the time of year?
questionGroup.words: winter, spring, summer, autumn, fall, holiday season, Christmas season, new year, midsummer, midyear

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used for a part of a school year?
questionGroup.words: term, semester, trimester, quarter, midterm

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a season related to the weather?
questionGroup.words: season, rainy season, long rains, short rains, dry season, cold season, hot season

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to a season related to a time of cultivation?
questionGroup.words: planting season, growing season, harvest season, hunger season

item.name: Year
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a year.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a year?
questionGroup.words: year, this year, last year, next year, the years to come

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to indicate that something happens every year?
questionGroup.words: yearly, every year, annually, annual

item.name: Era
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to an era--a very long period of time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to an era?
questionGroup.words: era, age, epoch, the times, generation, this age, the age to come

item.name: Special days
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a special day.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a special day of the year?
questionGroup.words: holiday, vacation

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used for the days when a person works?
questionGroup.words: weekday(s) (Monday through Friday), workday, workweek

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used for the days when a person does not work?
questionGroup.words: weekend, day off, Sabbath, day of rest

item.name: Take time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to taking time to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to how people relate to time?
questionGroup.words: take time, spend time, use time, make time, find time

item.name: A short time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a short time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens for a short time?
questionGroup.words: take a short time, be for a short time, brief, briefly, briefness

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happens for a very short time?
questionGroup.words: moment, instant, point in time, instantaneous, instantaneously

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to taking a short time to do something?
questionGroup.words: be brief, be quick

questionGroup.question: (4) What do people say when they want someone to do something in a short time?
questionGroup.words: be brief, don't take long, get it over with

item.name: A long time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a long time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens for a long time?
questionGroup.words: take a long time, be for a long time, go long, go over the time allotted, take forever, last a long time, went on forever, kept going and going, lengthy, enduring

questionGroup.question: (2) What do people say when they want someone to do something for a long time?
questionGroup.words: take your time, make it last, we want this to last a long time

item.name: Forever
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening forever.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that an event or state that will continue forever?
questionGroup.words: forever, always, ever, eternally, incessantly, unceasingly, forever and ever, in perpetuity, for all eternity, for all time

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to describe something will continue forever?
questionGroup.words: eternal, infinite, everlasting, constant, perpetual, unending, endless, never-ending, unceasing, ceaseless, incessant, undying, immortal, imperishable, deathless, boundless, indefinite, unlimited, immeasurable, never failing, unfailing, timeless

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to indicate that something will continue forever?
questionGroup.words: be forever, last forever, go on forever, always be there, never fail/end/die/stop

questionGroup.question: (4) What words are used to refer to all time or a time that will never end?
questionGroup.words: eternity, infinity, all times

item.name: Temporary
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something being temporary.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something will only last for some time and then end?
questionGroup.words: temporary, transient

item.name: Indefinite time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to an indefinite time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to an indefinite time?
questionGroup.words: when, then, sometime, someday, anytime, onetime, whenever, approximate, approximately

item.name: Telling time
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to telling time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to telling time?
questionGroup.words: tell time, keep time, mark time, measure time, beat time, register the time, to chronicle

questionGroup.question: (2) What is a written record of times and events called?
questionGroup.words: chronology, chronicle, record, history

questionGroup.question: (3) What is a person called who keeps time?
questionGroup.words: timekeeper

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate a particular time?
questionGroup.words: (In written English we use a semicolon to separate the hour from the minute: 5:00.)
questionGroup.sentences: It is now five <o'clock>.; It is five <a.m.>; It is five <p.m.>; It is noon <time>.; ten minutes <after> five.; <half> <past> five.; a <quarter> <to> five.; at ten <of> six.; a <quarter> <of> an hour.; in <half> an hour.; ten minutes <past> <the hour>.

item.name: Plan a time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to planning the time of an event.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to planning the time of an event?
questionGroup.words: plan a time, set a date, schedule something, time something

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the time of an event?
questionGroup.words: time, date, timing

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a plan for the time of an event?
questionGroup.words: schedule, timetable, program

item.name: Clock, watch
item.descr: Use this domain for machines that indicate what time it is.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to machines for telling time?
questionGroup.words: timepiece, watch, clock, alarm clock, digital watch, analog watch, electric clock, sundial, pendulum, hourglass

item.name: Relative time
item.descr: Use the domains in this section for words that relate one time to another. Use this domain for words that indicate a temporal relation between situations.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to one time in relation to another time?
questionGroup.words: relative to, in relation to, before or after
questionGroup.sentences: When did it happen <relative to> his death?

item.name: Order, sequence
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to temporal order or sequence--the order in which a group of events happen. Things and people may also be in order based on the order in which something happened or should happen to them.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the order or sequence of a group of events?
questionGroup.words: order, sequence, cycle, pattern, rota, order of events

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a group of events that happen in order?
questionGroup.words: sequence, series, succession, chain, course, progression

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a group of things in a series?
questionGroup.words: series, lineup, queue

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a group of things that have been put in order?
questionGroup.words: be in order, ordered, in sequence, be the right way round, in chronological order, chronological, consecutive, consecutively, successive, in succession, one after another, one after the other, (three years) running, sequential

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to doing things in order?
questionGroup.words: in order, take turns

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to the particular order in which something comes?
questionGroup.words: place, position, where something comes

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe a group of things that have not been put in order?
questionGroup.words: unordered, out of sequence

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe a group of things in the wrong order?
questionGroup.words: be out of order, be in the wrong order, be the wrong way round, backwards

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to something missing from a group of things in order?
questionGroup.words: gap

questionGroup.question: (10) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a noun phrase with no overt marker.
questionGroup.sentences: the first child; the second taxi; the next person (to speak); the last person (out the door)

questionGroup.question: (11) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a 'be' clause with the 'Item' in the subject position.
questionGroup.words: be
questionGroup.sentences: This child <was> first.

questionGroup.question: (12) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Item' marked by 'of'.
questionGroup.words: of
questionGroup.sentences: the second <of> the winners

item.name: Series
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to a series--several things that happen one after another.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a series of things, events, numbers or people?
questionGroup.words: series, sequence, string of, succession of, stream, train of events, course of

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe things in a series?
questionGroup.words: successive, consecutive, alternating, serial

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that someone does things in a series?
questionGroup.words: in succession, one after the other, one after another, straight, in a row, running, alternate

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the place that something has in a series?
questionGroup.words: place, order, rank, slot, grade

item.name: First
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening first--to be before all other things in order or time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe something that is first in order or time?
questionGroup.words: first, original, initial, earliest, inaugural, prime

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate an event or action that is first?
questionGroup.words: first (adv), first of all, beginning with, starting with

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something happened when you first saw something?
questionGroup.words: at first sight, at first glance

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something is the first in a list of things that you will talk about?
questionGroup.words: firstly, first of all, to start with, to begin with, in the first place

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something happens or is done for the first time?
questionGroup.words: first, the first time

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to the first time someone does something?
questionGroup.words: debut, premiere, maiden (voyage)

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe something that has never happened before?
questionGroup.words: unprecedented, a first

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to doing something that has never been done before?
questionGroup.words: be the first to do something, show the way, lead the way, pioneer, break new ground

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to being the first person to do something in a situation instead of waiting for someone else?
questionGroup.words: make the first move, take the initiative

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to the person who did something first?
questionGroup.words: pioneer, the first

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to something that is the first of its kind?
questionGroup.words: prototype, original (n)

item.name: Next
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening next.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event happens next?
questionGroup.words: next, right afterwards, the day after, then

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens next?
questionGroup.words: next, following, ensuing

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to an event happening next after another event?
questionGroup.words: follow, come next, be after, be next, succeed, come after, go after, go next, ensue

item.name: Last
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening last--to happen after all other things in a sequence, or to be the last person or thing in a sequence.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event happens last?
questionGroup.words: last (adv), at the end

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens last?
questionGroup.words: last (adj), final, closing, concluding

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to an event happening last?
questionGroup.words: come last, end with, finish with

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that a person or thing is the last in a list or line or group?
questionGroup.words: be last, come last, finish last, bring up the rear, straggler, be the last straw

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something is next to the last?
questionGroup.words: next to the last, the last but one, penultimate

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that something is the last before now?
questionGroup.words: last (week), latest

questionGroup.question: (7) What words do people use to indicate the last thing in a list of things they are talking about?
questionGroup.words: lastly, finally, last but not least

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to the last thing?
questionGroup.words: the last, the latter

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to the last part of something?
questionGroup.words: end, ending, finish

item.name: Regular
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something that happens regularly.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens regularly?
questionGroup.words: regular, regularly, at regular intervals, every day, daily, be punctuated by, with great regularity, routine, like clockwork

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happens sometimes but not regularly?
questionGroup.words: intermittently, intermittent, on and off, off and on, in fits and starts, sporadic

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something does not happen regularly?
questionGroup.words: irregular, without warning

item.name: Alternate
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to alternating--when several things happen one after another in a repeated pattern.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to things alternating?
questionGroup.words: alternate, repeat, cycle, rotate

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe things that alternate?
questionGroup.words: alternating, repeated, cyclical, rotating

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that two things alternate?
questionGroup.words: alternate (actions, events)

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to two or more people doing something in alternate turns?
questionGroup.words: alternate, take turns, take it in turns, share, spell each other, go back and forth

item.name: Before
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to one event happening before another.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens before a particular event?
questionGroup.words: before (conj), prior to, on the eve of, pre-
questionGroup.sentences: John took a bath <before> eating dinner.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happens before now or before a particular time?
questionGroup.words: before (adv), earlier, formerly, previously, ago, already

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that someone does something before a particular event?
questionGroup.words: beforehand, in advance, advance, prior

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something must be done before a particular time?
questionGroup.words: before, by, not later than, at the latest

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to something that happened before?
questionGroup.words: antecedent, precedent, precedence, the one before

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something that happened before?
questionGroup.words: previous, old, last (adj), earlier, former, prior, preceding, recent, preliminary

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe a time that comes before another one?
questionGroup.words: previous (day), last (night), the (week) before, the preceding (year)

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that something comes before another in a series?
questionGroup.words: before, in front of, ahead of

questionGroup.question: (9) What words describe something that comes before another in a series?
questionGroup.words: previous, preceding, earlier, the one before

questionGroup.question: (10) What words refer to something happening before something else?
questionGroup.words: come before, precede, predate, lead up to, come first, be before, be a prelude to, anticipate, antedate

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to coming before something else in a series?
questionGroup.words: come before, precede

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to doing something before someone else does it?
questionGroup.words: do something first, be first, beat someone to it, ahead of, be ahead of your time

questionGroup.question: (13) What words refer to a person or thing that existed before another?
questionGroup.words: predecessor, forerunner, precursor, ex-(wife/president)

questionGroup.question: (14) What words describe something that has been mentioned before?
questionGroup.words: above, aforementioned, foregoing

item.name: After
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to one event happening after another.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens after a particular time or event?
questionGroup.words: after, afterward, afterwards, later, later on, subsequently, after that, beyond that, hence

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happens after a certain period of time?
questionGroup.words: after, within, in, from now

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that comes after something else?
questionGroup.words: next, following, later, subsequent, succeeding, ensuing, after, future, consequent, latter

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something happening after something else?
questionGroup.words: follow, come after, ensue, follow-up, be after

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the events that happen after an event?
questionGroup.words: sequel, aftermath, what follows

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to a person who takes a job or position after someone else?
questionGroup.words: successor, next in line, succeed

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to a book or film that comes after another one?
questionGroup.words: sequel

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that something comes after another in a series?
questionGroup.words: after, next, later, further on

questionGroup.question: (9) What words indicate that something will not be done now, but later?
questionGroup.words: later, it can wait, it will wait

questionGroup.question: (10) What words are used to link events when telling a story?
questionGroup.words: and, and then, then, having...-en, after, thereafter, thereon, thereupon, whereupon, upon
questionGroup.sentences: John took a bath, <and> ate a big dinner.; John took a bath, <and then> ate a big dinner.; <Having> tak<en> a bath, John ate a big dinner.; <After> taking a bath, John ate a big dinner.

item.name: At the same time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to two things happening at the same time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that two things happen at the same time?
questionGroup.words: at the same time, together, at one time, at once, simultaneously, at the same instant, in concert, in unison

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happens at the same time as something else?
questionGroup.words: at the same time as, meanwhile, while, as, -ing, simultaneity, concurrently, coincident
questionGroup.sentences: John went out to the garden, carry<ing> his hoe and shovel.; Mary bought food, <while> John got gas for the car.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to two things happening at the same time?
questionGroup.words: coincide, clash

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to arranging two events so that they happen at the same time?
questionGroup.words: synchronize, tie something in with

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe things that happen at the same time?
questionGroup.words: simultaneous, synchronized, parallel, synchronous, contemporaneous, concurrent

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to two people that lived at the same time?
questionGroup.words: contemporary, be a contemporary of someone, be contemporaries

item.name: During
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something happened during some time period, or that something happened while something else was happening.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happened during some time period?
questionGroup.words: during, in, in the course of, during the course of, through, throughout, over, by day, by night, during the middle of, in the interim, within
questionGroup.sentences: It rained <during> the night.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happened during the time when something else was happening?
questionGroup.words: while, meanwhile, in the meantime
questionGroup.sentences: I decided to eat something <while> I waited for the rain to stop.

item.name: Right time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the right time to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the right time to do something?
questionGroup.words: the right time, a good time, be the time

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something happening at the right time?
questionGroup.words: timely, opportune, well-timed, come at the right time

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a person's ability to choose the right time to do something?
questionGroup.words: timing, sense of timing

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the wrong time to do something?
questionGroup.words: the wrong time, a bad time, not a good time, be no time, not be the time

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something happening at the wrong time?
questionGroup.words: badly-timed, ill-timed, come at the wrong time, at a bad time, inopportune

item.name: Early
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that something happens early--before the expected time, before the usual time, or before the time that was agreed on. Some words may include the idea that it is good that the event happened early. Other words may include the idea that it is bad that the event happened early.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens early?
questionGroup.words: early (adv), ahead of time, ahead of schedule, in good time

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens early?
questionGroup.words: early (adj)

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to something happening early?
questionGroup.words: be early

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something happens too early?
questionGroup.words: too early, too soon, untimely, premature, prematurely, jump the gun

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something happens early in the morning?
questionGroup.words: early, first thing, at the crack of dawn, bright and early

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that something will happen no earlier than a particular time?
questionGroup.words: at the earliest, no earlier than

item.name: On time
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something happening on time--at the expected time, at the usual time, or at the time that was agreed on.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens on time?
questionGroup.words: on time, right on time, punctually, promptly, on cue, on the dot, at the right time, at the designated time, at the appointed time, when expected, right when it was supposed to happen, at the exact moment

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens on time?
questionGroup.words: timely

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe someone who does things on time?
questionGroup.words: punctual, prompt

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something happens before it is too late?
questionGroup.words: in time, just in time, in the nick of time, not a moment too soon, at the last minute, at the eleventh hour, catch, cut it fine, cut it too close, made it in by a whisker, just under the wire

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to finishing something within the time that is allowed?
questionGroup.words: meet a deadline, on schedule

item.name: Late
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something happening late--after the expected time, after the usual time, or after the time that was agreed on.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens late?
questionGroup.words: late (adv), not on time, lateness (of the hour), late in life

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens late?
questionGroup.words: late (adj), overdue, belated

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe someone who is late?
questionGroup.words: tardy, latecomer

questionGroup.question: (4) What do people say to someone who is late?
questionGroup.words: about time too, what time do you call this? where have you been? better late than never

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to being late to pay back a loan?
questionGroup.words: be behind with, overdue, be in arrears

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that something happens late at night?
questionGroup.words: last thing at night, in the middle of the night, the early hours, till all hours

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to not finishing something within the time that is allowed?
questionGroup.words: be behind, be behind schedule, be running late, overrun

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that something is too late?
questionGroup.words: too late, it's a little late in the day, leave it a bit late, miss

questionGroup.question: (9) What words indicate that something will happen no later than a particular time?
questionGroup.words: no later than, at the latest

item.name: Delay
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something delaying someone or something--to cause something to happen at a later time, cause someone to do something at a later time, or cause someone or something to be late.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to something delaying someone?
questionGroup.words: delay, make someone late, hold someone up, keep, detain

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something delaying an event?
questionGroup.words: delay, hold something up, set back, put back, get bogged down

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to an instance of delaying something?
questionGroup.words: delay (n), hold-up

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to deliberately delaying someone in order to accomplish something?
questionGroup.words: stall, play for time, delaying tactics

item.name: Postpone
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to postponing something--to decide to do something later.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to postponing something?
questionGroup.words: postpone, put off, delay, reschedule, be put back, defer, table (v)

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to postponing something because you are lazy?
questionGroup.words: put off, procrastinate

questionGroup.question: (3) What do people say when they postpone doing something?
questionGroup.sentences: I'll get around to it someday.; I'll do it later.

item.name: Aspectual time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a time period that is part of a longer time period.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to part of a longer time period?
questionGroup.words: phase, aspect

item.name: Start something
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to starting something, or for something beginning to happen.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to starting something?
questionGroup.words: start, launch, open, initiate, set in motion, get things moving, start the ball rolling, begin

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to officially starting something such as a new law or way of doing something?
questionGroup.words: introduce, bring in, phase in

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to starting an organization?
questionGroup.words: start, start up, open, set up, establish, found, inception

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something starting a natural process?
questionGroup.words: start, activate, set off

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to starting something again after it has stopped?
questionGroup.words: restart, bring back, reintroduce, revive, restore, resurrect

item.name: Beginning
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something beginning to happen, to beginning to do something, to cause something to start happening, or to cause people to start doing something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that something has begun?
questionGroup.words: begin, start, commence, initiate, to institute

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the time when something begins?
questionGroup.words: beginning, the start, commencement, inception, at first, initially, originally

questionGroup.question: (3) What do people say when they want someone else to start?
questionGroup.words: go, dig in, have at it, let's go, let's do it, move it, let's get going, "on your marks, get set, go", "ready, set, go"

questionGroup.question: (4) What is a person called who starts something?
questionGroup.words: initiator, founder, originator, starter

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that some state has begun?
questionGroup.words: achieve, appear, arrive, attain

item.name: Stop something
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the end of an action or situation.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words (intransitive verbs) indicate that something has ended?
questionGroup.words: stop, come to rest, halt, come to a screeching halt

questionGroup.question: (2) What words (transitive verbs) indicate that someone is stopping something?
questionGroup.words: end (something), stop (something), stanch (flow of blood), obstruct (justice), arrest (progress), halt (traffic), impede (progress), inhibit (flow), delay (someone/event), hold up (traffic), detain (someone), discontinue (product), suspend (action), terminate (someone's life), conclude (story), cease (hostilities), desist from (doing something), bring closure to (something), curtail

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the event of stopping?
questionGroup.words: halt, standstill, pause, discontinuance, stoppage, stay, closure

questionGroup.question: (4) Where do things typically stop?
questionGroup.words: stopping place, station

questionGroup.question: (5) What things are used to stop things?
questionGroup.words: brake, catch, skid

questionGroup.question: (6) What do people say when they want someone to stop?
questionGroup.words: Halt! Stay! Cease and desist! Belay that order! Avast!

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe something that you can't stop doing?
questionGroup.words: compulsive

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that some state has ended?
questionGroup.words: cease, finish, stop

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to something stopping gradually?
questionGroup.words: fade away, wear off, go away, die away

item.name: End
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the end of an action or situation.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the end of something?
questionGroup.words: end, finish, conclusion, consummation, culmination, denouement, expiration, finale, homestretch, last, outcome, termination, terminus, terminal, conclusion, time is up, that is all

item.name: Until
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that something will continue to happen until a particular time or until something else happens, and then it will stop.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something will happen until something else happens?
questionGroup.words: (In written English a hyphen is used to indicate that something happens from one time until another time, as in "8:00-5:00" or "Monday-Friday".)

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something will not happen until something else happens?
questionGroup.words: until, wait until

item.name: Since, from
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that something will start to happen at some time and continue for some time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something starts to happen after a particular time and then continues?
questionGroup.words: starting, from, as from, after that

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something started in the past and continued until now?
questionGroup.words: since, ever since, for, from, starting from, from that time on, thereafter

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something starts to happen now and will continue?
questionGroup.words: from now on, from this time forward, starting now, starting from now, effective immediately, henceforth

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something will start in the future and continue?
questionGroup.words: from then on, starting then

item.name: Past
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the past or to a time in the past.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the past?
questionGroup.words: past, before, in the past, in years gone by, in the times of our fathers, in our father's/grandparent's/ancestor's time, was (being/doing/happening), lately

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that existed or happened in the past?
questionGroup.words: earlier, foregoing

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that existed or happened long ago?
questionGroup.words: the distant past, long ago

item.name: Recently
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something happened recently--a short time before now.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event happened a short time ago?
questionGroup.words: recently, not long ago, a short time ago, newly, freshly, a little while back, a short while ago, a little while ago

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that an event happened a very short time ago?
questionGroup.words: just, only just, a moment ago, a minute ago, just this minute, barely, scarcely, hardly
questionGroup.sentences: It <just> happened.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something has been happening up until now?
questionGroup.words: recently, lately, in recent weeks/months, in the last/past few weeks/months, for the last/past few weeks/months

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe an event that has happened recently?
questionGroup.words: recent, latest

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe news of something that happened recently?
questionGroup.words: latest, up-to-date, up-to-the-minute

item.name: Present
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the present time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the present?
questionGroup.words: present, now, right now, is (being/doing/happening), the present day, today

item.name: Now
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to now.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that a situation exists now?
questionGroup.words: now, right now, nowadays, at this time, at the present time, currently, already

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a situation that exists now?
questionGroup.words: current, present, present-day

questionGroup.question: (3) What do you say when you want someone to start doing something now?
questionGroup.words: Go! Now!

item.name: Future
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the future.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to refer to the future?
questionGroup.words: future (n), soon, in the near future, in the distant future, in our children's time, will (be/do/happen), shall, would

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that will exist or happen in the future?
questionGroup.words: future (adj), coming, forthcoming, upcoming, in the offing

item.name: Soon
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening soon.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event will happen soon?
questionGroup.words: soon, sooner, almost, approach, close, directly, imminence, imminent, impending, near, presently, quickly, shortly, about to, in a little while, not long, won't be long, almost here, just around the corner, in the near future, about to happen, any minute (now), in a minute, in a moment

item.name: Not yet
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something not happening yet.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event has not happened yet?
questionGroup.words: not yet, not now, still need to wait, it will be awhile (still), it will take some time, not quite here, almost

item.name: Eventually
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening eventually.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something eventually happened?
questionGroup.words: eventually, in the end, finally, end up, at last, in time

item.name: Immediately
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening immediately--without any time passing before it happens.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that someone does something immediately?
questionGroup.words: immediate, right away, in no time at all

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something happened immediately?
questionGroup.words: immediately, instantly, this instant, sudden, suddenly, right away, right now, at once, without any time going by, without delay, no sooner

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that happens immediately?
questionGroup.words: immediate, instant, instantaneous

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that someone does something immediately without thinking about it?
questionGroup.words: then and there

item.name: Age
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the age of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the age of something?
questionGroup.words: age, how old

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to say how old someone is?
questionGroup.words: be (ten), be (ten) years old, be (ten) years of age, aged (ten), (a boy) of (ten), (ten)-year-old, have turned (ten)

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to say how old something is?
questionGroup.words: be (ten) years old, (ten)-year-old

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that is the same age as something else?
questionGroup.words: the same age

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to all the people of the same age?
questionGroup.words: generation, age group, the under-(ten)s, the over-(ten)s

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to finding out how old something is?
questionGroup.words: date (v), establish the date of, determine the age of

item.name: Young
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something young--a word describing a living thing that has only existed for a short time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe a person or animal that is young?
questionGroup.words: young, little, small

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe someone who is younger than someone else?
questionGroup.words: younger, junior

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a younger brother or sister?
questionGroup.words: younger brother, younger sister, little brother, little sister, kid brother, kid sister

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a plant that is young?
questionGroup.words: green, immature, young

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe someone who looks or acts young?
questionGroup.words: youthful, well-preserved

item.name: Old, not young
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something old--a word describing a living thing that has existed for a long time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe a person or animal that is old?
questionGroup.words: old, elderly, aged, aging, ancient, be getting on, not be as young as you were, patriarchal, senior

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a plant that is old?
questionGroup.words: old, mature

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe someone who is older than someone else?
questionGroup.words: older, elder

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe someone who is older than everyone else?
questionGroup.words: oldest, eldest

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to being almost a particular age?
questionGroup.words: be pushing, be getting on for

item.name: New
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something new--a word describing something that has only existed for a short time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe something that is new?
questionGroup.words: new, newness, newly, modern, state-of-the-art, untrodden, up-to-date

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that has just been made?
questionGroup.words: new, brand new, fresh

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe food that is new?
questionGroup.words: fresh, raw

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that has been sold for only a short time?
questionGroup.words: new, brand new, recent, latest, be just out, be hot off the press

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe an organization that has existed for a short time?
questionGroup.words: new, young

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something that has just been discovered?
questionGroup.words: new, newly discovered, fresh

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe an experience or feeling that you have never had before?
questionGroup.words: new, newfound

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe a new idea or way of doing something?
questionGroup.words: new, newfangled, avant-garde, contemporary, forward-looking, fresh, futuristic, go-ahead, be in its infancy, innovative, inventive, modern, ultra-modern, move with the times, novel, original, originality, pioneering, present-day, progressive, revolutionary, up-to-date, up-to-the-minute, ahead of your time

questionGroup.question: (9) What words describe someone who has recently arrived in a place or just started a new job?
questionGroup.words: new, newcomer, new arrival, be new to, fresh, green, stranger

questionGroup.question: (10) What words describe something or someone that has recently replaced the one before it?
questionGroup.words: new, fresh

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to changing something that is old, so that it is like new?
questionGroup.words: renew, renewal, freshen, modernize, modernization, recondition, reconditioning, refresh, refurbish, refurbishing, rejuvenate, rejuvenation, renovate, restore, update, bring something up to date

questionGroup.question: (12) What words describe something that is old, but has been made to look new?
questionGroup.words: as good as new, renewed, freshened, modernized, reconditioned, refreshed, refurbished, rejuvenated, renovated, restored

questionGroup.question: (13) What words refer to something that is new?
questionGroup.words: novelty, innovation, latest, original

item.name: Old, not new
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something old--a word describing something that has existed for a long time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe something that is old?
questionGroup.words: old, older, oldest, dated, late

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is very old?
questionGroup.words: age-old, be as old as the hills, ancestral, ancient, be around from time immemorial

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is old and belongs to an early period of history?
questionGroup.words: primeval, antediluvian, medieval, primordial

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that is old and good?
questionGroup.words: antique, classical, time-honored, vintage

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that is old and not good?
questionGroup.words: crumbling, declining, decrepit, dowdy, effete, faded, past its prime, rusty, worn out

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something that has been used and is no longer new?
questionGroup.words: old, used, second hand, worn, time-worn

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe food that is old?
questionGroup.words: stale, decayed

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe an organization that has existed for a long time?
questionGroup.words: old, has a long history

questionGroup.question: (9) What words describe something that people have known about for a long time?
questionGroup.words: old hat

questionGroup.question: (10) What words describe an experience or feeling that you have had before?
questionGroup.words: familiar

questionGroup.question: (11) What words describe someone who has been in a place for a long time or has worked at a job for a long time?
questionGroup.words: old-timer, old hand, no stranger (to these parts)

questionGroup.question: (12) What words refer to something being older than other things like it?
questionGroup.words: outgrow, outlive, outwear

questionGroup.question: (13) What words describe something or someone that has been replaced by a new one?
questionGroup.words: old, former

questionGroup.question: (14) What words refer to changing something that is new, so that it looks like it is old?
questionGroup.words: antique (v), antiquate, give something an antique look

questionGroup.question: (15) What words refer to something that is old?
questionGroup.words: antique, antiquities

item.name: Modern
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something modern--a word that describes something like a machine, system, or country that uses the most recent equipment, ideas, and methods.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe a modern machine or system?
questionGroup.words: modern, up-to-date, advanced, sophisticated, high-tech, state-of-the-art, be ahead of its time, at the leading edge of, at the cutting edge of

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe a modern country?
questionGroup.words: advanced, developed

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a modern person or organization?
questionGroup.words: progressive, innovative, forward-looking, move with the times, go-ahead

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe modern art, literature, or music?
questionGroup.words: contemporary, avant-garde, futuristic

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to changing something to make it modern?
questionGroup.words: modernize, bring something up to date, update

item.name: Old fashioned
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something old fashioned--something that was done or used in the past, but not done or used now.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe something that is old fashioned?
questionGroup.words: old-fashioned, unfashionable, antiquated, archaic, outdated, out of date, outmoded, outworn

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is old fashioned and no longer used?
questionGroup.words: antiquated, dated, fusty, early type/form of, obsolete, primitive

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe an old fashioned idea or way of doing something?
questionGroup.words: old, customary, inveterate, passé, traditional, tried and true, well-trodden

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that is so old fashioned that people think it is stupid?
questionGroup.words: medieval, out of the ark, dinosaur, anachronism, archaic

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that is old fashioned but people still like it?
questionGroup.words: quaint, old-time, of the old school, olde worlde

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to something becoming old fashioned?
questionGroup.words: be on the way out, fall into disuse

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to making something old fashioned by doing the same thing a new way?
questionGroup.words: antiquate, render obsolete

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe someone who is old fashioned in the way they think or act?
questionGroup.words: old fashioned, be behind the times, be living in the past, reactionary, straitlaced

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to someone who is old fashioned?
questionGroup.words: fuddy-duddy, old fogy, old guard, traditionalist

item.name: Once
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening once.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event has happened once?
questionGroup.words: once, one time, on one occasion, at one stage, at one point, one day

item.name: Again
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening again or doing something again.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event happens again?
questionGroup.words: again, once again, once more, yet again, one more time, afresh, fresh, another time, another time

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to doing something again?
questionGroup.words: do something again, repeat, redo, over, all over again
questionGroup.sentences: (Mary washed the dress, but it wasn't clean so) she washed it <again>.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to starting to do something again that you had been doing before?
questionGroup.words: return to, go back to, get back to, resume, resumption, bring back, revive, revival

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to having to start something again from the very beginning?
questionGroup.words: back to square one, make a fresh start

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to being back to the same situation that you were in before?
questionGroup.words: again, once more

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to taking an examination again?
questionGroup.words: retake, resit

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to something you do again?
questionGroup.words: repetition

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that something is done many times?
questionGroup.words: repeated, repeatedly, recurrent, recurring, repetitive, again and again, over and over again, always, never stop
questionGroup.sentences: Mary washed the dress <over and over again>.

item.name: Sometimes
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening sometimes.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that an event happens sometimes?
questionGroup.words: sometimes, occasionally, every so often, once in a while, at times, now and again, now and then, from time to time

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens sometimes?
questionGroup.words: occasional, the odd, periodic, intermittent, casual

item.name: Often
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening often--happening or done many times.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate how often something happens?
questionGroup.words: often, frequently, time after time, time and again, repeatedly, many a time, hundreds of times, half the time, at frequent intervals
questionGroup.sentences: Mary <often> washes the dress.; I have <frequently> lent John money.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that happens often?
questionGroup.words: frequent, repeated, habitual

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something does not happen often?
questionGroup.words: rarely, infrequently

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that does not happen often?
questionGroup.words: rare, infrequent

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate how often something happens?
questionGroup.words: how often, how many times, the number of times, frequency

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to something happening more often?
questionGroup.words: increasingly

item.name: All the time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening all the time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something happens or a situation exists all the time?
questionGroup.words: all the time, always, constantly, permanently, permanent

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that a situation exists during a time period?
questionGroup.words: throughout, all through, the whole time, all day, all week, from start to finish

item.name: Every time
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to something happening every time something else happens.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something always happens?
questionGroup.words: always, habitually

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that when one thing happens something else always happens?
questionGroup.words: every time, whenever

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something happens every day or week?
questionGroup.words: every (day)
questionGroup.sentences: John waters his cows <every> evening.

item.name: Never
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that something that never happens, or that something has not once happened.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something that never happens?
questionGroup.words: never, not ever, never once, not once, never for a moment, not for a moment, never ever, at no time, not in a million years, never in a million years, have never been known to do something

item.name: Continue, persevere
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to continuing to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to continuing to do something?
questionGroup.words: continue (doing something), remain at (something), keep on (doing something), stay at (it), stick to (it), hold on, keep (going), keep at (it), sticktoitiveness, sustain

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is continuing?
questionGroup.words: continuity, continual, continuous, to last (for a long time), endure, enduring, lasting, continuing, remain, perpetual, durable, rest, retain, stand, endless

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to continuing to do something without waiting?
questionGroup.words: go ahead, proceed

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something that continues?
questionGroup.words: continuum

item.name: Interrupt
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to interrupting someone--speaking when someone is speaking, or doing something to stop someone from doing what they are doing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to interrupting someone or something that is happening?
questionGroup.words: interrupt, break in, stop, butt in, interruption, intermission, interlude

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to describe something that is not interrupted?
questionGroup.words: incessant, uninterrupted

item.name: Start again
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to starting to do something after stopping for some time.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to continue doing something after stopping?
questionGroup.words: continue, start again, resume, get on with, get around to

item.name: Interval
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to an interval between two events.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the time period between events?
questionGroup.words: interval, space things out

item.name: Speed
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the speed at which a person acts or the speed at which something happens.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the speed at which a person acts?
questionGroup.words: speed, velocity, pace

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to indicate the speed of something?
questionGroup.sentences: miles <per> hour

item.name: Quick
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to doing something at a quick speed or something happening quickly.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe an action that is done quickly?
questionGroup.words: fast, quick, quickly, quickness, speedy, speeding, speedily, speed, hasty, hastily, haste, rapid, rapidly, rapidity, hurry, hurried, hurriedly, in a hurry, swift, swiftly, swiftness, rush, rush into, rush through, in a rush, express

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe an action that is done extremely quickly?
questionGroup.words: at light speed, faster than a speeding bullet, just a blur

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that happens quickly?
questionGroup.words: happen so fast, in the twinkling of an eye, came and went so quickly, it was all over in a minute

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to doing something quickly?
questionGroup.words: to speed, move fast, hurry, hasten, be brief

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to causing someone to do something quickly?
questionGroup.words: hurry (someone), rush (someone)

questionGroup.question: (6) What do you say to someone when you want him to hurry?
questionGroup.words: Hurry up! Move it! Let's go, let's go! Quick! Faster! Speed it up! Get a move on! Giddy up! (horse)

item.name: Slow
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to doing something at a slow speed.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe an action that is done slowly?
questionGroup.words: slow, slowly, leisurely

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe an action that is done extremely slowly?
questionGroup.words: excruciatingly slow, move at a snail's pace, gradual, gradually, little by little, bit-by-bit, glacial

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to doing something slowly?
questionGroup.words: go slow, slowness, take your time (over)

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to causing someone to do something slowly?
questionGroup.words: slow (someone) down, hold back, restrain, delay, hold up

questionGroup.question: (5) What do you say to someone when you want him to do something slowly?
questionGroup.words: Slow down! Take it easy! Take your time! Whoa! (horse)

item.name: Sudden
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a sudden event--something happens that I don't expect.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to moving suddenly?
questionGroup.words: move suddenly, sudden movement

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to indicate that an event is sudden?
questionGroup.words: sudden (warning), all of a sudden, abrupt

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to indicate that something happened suddenly?
questionGroup.words: suddenly, abruptly, without warning, without notice

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the suddenness of something?
questionGroup.words: suddenness

item.name: Location
item.descr: Use this domain for words that refer to the place where something is located and for words indicating the location of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the location of something?
questionGroup.words: location, position, place, venue, at, spot

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is located somewhere?
questionGroup.words: be at, at, be, be located, location
questionGroup.sentences: John <is at> home.; John <is> here.; The books <are> in the box.; The office <is located> in the next building.; The <location> of the library <is> in the Academic Building.; Here <is> John.; There <are> the potatoes.; the steps <at> the door

item.name: Here, there
item.descr: Use this domain for words that refer to a place in relation to the speaker or listener.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a place near the speaker?
questionGroup.words: here, hereabouts, hither, in this place, on this very spot, around here

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a place near the listener?
questionGroup.words: there, thereabouts, thither

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a place that is not near the speaker or the listener?
questionGroup.words: over there, elsewhere, yon, yonder

item.name: In front of
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to being in front of you.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is in front of something else?
questionGroup.words: front, in front, in the front, up front, forward, in the foreground, be in front, out in front, before, ahead of

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the front of a line of people or vehicles?
questionGroup.words: the front

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to being at the front of a line?
questionGroup.words: at the front, at the head of, leading

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something is in front of you?
questionGroup.words: in front, ahead, up ahead

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that two people are in front of each other?
questionGroup.words: face to face, facing each other

item.name: Behind
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is behind you.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is in back of something else?
questionGroup.words: behind, in back, way back, in the rear, background

item.name: Beside
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that something is to the side of someone.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is beside something else?
questionGroup.words: be beside, alongside, along, next to, at your side, be way over to the side, be on the right, be on the left

item.name: Around
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is around something else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is around something else?
questionGroup.words: be around, surrounding

item.name: Between
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is between two other things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is between two other things?
questionGroup.words: between, amid, amidships, amidst, among, amongst, betwixt, center, central, equidistant, half-way, mean, medial, median, medium, mid, middle, middlemost, midst, midway, therein, throughout, within

item.name: On
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is on another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is on something else?
questionGroup.words: be on, be on top of, topside, upon

item.name: Above
item.descr: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something is above another thing. The concept 'above' is inherently relational, expressing the relative positions of two things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is above something else?
questionGroup.words: above, higher than, over, overhang, up above, super-, supra-, on high

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is above something else?
questionGroup.words: aloft, overhanging, overhead, upper

item.name: Under, below
item.descr: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something is under another thing. The concept 'under' is inherently relational, expressing the relative positions of two things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is under something that is directly above it?
questionGroup.words: under, underneath, beneath, under-, sub-

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is in a lower position or on a lower level?
questionGroup.words: below, beneath, sunken, lower

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is under a covering (such as clothes, skin, or paint)?
questionGroup.words: under, underneath, beneath

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to being under something?
questionGroup.words: underlay, underlie

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that is under another thing?
questionGroup.words: underlying, nether

item.name: Inside
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is outside something else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is in something else?
questionGroup.words: be in, inside, inner, within

item.name: Out, outside
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is outside of another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is outside of something else?
questionGroup.words: be out, outside, outer

item.name: Touching, contact
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that two things are touching or in contact with each other.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to two things touching each other?
questionGroup.words: contact, be in contact, touch, rest against, up against, together, end to end

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to two things moving until they touch each other?
questionGroup.words: come into contact, make contact, touch, bump into, come together, brush, skim, graze, meet, connect, butt up against, come to rest against

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is touching another?
questionGroup.words: abutting, adjoining, contiguous

item.name: Next to
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is next to something else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is next to another?
questionGroup.words: next to, right next to, right up next to, by, beside, neighbor, juxtaposed, nearest

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is next to something long such as a road?
questionGroup.words: along, alongside, by the side of, at the side of

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something such as a building or country is next to another?
questionGroup.words: next door, adjoin, border (v)

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that two things are next to each other and facing in the same direction?
questionGroup.words: side by side, abreast

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that is next to another?
questionGroup.words: the next, adjacent, adjoining, bordering, neighboring

item.name: Across
item.descr: Use this domain for words that refer to a place on another side of something from the reference point. 'Across' involves three things--the object, the reference point, and something else in between the two.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is across from something else?
questionGroup.words: across, across from, on the other side of, on the opposite side of, beyond, offshore from
questionGroup.sentences: The village was on the other side of the river from us.

item.name: Indefinite location
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is at an indefinite location.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to an indefinite location?
questionGroup.words: somewhere, anywhere, someplace, anyplace, where, here, there, over there, any old place, wherever, who knows where, could be anywhere, undisclosed location, location unknown, here and there, whereabouts, hereabouts, thereabouts

item.name: Direction
item.descr: Use this domain for general words referring to a direction.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a direction?
questionGroup.words: direction, orientation, course, way, bearing
questionGroup.sentences: What <way> did he go?; He headed in that <direction>.; Turn to a <bearing> of 270 degrees.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to facing in some direction?
questionGroup.words: face (v), point, orient
questionGroup.sentences: Turn and <face> north.; The temple <faced> east.; We buried him with his feet <pointing> west.; The captain <pointed> the ship into the wind.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a person's ability to know what direction he is going in?
questionGroup.words: sense of direction

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that two things are going in the same direction?
questionGroup.words: with
questionGroup.sentences: We were carried down the river <with> the current.

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that two things are going in different directions?
questionGroup.words: against
questionGroup.sentences: The ship was sailing <against> the wind.

item.name: Forward
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a forward direction.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the direction forward?
questionGroup.words: forward, ahead

item.name: Backward
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a backward direction.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the direction backward?
questionGroup.words: back, backward, behind, reverse

item.name: Right, left
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to right and left.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the right side?
questionGroup.words: right

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the left side?
questionGroup.words: left

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a person who usually uses his right hand?
questionGroup.words: right-handed

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a person who usually uses his left hand?
questionGroup.words: left-handed

item.name: Up
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the direction up.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the direction up?
questionGroup.words: up, upwards, upward, uphill, upstairs, higher and higher, up and down

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is facing or pointing upwards?
questionGroup.words: face-up

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that a path or road goes upward?
questionGroup.words: go up, climb, rise

item.name: Down
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the direction down.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the direction down?
questionGroup.words: down, downwards, downhill

item.name: Away from
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a direction away from something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is moving away from something else?
questionGroup.words: toward, towards, away from, inward, inwards, outward, outwards

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something moves from one place (to another place)?
questionGroup.words: from

item.name: Towards
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a direction toward something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is moving toward something else?
questionGroup.words: toward, towards, away from, inward, inwards, outward, outwards

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something moves (from one place) to another place?
questionGroup.words: to

item.name: North, south, east, west
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the directions of the compass.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to a direction of the compass?
questionGroup.words: direction, heading, point of the compass, degree, bearing, cardinal points

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a direction of the compass?
questionGroup.words: north, south, east, west, northeast, northwest, southeast, southwest, northward, southward, eastward, westward, northerly, southerly, westerly, easterly, up north, down south, sunrise, sunset

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is toward one of the directions of the compass?
questionGroup.words: northern, southern, eastern, western, boreal, austral, oriental, occidental, Midwestern, Far East

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something going in one of the directions?
questionGroup.words: northbound, southbound, eastbound, westbound

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe a person who is from a part of the country that is north, south, east, or west?
questionGroup.words: northerner, southerner, easterner, westerner

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to a compass?
questionGroup.words: compass, needle

item.name: Be at a place
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being at a place.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something or someone is in a particular place?
questionGroup.words: be at a place/location, be in a place/location, be located, be situated, be localized, attendance, be present, presence, sit, lie, laid, occupy, be resting

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something or someone is in the correct or expected place?
questionGroup.words: in place, in the proper place, in your place, out of place

item.name: Absent
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being absent--to not be in a particular place, or not be in the correct or expected place.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something or someone is not in a particular place?
questionGroup.words: be absent, not be here, not be around, be out, not be in, be away, missing, be off, not be at, not be there, absence, be gone, not present, be away, nowhere to be found, out of sight, truant, absent without leave, AWOL, missing in action, not show up, make yourself scarce, minus someone, be lacking, lose, elsewhere, somewhere else

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person who is absent?
questionGroup.words: absentee, truant, missing person, no-show

item.name: Area
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to an area.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to an area?
questionGroup.words: area, region, district, expanse (of land)

item.name: Vicinity
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to a vicinity--an area around something else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the area around something else?
questionGroup.words: area, vicinity, environs, neighborhood, surroundings, community, district, region, context

item.name: Occupy an area
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to occupying an area.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to occupying an area?
questionGroup.words: occupy, occupy an area, take up space, cover an area, fill

item.name: Space, room
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the amount of empty space that is available to be used.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the amount of empty space that is available to be used?
questionGroup.words: space, room, clearance, floor space, elbow room

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to providing space for someone or something?
questionGroup.words: make room, clear a space, make way, get out of the way

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe a situation where there is just enough room?
questionGroup.words: a tight squeeze, barely enough room, close fit

item.name: Interval, space
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to an interval or space between things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the area between things?
questionGroup.words: space, gap, opening, break, interval, separation, hole

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to arranging things with spaces between them?
questionGroup.words: space out

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that things have spaces between them?
questionGroup.words: spaced, apart, be spaced out

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that things are arranged with regular spaces in between?
questionGroup.words: at regular intervals, every meter, evenly spaced

item.name: Spatial relations
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate a spatial relation between situations.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that a situation happened at the same place as another situation?
questionGroup.words: where, in the same place as, at the same place as
questionGroup.sentences: He is sitting <where> I was sitting.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that a situation happened at a different place as another situation?
questionGroup.words: somewhere else, elsewhere

item.name: Contain
item.descr: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something contains something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something contains something?
questionGroup.words: have, of, -'s, contain, hold

questionGroup.question: (2) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb 'contain' with the 'Container' in the subject position and the 'Content' in the object position.
questionGroup.sentences: The cup <contained> milk.

questionGroup.question: (3) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb with the 'Container' in the subject position, the 'Content' in the object position, and the 'Container' in a preposition phrase marked by 'in'.
questionGroup.sentences: The cup <has> milk <in it>.

questionGroup.question: (4) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.
questionGroup.sentences: a cup <of> milk

questionGroup.question: (5) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.
questionGroup.sentences: the <container> <of> milk

questionGroup.question: (6) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'contents' as the head and the 'Container' marked by 'of'.
questionGroup.sentences: the <contents> <of> the cup

questionGroup.question: (7) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a possession phrase with the 'Container' in the first position and the word 'contents' in the second position.
questionGroup.sentences: the cup<'s> <contents>

item.name: Parts of things
item.descr: Use this domain for words that refer to a part of something. These words are often based on the parts of a person's body.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to a part of something?
questionGroup.words: part, piece, section, component, portion, bit

questionGroup.question: (2) If something has two sides, what words refer to the other side?
questionGroup.words: the back, the reverse, the other side, the flip side

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the part of something used to hold it?
questionGroup.words: handle, grip

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the main part of something?
questionGroup.words: body, chassis

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to something added to the main part?
