questionGroup.words: appendage, appurtenance, adjunct, accessory, addition, attachment

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to a layer of something?
questionGroup.words: layer, level, stratum, stratified, story, floor, sandwich

questionGroup.question: (7) What other words refer to a part of something?
questionGroup.words: flap, detail, bar, blade, hook, lid, neck, nose, shelf, wheel, longitudinal, projection

item.name: Front
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the front part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the front of something?
questionGroup.words: front (n), face, facade

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the front?
questionGroup.words: front (adj), frontal, anterior

item.name: Back
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the back part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the back of something?
questionGroup.words: back (n), rear, hind end

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the back?
questionGroup.words: back (adj), rear, posterior

item.name: Top
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the top part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the top of something?
questionGroup.words: top (n), topside, summit, peak, pinnacle, cap, head

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the top?
questionGroup.words: top (adj), uppermost

item.name: Bottom
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the bottom part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the bottom of something?
questionGroup.words: bottom (n), underside, base, breech, foot, foundation, ventral, undersurface

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the bottom?
questionGroup.words: bottom (adj)

item.name: Side
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the side part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the side of something?
questionGroup.words: side (n), flank, right side, left side

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to an area that is on one side of a border or wall
questionGroup.words: side

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is on the side?
questionGroup.words: side (adj), lateral

item.name: Inner part
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the inside part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the inside part of something?
questionGroup.words: inside (n), interior, innards, lining, framework

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the inside?
questionGroup.words: inside (adj), interior, inner

item.name: Outer part
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the outside or surface part of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the outside part of something?
questionGroup.words: outside (n), exterior, surface, cover, covering, skin, shell

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the outside?
questionGroup.words: outside (adj), outer, external, surface, superficial

item.name: Middle
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the middle part or center of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the middle part of something?
questionGroup.words: middle (n), center, the heart of, core

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is in the middle?
questionGroup.words: middle (adj), center (adj), central

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is in the middle of a thing or area?
questionGroup.words: in the middle, at the center

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the middle position between two places, times, or amounts?
questionGroup.words: in the middle, halfway, midway, midpoint

item.name: Edge
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the edge of something--the part of something where two sides come together.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the edge of something?
questionGroup.words: edge (n), border, outskirts, perimeter, margin, periphery, curb

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the edge of an area of land?
questionGroup.words: border, boundary, frontier

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the edge of a cup or plate?
questionGroup.words: rim, lip, brim

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the edge of a piece of clothing?
questionGroup.words: hem, fringe

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to something put along the edge of something?
questionGroup.words: frame, edging, skirting

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something that is on the edge?
questionGroup.words: edge (adj), peripheral, marginal, border (adj), bordering

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to the corner of something?
questionGroup.words: corner (n)

questionGroup.question: (8) What words describe something that is on the corner?
questionGroup.words: corner (adj)

item.name: End, point
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the end of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the end of something?
questionGroup.words: end (n), point, tip, nose, head

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is on the end?
questionGroup.words: end (adj), pointy

item.name: Grammar
item.descr: Use this domain for technical linguistic terms that refer to grammatical words and constructions. Most languages have few if any words in this domain.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the study of grammar?
questionGroup.words: grammar, syntax, morphology

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to types of grammatical words?
questionGroup.words: noun, verb, adjective, adverb, conjunction, preposition, particle, article, word, participle, infinitive, part of speech, compound, derivative

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to types of grammatical constructions?
questionGroup.words: phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to parts of words?
questionGroup.words: root, stem, affix, prefix, suffix, ending, morpheme

questionGroup.question: (5) What words are used to talk about grammar?
questionGroup.words: inflect, inflection, case, decline, declension, conjugate, conjugation, parse, paradigm, rule, singular, plural

questionGroup.question: (6) What words are used to talk about the sounds of a language?
questionGroup.words: letter, consonant, vowel, syllable

item.name: General words
item.descr: Use the following section for words that don't belong in any other domain because they are so general in meaning that you can use them to talk about any topic. Use this domain for general and indefinite words that can be used in the place of any word. Some languages have a general word that can replace a noun or a verb. For instance some Philippine languages use the word 'kwan' in this way. Colloquial German can use the word 'dings' as a noun or verb. Often these words are used when you can't remember the particular word you are trying to think of. In English we use the word 'blank' when we don't want to say a word, for instance when we are testing someone and want them to say the word.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words can be used in the place of any word?
questionGroup.words: blank, ... (ellipsis), you know what I mean

item.name: Be
item.descr: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'be' may be used to identify something, describe something, and many other ideas.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to something being something?
questionGroup.words: be, represent, amount to, form, make, constitute
questionGroup.sentences: Your idea <is> good.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is being identified?
questionGroup.words: is
questionGroup.sentences: John <is> our new leader.; This <is> a pine tree.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that a group of things is something?
questionGroup.words: make up, form, constitute, add up to

item.name: Exist
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something exists.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that something exists?
questionGroup.words: exist, existence, there is, there exists, there lives, be, be found, occur, be in existence, be in operation, real
questionGroup.sentences: <There is> a man....; <There was> a man....; <There exists> evidence....; Evidence <exists>....; God <exists>.; I think, therefore I <am>.; Once upon a time <there lived> a man....

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something starting to exist?
questionGroup.words: appear, arise, coalesce, come into being, come into existence, come to be, develop, emerge, form, materialize, spring up, take shape

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to continuing to exist?
questionGroup.words: remain, persist, persistence, survive, survival, survivor

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something ceasing to exist?
questionGroup.words: become extinct, extinction, die out, disappear, vanish, cease to exist, disappearance, disintegrate, disintegration, fade, loss

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to not existing?
questionGroup.words: non-existent, extinct, there's no, there's no such thing

item.name: Become, change state
item.descr: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of change of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'become' may be used to a change in identity, a change in characteristic, a change in nature, and many other ideas.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate a change of state?
questionGroup.words: become (characteristic), change, come to be, turn, get, develop, grow into, turn into, change into, become different, evolve
questionGroup.sentences: John <became> president last year.; The sky <turned> red as the sun set.; After a long illness, John finally <got> better.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used of causing or producing a state?
questionGroup.words: produce, cause to be, make to be, make, make into, result in, bring upon, bring about
questionGroup.sentences: He <made> me angry.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used of attaining a state?
questionGroup.words: come to be, attain, achieve, reach
questionGroup.sentences: He <reached> the age of 100.

item.name: Have, of
item.descr: Many languages have several general words that are used to indicate a variety of relationships between two things. There are three such words in English: "have," "of," and the possessive suffix "-'s." The basic meaning of these words in English is 'to own', but they can mean many other things too. For instance they can mean that I am related to someone (I have a brother), something has a part (birds have wings), and many other ideas. There is also a set of pronouns in English that are like nouns ending in -'s (my/mine, your/yours, his, her/hers, its, our/ours, their/theirs, whose). Use this domain for these general words.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words relate two nouns?
questionGroup.words: have, of, -'s
questionGroup.sentences: Own: John <has> a house (to sell), the house <of> John, John<'s> house, hi<s> house, who<se> house (is this?), the house is hi<s>; Kinship: John <has> a brother, the brother <of> John, John<'s>brother, hi<s> brother; Relationship: John <has> a friend, the friend <of> John, John<'s> friend, a friend of hi<s>; Member: The school <has> (a hundred) students, the students <of> the school, the school<'s> students; Part: Trees <have> leaves, the leaves <of> the tree, the tree<'s> leaves, it<s> leaves; Name: John <has> three names, the three names <of> John, John<'s> three names, hi<s> names; Know: John <has> the answer, John<'s> answer, hi<s> answer; Hold: John <has> the key (in his pocket), John<'s> key, hi<s> key; Feel: John <has> anger, the anger <of> John, John's anger, hi<s> anger; Sickness: John <has> cancer, John<'s> cancer, hi<s> cancer; Located on: The yard <has> a fence, the yard<'s> fence; Be pictured in: the photo <of> John, John<'s> photo, hi<s> photo; Quality: John <has> status, the status <of> John, John<'s> status, hi<s> status; Use: The secretary <has> a computer, the computer <of> the secretary, the secretary<'s> computer, the computer is her<s>; Event: the arrival <of> John, John<'s> arrival, hi<s> arrival

item.name: Attribution
item.descr: Attributes often belong to a class of attributes (shape = straight, curved) or to a scale (length = long, short). The class or scale can sometimes be included in the expression, but does not mark the proposition itself. (The towel <feels> damp. The box <weighs> five kilos.)

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate an attribute of something?
questionGroup.words: found to be, discover to be, turn out to be, be in many ways
questionGroup.sentences: <be> characteristic, state; <have> condition; <bear> characteristic; <be in a state of> characteristic; The dirt <is> red.; The towel <is> damp.; This man <is> important.; This man <has> an important status.; The towel<'s> dampness.; The dampness <of> the towel.; The damp state <of> this towel.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate a point on a scale?
questionGroup.sentences: The box <weighs> five kilos.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate an evaluation of something?
questionGroup.sentences: That woman <is> beautiful.

item.name: Do
item.descr: Use this domain for general verbs with a volitional subject (agent).

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to someone doing something?
questionGroup.words: do, act, actuate, behave, accomplish, achieve, attain, conduct, effectuate, engage in, execute, exercise, exert, function, give, go about, dabble in, implement, manage, perform, practice, progress, undertake, up to, use, utilize, work, operate, be involved in

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the thing that is done?
questionGroup.words: deed, thing to do, something to do, what you do, act (n), action, activity, event, behavior, accomplishment, achievement, attainment, execution, exercise, function (n), job, implementation, measure, performance, practice (n), task, undertaking, work (n), workmanship, feat, exploits, operation

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to the person doing something?
questionGroup.words: achiever, actor, doer, performer, agent

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe someone who is doing something?
questionGroup.words: active, in action

questionGroup.question: (5) How do you ask someone what he is doing?
questionGroup.words: What are you doing? What are you up to? What do you think you are doing?

item.name: Happen
item.descr: Use this domain for non-volitional pro-verbs.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to something happening?
questionGroup.words: happen, occur, take place, chance, befall, betide, supervene

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something that has happened?
questionGroup.words: event, experience, affair, occurrence, phenomenon, occasion

item.name: React, respond
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to reacting or responding to something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to reacting or responding?
questionGroup.words: react, respond

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to reacting to someone in the same way they treat you?
questionGroup.words: reciprocate, give back

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to reacting too strongly?
questionGroup.words: overreact

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to how someone reacts?
questionGroup.words: reaction, response, feedback, backlash

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the ability to react quickly to something?
questionGroup.words: reactions, reflexes

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to reacting in a good way?
questionGroup.words: responsive

item.name: Create
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to creating something--causing something to be that did not exist before.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to inventing something?
questionGroup.words: create, dream up, imagine, compose, contrive, design, devise, invent, conceive of, think up, make up

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something that has been invented?
questionGroup.words: design, invention, conception, dream

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to something that has been created?
questionGroup.words: creation, creature

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a person who creates?
questionGroup.words: creator, inventor

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that was created?
questionGroup.words: created

item.name: Design
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to designing something--to decide and plan how something new will look and work.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to designing something?
questionGroup.words: design, plan

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the way something is designed?
questionGroup.words: design

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to someone who designs things?
questionGroup.words: designer, architect, planners

item.name: Make
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to making something--joining things together to create something to be that did not exist before.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to making something?
questionGroup.words: make, build, construct, create, fabricate, fashion, form, generate, manufacture, prepare, produce, shape, bring into being

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something that has been made?
questionGroup.words: artifact, building, construction, manufactured goods, product, production

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a person who makes something?
questionGroup.words: builder, maker, producer, manufacturer

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that was made?
questionGroup.words: man-made, hand-made, manufactured, artificial, synthetic

item.name: Change something
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to someone changing something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to refer to changing something?
questionGroup.words: change (v), change (n), revise, revision, revolutionize, revolution, reform, reformation, modify, modification, develop, development, make different, impact, process, transform

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person who changes something?
questionGroup.words: revolutionary, reformer, radical

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that can be changed?
questionGroup.words: changeable

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe a big change?
questionGroup.words: big, major, sweeping, radical, fundamental, revolutionary, monumental

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe a small change?
questionGroup.words: small, slight, tiny, minute

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe a quick change?
questionGroup.words: quick, fast, rapid

questionGroup.question: (7) What words describe a slow change?
questionGroup.words: slow, gradual

item.name: Event propositions
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate event propositions. Event propositions are similar in that they are normally expressed by a subject and a verb, possibly including an object, indirect object, or complement clause. However there are multiple ways in which a language can express an event, such as a passive construction, noun phrase, or subordinate clause. In addition each event type is different in its primary cases, and in the ways those cases are marked. Each event type has subtypes, such as intransitive, transitive, and ditransitive verbs. A great deal of research is needed in order to identify all the variations. Ultimately every verb must be investigated to determine how it behaves in each syntactic construction and how its case relations are marked. No two verbs are entirely alike.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate an event?
questionGroup.words: -ing, -'s...-ing, -ing...of, to
questionGroup.sentences: A bark<ing> dog (kept me awake last night).; The dog<'s> bark<ing> (woke me up).; The bark<ing> <of> a dog (woke me up).; (John told me) <to> wake him up at 6 a.m.; I want <to> do something.; He started do<ing> something.

item.name: Thing
item.descr: Use this domain for general words referring to things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to a thing?
questionGroup.words: thing, something, article, artifact, entity, item, object, wares

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a group of things of different types?
questionGroup.words: things, oddments, paraphernalia, stuff, odds and ends, bits and pieces, knick-knacks

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to refer to something when you can't remember what it is called?
questionGroup.words: what's its name, thingy, thingamajig, whatchamacallit, whatsit, such and such

questionGroup.question: (4) What words are used to end a list of things to indicate that there are more things in the list?
questionGroup.words: et cetera, etc., and what not, and so forth, and the like, and on and on, ... [ellipsis]

item.name: Physical, non-physical
item.descr: Use this domain for words describing something that is physical--that you can touch and see, and for words describing something that is non-physical--that you cannot touch or see.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe something that is physical?
questionGroup.words: animal nature, biological, bodily, concrete, corporal, corporeal, earthly, earthy, fleshly, incarnate, inferior, matter, material, materialistic, mundane, natural, objective, physical, seen, sensible, sensual, tangible, temporal, unspiritual, worldly
questionGroup.sentences: A ghost cannot take <physical> form.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something that is physical?
questionGroup.words: substance, stuff, matter, material

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is non-physical?
questionGroup.words: disembodied, extramundane, extrasensory, immaterial, impalpable, incorporeal, instinctive, intangible, intellectual, libidinal, life, mental, metaphysical, nonphysical, nonmaterial, numinous, otherworldly, preternatural, psychic, psychological, rational, reasoning, spiritual, spiritualist, subjective, supernatural, transcendent, transcendental, unbodied, unearthly, unseen, unworldly
questionGroup.sentences: Thoughts and ideas belong to the <spiritual> realm.

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something that is non-physical?
questionGroup.words: spirit

item.name: Situation
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a situation--a particular time and place, and the things that are true about it.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the general situation that exists in a place?
questionGroup.words: situation, things, conditions, state of affairs, set-up, context

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a situation that affects what can happen or what people can do?
questionGroup.words: situation, circumstances, environment, climate, conditions, the lay of the land, which way the wind blows, scenario

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a situation that exists at some time during a larger event or process?
questionGroup.words: situation, position, state of play

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to the true situation rather than the situation that people think exists?
questionGroup.words: the picture, the score, what's going on

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to the situation a person is in?
questionGroup.words: situation, circumstances, position, case, plight

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that something must happen or cannot happen because of the situation?
questionGroup.words: under the circumstances, in the circumstances, given the circumstances, given the situation, as it is, as things stand, force of circumstances, the way things are

item.name: General adjectives
item.descr: Use this domain for general adjectives that can replace or stand for a specific adjective.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words can replace an adjective?
questionGroup.words: such, that kind of, that sort of
questionGroup.sentences: We all admire <such> a man. (a generous man); We all admire <that kind of> a man.; We all admire <that sort of> a man.

questionGroup.question: (2) What question words ask for an adjective in the answer?
questionGroup.words: what kind of, what sort of
questionGroup.sentences: <What kind of> a man is he? (a good man); <What sort of> man is he?

questionGroup.question: (3) What question words ask for an ad-adjective in the answer?
questionGroup.words: how
questionGroup.sentences: <How> big a box is it? (very big)

item.name: General adverbs
item.descr: Use this domain for general adverbs that can replace or stand for other adverbs.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words can replace an adverb?
questionGroup.words: thus, thusly, so, how, like this, this way, in that way, in this manner
questionGroup.sentences: We would like you to do it <thus>.; I'll show you <how> I want it.

item.name: Part of speech
item.descr: This domain is for organization purposes and should not be used for any words. Use the domains in this section for words that belong to a particular part of speech. It is best not to use these domains, since they are based on grammar and not meaning. But if you have a small group of words that belong to a part of speech and you want to list them all, you can use these domains. You can also classify words in this section if you don't know what they mean yet.

item.name: Adjectives
item.descr: Use this domain to list all adjectives. If there are many adjectives in your language, you should not try to list them all here. If you want to find all the adjectives, most dictionary programs can sort your dictionary by part of speech. However if your language only has a few adjectives, you can list them all in this domain. In the book, "Where Have All the Adjectives Gone?" R. M. W. Dixon [Dixon, R. M. W. 1982. Where have all the adjectives gone? Berlin: Mouton.] identifies seven universal semantic types that are often expressed by adjectives. They are: Age (new, young, old), Dimension (big, little, long, short, wide, narrow, thick, fat, thin), Value (good, bad, proper, perfect, excellent, fine, delicious, atrocious, poor), Color (black, white, red), Human propensity (jealous, happy, kind, clever, generous, cruel, rude, proud, wicked), Physical property (hard, soft, heavy, light, rough, smooth, hot, cold, sweet, sour), Speed (fast, slow). Words in the Human propensity class may be nouns. Words in the Physical property and Speed classes may be verbs.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the adjectives in your language?
questionGroup.words: young, big, good, black, kind, hot, fast

item.name: Adverbs
item.descr: Use this domain to list all adverbs. If there are many adverbs in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.

questionGroup.question: (1) What adverbs are in your language?
questionGroup.words: quickly

item.name: Pronouns
item.descr: Use this domain for the personal pronouns, including independent, subject, object, and possessive pronouns. It is best to collect all the pronouns in a chart. This way you are more certain of collecting them all and seeing how they are related to each other. A language may have more sets and more distinctions than English does, or it may have less. For instance some languages have a pronoun 'we' which includes the hearer, and another pronoun 'we' which excludes the hearer. Other languages have an indefinite pronoun that means something like the English word 'someone'. Many languages do not have the masculine (he), feminine (she), and neuter (it) distinctions that English has. It is necessary to determine the sets and functions of the pronouns for each language.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to the class of pronouns?
questionGroup.words: pronoun

questionGroup.question: (2) What pronouns refer to the speaker?
questionGroup.words: I, me, my, mine

questionGroup.question: (3) What pronouns refer to the speaker and those associated with the speaker?
questionGroup.words: we, us, our, ours

questionGroup.question: (4) What pronouns refer to the audience?
questionGroup.words: you, your, yours

questionGroup.question: (5) What pronouns refer to the people or things being spoken about?
questionGroup.words: he, him, his, she, her, hers, it, its, they, them, their, theirs

questionGroup.question: (6) What pronouns are used for the subject of a sentence?
questionGroup.words: I, you, he, she, it, we, you, they
questionGroup.sentences: <I> went to town.

questionGroup.question: (7) What pronouns are used for the object of a sentence?
questionGroup.words: me, you, him, her, it, us, you, them
questionGroup.sentences: John hit <me>.

questionGroup.question: (8) What pronouns are used in a possessive phrase?
questionGroup.words: my, your, his, her, its, our, your, their
questionGroup.sentences: This is <my> house.

questionGroup.question: (9) What pronouns are used in a possessive clause?
questionGroup.words: mine, yours, his, hers, its, ours, yours, theirs
questionGroup.sentences: That house is <mine>.

questionGroup.question: (10) What pronouns are used to emphasize the people or things being spoken about, especially when you are emphasizing that one person does something and not someone else?
questionGroup.words: as for me (I), as for you (you), as for him (he), as for us (we), as for them (they)
questionGroup.sentences: He <himself> admits he is guilty.; I did it <myself> without any help.; You can do what you want. <As for me>, I'm not going.

item.name: Reflexive pronouns
item.descr: Use this domain for pronouns that refer back to the subject of the sentence. These pronouns should be added to the chart of personal pronouns.

questionGroup.question: (1) What pronouns express reflexive reference?
questionGroup.words: self, myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves, oneself
questionGroup.sentences: I cut <myself>.

questionGroup.question: (2) What pronouns express reciprocal reference?
questionGroup.words: each other, one another
questionGroup.sentences: They hit <each other>.; We should help <one another>.

item.name: Indefinite pronouns
item.descr: Use this domain for pronouns that do not refer to a definite person or thing, but can refer to anyone or anything. Some languages will not have all the sets of pronouns described below. Add each set you find in your language to the pronoun chart.

questionGroup.question: (1) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a person?
questionGroup.words: person, who, someone, anyone, everyone, no one, each one, whoever

questionGroup.question: (2) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a thing?
questionGroup.words: thing, what, something, anything, everything, nothing, each thing, whatever, whichever

questionGroup.question: (3) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a time?
questionGroup.words: time, period, when, sometime, anytime, every time, never, at no time, each time, whenever, sometimes

questionGroup.question: (4) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a place?
questionGroup.words: place, where, somewhere, anywhere, everywhere, nowhere, each place, wherever, which way

questionGroup.question: (5) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a reason?
questionGroup.words: reason, why, for what reason, for some reason, for any reason, for each and every reason, for no reason, why ever

questionGroup.question: (6) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a manner?
questionGroup.words: manner, means, how, somehow, anyhow, every way, no way, each way, however

questionGroup.question: (7) What pronouns express indefinite reference of an amount?
questionGroup.words: amount, how much, however many, however much, plenty

item.name: Relative pronouns
item.descr: Use this domain for pronouns used in relative clauses.

questionGroup.question: (1) What pronouns are used in relative clauses?
questionGroup.words: who, whom, that, which, why
questionGroup.sentences: I'm looking for the man <who> killed John.; I found the coin <that> I lost.; That is the reason <why> I did it.

item.name: Question words
item.descr: Use this domain for pronouns used in questions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What pronouns are used in questions?
questionGroup.words: who, what, when, where, how, why
questionGroup.sentences: <Who> is that?; <Where> did you go?; <How many> did you get?; <How often> will you go?; <Why> did you do that?

item.name: Demonstrative pronouns
item.descr: Use this domain for demonstrative pronouns.

questionGroup.question: (1) What pronouns are used to indicate a particular referent?
questionGroup.words: a, an, the, this, these, that, those, specific
questionGroup.sentences: <the> leader; <a> really old man; <this> new shirt; <these> tomatoes; <that> book; <those> flowers; I want <this>.; <That> is what I want.

item.name: Personally
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that someone does something himself, rather than through someone else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that you do something yourself, rather than through someone else?
questionGroup.words: personally, in person, direct
questionGroup.sentences: You don't need to do anything. I will take care of it <personally>.; Instead of sending a representative, he is coming <in person>.; You can talk to him <direct>.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to indicate that you make something yourself rather than using a machine?
questionGroup.words: by hand
questionGroup.sentences: We made this book entirely <by hand>, using locally available materials.

item.name: Prepositions, postpositions
item.descr: Use this domain to list all prepositions and postpositions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What prepositions are in your language?
questionGroup.words: in, on, at, from, to, away, toward, about

item.name: Conjunctions
item.descr: Use this domain to list all conjunctions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What conjunctions are in your language?
questionGroup.words: and, or, but

item.name: Phrase conjunctions
item.descr: Use this domain to list all phrase level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two words within a phrase.

questionGroup.question: (1) What conjunctions join two words within a phrase?
questionGroup.words: and, both...and, or, either...or, neither...nor, but
questionGroup.sentences: coming <and> going; me <and> you; men <and> women; <both> this <and> that; <either> good <or> bad; <neither> good <nor> bad; quickly <but> not carelessly

item.name: Clause conjunctions
item.descr: Use this domain to list all clause level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two clauses.

questionGroup.question: (1) What conjunctions join two clauses?
questionGroup.words: and, or, while, then, if, because
questionGroup.sentences: You come here <and> I'll go there.; You come here <or> I'll go there.; You come here <while> I go there.; You come here <then> I'll go there.; <If> you come here, I'll go there.

item.name: Sentence conjunctions
item.descr: Use this domain to list all sentence level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two sentences.

questionGroup.question: (1) What conjunctions join two sentences?
questionGroup.words: then, so
questionGroup.sentences: I want you to come here. <Then> I'll go there.; You wanted to come here. <So> I decided to let you.

item.name: Particles
item.descr: Use this domain to list all particles.

questionGroup.question: (1) What particles are in your language?
questionGroup.words: He lives <just> across the street.

item.name: Classifiers
item.descr: Use this domain to list all classifiers.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the class of something?
questionGroup.words: (Japanese) -hon (long objects), -mai (flat objects), -ban (order in a series), -nin (people), -fun (minutes), -dai (large vehicles)

item.name: Interjections
item.descr: Use this domain to list all interjections.

questionGroup.question: (1) What interjections are in your language?
questionGroup.words: Wow! Hold on! Good grief!

item.name: Onomatopoeic words
item.descr: Use this domain to list all onomatopoeic words. If there are many onomatopoeic words in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.

questionGroup.question: (1) What onomatopoeic words are in your language?
questionGroup.words: knick-knack, flimflam

item.name: Affixes
item.descr: Use this domain to list all affixes that do not fit in any of the subdomains under it. This section should be filled out by a linguist.

questionGroup.question: (1) What affixes are in your language?
questionGroup.words: -s, -ed, -ing

item.name: Verb affixes
item.descr: Use this domain to list all verb affixes.

questionGroup.question: (1) What affixes can be joined to verbs?
questionGroup.words: -ing, -ed, -s

item.name: Noun affixes
item.descr: Use this domain to list all noun affixes.

questionGroup.question: (1) What affixes can be joined to nouns?
questionGroup.words: -s, -en

item.name: Derivational affixes
item.descr: Use this domain to list all derivational affixes. A derivational affix is joined to a root and changes it into a different word. Derivational affixes often change the root into a different part of speech. Adding a derivational affix usually changes the meaning of the root in a significant way.

questionGroup.question: (1) What derivational affixes are there?
questionGroup.words: un-, a-, self-, super-, -ment, -hood, -ous, -ly, -fy

item.name: Very
item.descr: Use this domain for words that intensify an attribute.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words intensify an attribute?
questionGroup.words: very, really, highly, deeply, real, so, mighty, one, quite, ever so, bloody, decidedly, too, proper, true, extremely, such
questionGroup.sentences: <very> green; <too> dark; <really> fast; <real> good; <pretty> heavy

questionGroup.question: (2) What words intensify an attribute to an extreme degree?
questionGroup.words: extremely, terribly, dreadfully, incredibly, unbelievably, ridiculously, absurdly, remarkably, exceptionally, extraordinarily, terrifically, enormously, hugely, exceedingly

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that an attribute is not intense?
questionGroup.words: not very, hardly, barely, a little, fairly

item.name: Degree
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate a degree on a scale.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the degree of something?
questionGroup.words: degree, extent, level, thus

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate a degree on a scale?
questionGroup.words: high, low, greater, lesser, first, primary, secondary
questionGroup.sentences: Ambassador Stevenson is a very <high> level official.; <Low> priority tasks should be placed later in the list.; The musician gave a <first> rate performance.; Finding a suitable place to live was of <primary> importance.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a marked extent?
questionGroup.words: up to, as much as, to the degree that

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a change in degree?
questionGroup.words: fluctuate, fluctuation, move, vary

questionGroup.question: (5) What words express a comparative degree?
questionGroup.words: more, -er
questionGroup.sentences: fast<er>

questionGroup.question: (6) What words express a superlative degree?
questionGroup.words: most, -est
questionGroup.sentences: fast<est>

item.name: To a large degree
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a large degree.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate a large degree?
questionGroup.words: large, great, major, considerable, large scale, huge, enormous, immense, tremendous, high, advanced, rich

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a large degree?
questionGroup.words: size, magnitude

item.name: To a small degree
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a small degree.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate a small degree?
questionGroup.words: deficient, inappreciably, inconsequentially, insignificantly, lacking, lightly, limited, little, low, merely, moderately, negligibly, piddling, possible, puny, reasonably, relatively, slightly, somewhat, sparingly, temperately, trivial, trivially

item.name: To a larger degree
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a larger degree.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is becoming larger in degree?
questionGroup.words: advance, double, explode, gain, grow, increase, jump, rise, rocket, soar, triple

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the amount by which something became larger?
questionGroup.words: growth, explosion, hike, increase, rise

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to causing something to become larger in degree?
questionGroup.words: increase, raise, swell

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something is larger than another thing in degree?
questionGroup.words: more than

item.name: To a smaller degree
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a smaller degree.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is becoming smaller in degree?
questionGroup.words: decline, decrease, diminish, drop, dwindle, fall, plummet, slide, tumble

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the amount by which something became smaller?
questionGroup.words: decline (n), decrease, fall, reduction, tumble

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to causing something to become smaller in degree?
questionGroup.words: decrease, lower, reduce

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something is smaller than another thing in degree?
questionGroup.words: less than, lower

item.name: Completely
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is done to a complete degree?
questionGroup.words: completely, fully, totally, entirely, wholly, absolutely, utterly, positively, in every way, in every respect, in every sense, through and through, wholeheartedly, altogether, out-and-out, outright, perfect, perfectly, roundly, solid, solidly, thoroughly, unmitigated, unqualified, utter

questionGroup.question: (2) What general words refer to all of something's attributes or manners?
questionGroup.words: completely, in every way

questionGroup.question: (3) What words describe something that is done completely?
questionGroup.words: complete, thorough, full, comprehensive, exhaustive, entire

item.name: Partly
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is done partly?
questionGroup.words: partly, partially, to some extent, to a certain extent, to a degree, to some degree, up to a point, in part, sort of

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is done one part at a time?
questionGroup.words: gradually, in stages, step by step, one step at a time, in increments, incrementally, piecemeal, by degrees, little by little

item.name: Do intensely
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating intensity of an action.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that something is being done intensely?
questionGroup.words: intense, intensely, extensively

item.name: Attribution of an attribute
item.descr: Use this domain for words that modify an attribute.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words modify an attribute?
questionGroup.words: fairly, sort of, quite
questionGroup.sentences: <light> blue, <dark> red, <dull> gray, <faded> colors

item.name: Semantic constituents related to verbs
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that modify verbs.

item.name: Tense and aspect
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense and aspect.

item.name: Tense
item.descr: Use this domain for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense (also known as temporal deixis)--the time of a situation (event, activity, or state) in relation to a reference point, which is usually the time of utterance. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) present: the situation occurs simultaneously with the moment of speech.
(2) past: the situation occurred before the moment of speech.
(3) future: the situation takes place after the moment of speech; the speaker predicts that the situation in the proposition will hold.
(4) crastinal: tomorrow.
(5) hesternal: yesterday.
(6) hodiernal: today, normally with past.
(7) pre-hodiernal: before today.
(8) post-crastinal: after tomorrow.
(9) ancient past: used for narrating events in ancient or mythical time.
(10) remote: combines with other tense labels to indicate a situation occurring temporally distant from the moment of speech.
(11) immediate: a meaning label that may be combined with other tense labels to indicate a situation not simultaneous with the moment of speech, but very close to it.
(12) immediate future: what is about to occur.
(13) immediate past: occurring immediately before the moment of speech. Also called the Recent Past. Do not use this label if there is any sense of current relevance--use anterior for that.
(14) Immediate may also be combined with anterior or imperative.
(15) expected future: the situation is to occur in the near future; what is scheduled to happen.
(16) narrative time: the use of a form with no other past uses for reporting a past narrative.

(17) gnomic present: the situation described in the proposition is generic; the predicate has held, holds, and will hold for the class of entities named by the subject, such as 'Elephants have trunks'.
(18) What general words refer to the tense of an event?
questionGroup.words: tense, time

questionGroup.question: (19) What words are used to indicate the present tense?
questionGroup.words: (no words or affixes in English)

questionGroup.question: (20) What words are used to indicate the past tense?
questionGroup.words: -ed, (in English vowel replacement is also used to indicate past tense, e.g. run, ran)

questionGroup.question: (21) What words are used to indicate the future tense?
questionGroup.words: will, going to

item.name: Aspect--dynamic verbs
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of dynamic verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) habitual: the situation is customary or usual, repeated on different occasion over a period of time. English 'used to' is past habitual; English 'Nancy sings' is present habitual.

(2) continuous: a single situation is viewed as in progress, as maintained over a period of time; also called "durative." The English "Progressive" is a continuous restricted to dynamic words. English 'I am reading; *I am knowing the number'.
(3) continuative: keep on doing what is being done. Restricted to dynamic words.

(4) progressive: the action takes place simultaneously with the moment of reference, 'to be in the process of...'. This is more restricted than the English Progressive, which may be used for events that are not actually in progress at reference time: 'I am writing a book' may be used even if the speaker is not at that moment writing.
(5) excessive duration: action is extended over a long period of time, longer than normal for that action.
(6) limited duration: action performed for a relatively short or bounded period of time.
(7) iterative: the action is repeated on one occasion; usually restricted to dynamic words, often further restricted to semelfactive words.
(8) frequentative: action occurs frequently, not necessarily habitually, nor necessarily on one occasion, as is the iterative.
(9) imperfective: the situation is viewed as unbounded in the sense that it is habitual, continuous, progressive, or iterative.
(10) perfective: the situation is viewed as bounded temporally. It cannot be simultaneous with the moment of speech; in the non-past it is sometimes interpreted as future.
(11) completive: to do something thoroughly and to completion, e.g. 'to shoot someone dead, to eat up'.
(12) inceptive: the action or event begins. We are distinguishing this from the beginning of a state.
(13) delimited: action is performed only a little.
(14) The preceding terms or "Aspects" are not usually relevant to stative words.
(15) What general words refer to an aspect of an event?
questionGroup.words: aspect

questionGroup.question: (16) What words are used to indicate that something has begun?
questionGroup.words: begin, start, commence, beginning, the start, commencement, initiate, to institute, inception

questionGroup.question: (17) What do people say when they want someone else to start?
questionGroup.words: go, dig in, have at it, let's go, let's do it, move it, let's get going, "on your marks, get set, go", "ready, set, go"

questionGroup.question: (18) What is a person called who starts something?
questionGroup.words: initiator, founder, originator, starter

questionGroup.question: (19) What words are used to indicate that someone is attempting to do something?
questionGroup.words: try, attempt

questionGroup.question: (20) What words are used to indicate that something is being done quickly?
questionGroup.words: quick, quickly, rapidly

questionGroup.question: (21) What words are used to indicate that something happened suddenly?
questionGroup.words: sudden, suddenly, suddenness, immediate

questionGroup.question: (22) What words are used to indicate something is continuing?
questionGroup.words: continue, continuous, keep on

questionGroup.question: (23) What words are used to indicate that something has been completed?
questionGroup.words: complete, finish, succeed

item.name: Aspect--stative verbs
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of stative verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) state exists: the state is begun before reference time and continues after reference time.
questionGroup.words: is

questionGroup.question: (2) state commences: beginning of a state of "becoming." Often called Inceptive or Inchoative. If there is a morpheme specifically for this meaning, it is usually derivational and restricted to stative words. However, it is also possible for "Perfects" or "Perfectives" to have this as their use with stative words.
questionGroup.words: becoming

questionGroup.question: (3) state ends: state existed in the past, but no longer exists. Also a possible meaning of "Perfects" or "Perfectives" in combination with stative words.
questionGroup.words: no longer

questionGroup.question: (4) state continues: state is continuing a reference time.
questionGroup.words: still

questionGroup.question: (5) state changes: (self-explanatory).
questionGroup.words: turn

item.name: Relational tenses
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate relational tenses. Relational tenses describe situations where the reference time is not the same as the moment of speech. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) resulting state (resultative): action in the past produces a state that persists into the present.
questionGroup.words: be... -en

questionGroup.question: (2) anterior continuing: past action continues into the present: 'I have waited over an hour' ( = and I'm still waiting).
questionGroup.words: have been... -ing

questionGroup.question: (3) anterior: the situation occurs prior to reference time, and is relevant to the situation at reference time. This is different from a simple past or perfective, where the situation is reported for its own sake and independent of its relevance to any other situation.
questionGroup.words: have... -en

questionGroup.question: (4) A form that signals a situation that is prior to and relevant to a past reference time will be coded with two meaning labels, past and anterior.
questionGroup.words: had... -en

item.name: Agent-oriented modalities
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate agent-oriented modalities. Agent-oriented modalities describe internal or external conditions on a willful agent with respect to the completion of the predicate situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) ability: the agent of the verb has the mental or physical ability to complete the action of the main verb.
(2) ability, mental: English: 'Melissa can speak Dutch'.
questionGroup.words: can

questionGroup.question: (3) ability, physical: English: 'Hortense can swim the English Channel'.
questionGroup.words: can

questionGroup.question: (4) attempt: the agent attempts to complete the action specified by the predicate. Note: this has a sense of incompleteness, and I have seen authors call this "Incomplete" and gloss the examples with 'try'.
questionGroup.words: try to, attempt to

questionGroup.question: (5) desire: the agent of the verb desires or wants to complete the action of the verb.
questionGroup.words: want to, would like to

questionGroup.question: (6) obligation: the agent is obliged to perform the action of the verb.
(7) obligation, strong: it is absolutely incumbent upon the agent to complete the action of the main verb: 'I have to mail this letter today'.
questionGroup.words: have to, must

questionGroup.question: (8) obligation, weak: it is recommended that the agent complete the action of the main verb: 'Harry ought to get a haircut before meeting Sue's mother'.
questionGroup.words: ought to, should

questionGroup.question: (9) permission: the agent is allowed to complete the action of the main verb: 'The students may check books out for two weeks'.
questionGroup.words: may

questionGroup.question: (10) root possibility: it is possible for the agent to carry out the action of the main verb; i.e. s/he is able and external conditions allow it: 'You can get that kind of paper at Ulbrich's'.
questionGroup.words: can

questionGroup.question: (11) intention: the agent intends to carry out the action of the main verb: 'Sam's gonna take Sanskrit next semester'.
questionGroup.words: gonna, going to, intend to

questionGroup.question: (12) andative: agent moves away from the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be going to do something'. Of course such forms are often related to the verb 'to go' and also may have uses of intention and future.
questionGroup.words: go to

questionGroup.question: (13) venitive: the agent moves toward the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be coming to do something'. This may be related to the verb 'to come' and may have future uses as well.
questionGroup.words: come to

item.name: Can
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that someone can do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that someone is able to do something?
questionGroup.words: can, know how to, be able to, have the ability to, capable
questionGroup.sentences: John <can> drive a car.; John <knows how> to drive a car.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the ability of someone to do something?
questionGroup.words: ability, capability, prowess

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that someone is not able to do something?
questionGroup.words: inability, unable, incapable

item.name: Can't
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being incapable of doing something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words describe a person's inability to do a job?
questionGroup.words: can't do something, not be able to do something, cannot, be incapable of, not be capable of, be unable to do something, someone's inability to do something, incompetent, unqualified, unfitted, untrained, not be equipped, be ill-equipped, powerless

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a person's inability to do a job?
questionGroup.words: incapacity, incompetence, inability, deficiency, lack of training

item.name: Necessary
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something must happen.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is necessary?
questionGroup.words: must, need to, have to, have got to

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that is necessary?
questionGroup.words: necessary, compulsory, essential, imperative, indispensable, inevitable, mandatory, obligatory, required, unavoidable, urgent, vital

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to something that is necessary?
questionGroup.words: necessity, need, obligation, prerequisite, requirement

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something that is not necessary?
questionGroup.words: unnecessary, extraneous, incidental, inessential, needless, nonessential, uncalled-for, unessential, unnecessary, unneeded

item.name: Moods
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate moods.

item.name: Imperative
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate imperatives. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press. Use this domain for words and affixes that a speaker uses to indicate that he is making a command. English has no command word. Some languages change the form of the verb by adding an affix. Some languages have special verbs that are only or normally used as commands. Those verbs could be classified here.

questionGroup.question: (1) imperative: the verb form used for direct commands in the 2nd person. If there are also 1st and 3rd person forms, the meaning can still be that of imperative, with the 1st and 3rd persons being interpreted as 'Let us, let him...', etc.
(2) optative: the proposition represents the speaker's will. Translated into English as 'May you prosper', 'May we all meet again.' with counterfactual: 'If only he had...', etc.
(3) hortative: the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
(4) prohibitive: the mood for expressing negative commands. The English is 'Don't'.
(5) admonitive: the command constitutes a warning: 'you had better not...'.
(6) Meanings co-occurring with imperative:
(7) polite: a mild or polite form of command.
(8) delayed: the action of the command is to be carried out in the future rather than immediately.
(9) immediate: the action of the command is to be carried out immediately.
(10) strong: (self-explanatory).
(11) What words indicate that the sentence is a command?
questionGroup.words: (none in English)

questionGroup.question: (12) What affixes indicate that the sentence is a command?
questionGroup.words: (none in English), (in many Bantu languages) -e 'a verbal suffix indicating that the sentence is a command'

questionGroup.question: (13) What words are only used in the imperative?
questionGroup.words: whoa (stop)

item.name: Hortative
item.descr: Use this domain for ways of saying that someone should do something. If I say someone should do something, I think it is good that he does it.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
questionGroup.words: urge, request, let, why don't, please
questionGroup.sentences: I <urge> you to help.; I <request> that you help.; <Let> us all do our part.; <Why don't> you do something to help?; <Please> do something to help.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something should be done?
questionGroup.words: should, ought to, be responsible for, be duty bound
questionGroup.sentences: We <should> do something to help.; We <ought to> do something to help.; <Should>n't we do something to help?; This building <should> be torn down.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something should not be done?
questionGroup.words: should not, ought not to, caution
questionGroup.sentences: We <should not> do anything to hinder them.; We <ought not to> do anything that might harm them.; I <caution> you not to interfere.

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to something a person should do?
questionGroup.words: duty, responsibility, obligation, onus, requirement

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe the person who should do something?
questionGroup.words: responsible

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe someone who does what he should?
questionGroup.words: dutiful, responsible

item.name: Interrogative
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he is asking a question. English has no question word, but other languages such as Japanese do.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that the sentence is a question?
questionGroup.words: (Japanese) ka? 'a particle coming at the end of a sentence to indicate that it is a question'

questionGroup.question: (2) English has an interjection that is added to a statement that has the effect of questioning something about it.
questionGroup.sentences: So, you are going, <hmm?>

item.name: Epistemic moods
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate epistemic moods. Epistemic moods have the whole proposition in their scope and indicate the degree of commitment of the speaker to the truth or future truth of the proposition. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) possibility: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is possibly true. Some markers with this meaning also indicate future time: 'He may arrive late because of the weather; It may snow again tomorrow; She could have already taken it'.
questionGroup.words: may, could

questionGroup.question: (2) probability: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is probably true. Some marker with this meaning also indicate future time. This is sometimes called the "Dubitative" in grammars: 'Paula should be home by now'.
questionGroup.words: should

questionGroup.question: (3) inferred certainty: the speaker infers from evidence that the proposition is true: 'They must have killed a bear here (I can see blood on the snow)'.
questionGroup.words: must have

questionGroup.question: (4) certainty: the speaker is emphasizing that the proposition is true.
questionGroup.words: certainly

questionGroup.question: (5) uncertainty: the speaker is emphasizing that s/he doesn't know that the proposition is true.
questionGroup.words: might

questionGroup.question: (6) indicative: main clause mood that also appears in questions. Contrasts with subjunctive, conditional, and imperative.
questionGroup.words: [none in English]

item.name: Certainly, definitely
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is certainly true or is certain to happen.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is certainly true?
questionGroup.words: certainly, absolutely, definitely, there is no doubt, undoubtedly, without a doubt, without doubt, without a shadow of a doubt, unquestionably, be beyond dispute, there's no denying, there are no two ways about it, there is no question

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something will certainly happen?
questionGroup.words: certainly, definitely, be bound to, be sure to, be certain to, be assured of, be only a matter of time, be just a matter of time, cut and dried, you can bet your life, you can bet your bottom dollar, be a certainty, be a foregone conclusion, for sure

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something will certainly succeed?
questionGroup.words: can't go wrong, be a dead cert, it's in the bag, it's a safe bet, it's a sure bet, foolproof

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to doing something in order to be certain that something will happen?
questionGroup.words: make sure, make certain, insure, ensure, see that, see to it

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something is certain to happen and nothing can be done to stop it?
questionGroup.words: inevitable, whether you like it or not, willy-nilly, be fated to, be destined to, predestined, be meant to be, pre-ordained, doomed, the inevitable

questionGroup.question: (6) What words describe something that is certain?
questionGroup.words: certain, definite, conclusive

questionGroup.question: (7) What words indicate that something is certainly not true?
questionGroup.words: absolute, assurance, assured, can, certain, certainly, certitude, clear, decided, decisive, definite, doubtless, established, fixed, guaranteed, incalculable, incontestable, incontrovertible, indisputable, indubitable, ineluctable, inevitable, infallible, inescapable, inevitable, irrefragable, irrefutable, positive, really, set, settled, single-minded, sure, sureness, trustworthy, unarguable, unavoidable, undeniable, unequivocal, unmistakable, unquestionable

item.name: Sure
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to being sure that something is true.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that someone is certain about something?
questionGroup.words: be sure, be certain, be positive, know, know very well, swear, I could have sworn, have no doubt, confident, convinced, satisfied (that), I bet, I'd put money on it, say what you like

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to making someone sure about something?
questionGroup.words: convince

item.name: Probably
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is probable or likely to occur.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something will probably happen?
questionGroup.words: probably, likely, probable, be a strong possibility, it looks as if, it looks like, chances are, may well, be in the cards, as likely as not, I wouldn't be surprised if, I dare say, I should think, I guess

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is probably true?
questionGroup.words: probably, likely, probable, it looks as if, it's a fair bet, may well, may easily, as likely as not, I should think

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is very probably true
questionGroup.words: very probably, very likely, there is a strong likelihood, there is a strong probability, almost certain, be more than likely, in all probability, ten to one

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something good will probably happen?
questionGroup.words: ought to be, should be, promise to be, looks promising

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something bad will probably happen?
questionGroup.words: be heading for, be in for, threaten, threat

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that someone or something will probably be successful?
questionGroup.words: have a good chance, stand a good chance, be set to do something, be on course

questionGroup.question: (7) What words indicate that someone will probably do something bad?
questionGroup.words: be quite capable of, I wouldn't put it past him

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate how probable it is that something will happen?
questionGroup.words: likelihood, probability, prospect, chances, odds

questionGroup.question: (9) What words indicate that something is possible but not very probable?
questionGroup.words: unlikely, improbable, doubtful, remote

questionGroup.question: (10) What words indicate that someone or something will probably not be successful?
questionGroup.words: little chance, little hope, little prospect, have little chance, stand little chance, outside chance

item.name: Possible
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is possible. Maybe implies that the speaker doesn't know something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is possible?
questionGroup.words: possible, possibly, could, might, may, able, maybe, perhaps, sort of, I guess so
questionGroup.sentences: <It is possible that> he will come.; <It is possible for> him to come.; He <could> come.; He <might> come.; He <may> come.; He <is able to> come.; <Maybe> he will come.

item.name: Uncertain
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that no one is certain that something is true, or when it is impossible to be certain that something is true.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is uncertain?
questionGroup.words: uncertain, not be certain, not be clear, it's up in the air, there is uncertainty

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is uncertain, but it is likely that something bad will happen?
questionGroup.words: uncertain, doubtful, be in doubt, there is doubt about, it's touch and go, hang in the balance, iffy

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that two things are equally possible?
questionGroup.words: could go either way, borderline, there's a fifty-fifty chance, it's a toss-up

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something is uncertain because people have many different opinions about it?
questionGroup.words: debatable, questionable, open to question, open to debate, moot point

item.name: Unsure
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to not feeling sure about something or someone.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to not being sure about something?
questionGroup.words: not be sure, not be certain, be unsure, be uncertain, not know, doubt, wonder, can't be sure, not be confident, be indefinite about, ambivalent

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to not being sure whether you should do something?
questionGroup.words: have doubts, have reservations, have misgivings, have mixed feelings, have qualms, hesitant

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to making someone unsure about something?
questionGroup.words: make someone unsure, make someone uncertain, cause doubt, cause uncertainty, it makes you wonder, raise doubts

item.name: Think so
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that you think something is true, but you are not completely sure about it.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that you think something is true, but you are not completely sure about it?
questionGroup.words: think, think it is possible, believe, bet, would gamble, would wager, guess, reckon, speculate, surmise, suspect, get the impression, have the impression, be under the impression, get the idea, feel, have the feeling, get the feeling

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that you think something is true, but you have no proof of it?
questionGroup.words: assume, assumption, presume, suppose, imagine, take it for granted, presumably, I take it
questionGroup.sentences: <I suppose> X is true.; <It is my conjecture that> X is true.; <I would wager that> X is true.; <If my suspicions are true,> X is true.; X <may> be true.; <It's possible> X is true.

questionGroup.question: (3) What do you say when you think something is true, but you are not sure?
questionGroup.words: I think so, I guess so, as far as I know, to the best of my knowledge, as far as I'm aware
questionGroup.sentences: "Is X true?" "<I think so>."; X is true, <as far as I know>.; <To the best of my knowledge>, X is true.; <As far as I'm aware>, X is true.

item.name: Maybe
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks it is possible that something may happen or be true, but he isn't certain.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that maybe something may happen or is true?
questionGroup.words: maybe, perhaps, may, might, it is possible, possibly, could, who knows?, there's a chance, you never know, conceivably
questionGroup.sentences: <It is possible that> he will come.; He <could> come.; He <might> come.; He <may> come.; <Maybe> he will come.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that the speaker is guessing about a number or amount, but is not certain?
questionGroup.words: maybe, perhaps, possibly

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that the speaker is not certain about a suggestion, plan, or idea?
questionGroup.words: maybe, perhaps

item.name: Seem
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something seems to be a certain way--you see (or hear) something and think something about it, but you are not sure that what you think is true.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something seems to be a certain way, but you are unsure?
questionGroup.words: seem, appear, look, sound, give the impression, have a (certain) look, come across as, show signs of, strike someone as, have all the hallmarks of, an air of, give the impression
questionGroup.sentences: X <seems to> be true.; X <appears to> be true.; <It sounds to me like> X is true.; <It appears that> X is true.; <To all appearances> X is true.; <All indications are that> X is true.; <It looks suspiciously like> X is true.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that someone seems to be doing something, or something seems to be happening?
questionGroup.words: seem, appear

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something seems to be happening, or something seems to be true?
questionGroup.words: it seems, it appears, it looks as if, apparently, to all appearances, by all appearances, seemingly, on the face of it, on the surface, outwardly

questionGroup.question: (4) What words describe something, such as a feeling or quality, that someone or something seems to have?
questionGroup.words: apparent, seeming, superficial

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that, because something seems to be a certain way, you think something is true?
questionGroup.words: judging by, judging from, going by, from, from the way, you'd think, anyone would think

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that someone or something is not what it seems to be?
questionGroup.words: there's more to someone/something than meets the eye, deceptive, deceptively, not be what you/it seem

questionGroup.question: (7) What words refer to what you think or feel because of what someone or something seems?
questionGroup.words: impression, feeling

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to the way something seems to appear?
questionGroup.words: appearance, semblance of

item.name: Just, almost not
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that although something is true, it almost is not true.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that although something is true, it almost is not true?
questionGroup.words: just, almost didn't, nearly didn't, only just, narrowly, barely

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something bad almost happened, but it did not?
questionGroup.words: narrowly missed, close shave

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that you did something, but almost didn't do it?
questionGroup.words: just, only just, barely, be a near thing, be a close thing, by the skin of your teeth

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that you can do something, but it is difficult?
questionGroup.words: can hardly, can barely, can scarcely

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something is a particular amount, but not much more?
questionGroup.words: just, only just, barely

item.name: Don't think so, doubt it
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that you think something is unlikely to be true or to happen.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that you think it is very unlikely that something is true or will happen?
questionGroup.words: don't think, doubt, be doubtful, be dubious, I'd be surprised if, I think not, I wouldn't have thought so

item.name: Impossible
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is impossible.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something cannot be done?
questionGroup.words: impossible, not possible, impracticable, there's no way, out of the question, hopeless, impractical
questionGroup.sentences: <It is impossible for> a person to fly.; <It is not possible for> a person to fly.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that your situation makes it impossible for you to do something?
questionGroup.words: impossible, not have a hope, not stand a chance, can't possibly, that's out, with the best will in the world, do the impossible

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something cannot happen?
questionGroup.words: impossible, not possible, can't, couldn't, impossibility, inconceivable, unthinkable, by any/no stretch of the imagination, there's no way

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that something is impossible to get?
questionGroup.words: unattainable, out of reach

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that one thing makes something else impossible?
questionGroup.words: make something impossible, rule out, preclude

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that something is impossible?
questionGroup.words: absurd, impenetrable, impervious, inaccessible, inoperable, insurmountable, no chance, no earthly way, outlandish, preposterous, ridiculous, unable, unachievable, unapproachable, undoable, unfeasible, unimaginable, unworkable

item.name: Evidentials
