item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate evidentials. An evidential is when the speaker indicates the source of the information on which an assertion about a situation is based. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) direct evidence: the speaker claims to have witnessed the situation, but does not specify the type of sensory evidence.
questionGroup.words: I was there and...

questionGroup.question: (2) visual evidence: the speaker claims to have seen the situation described.
questionGroup.words: with my own eyes I saw...

questionGroup.question: (3) auditory evidence: the speaker claims to have heard the situation described.
questionGroup.words: with my own ears I heard...

questionGroup.question: (4) sensory evidence: the speaker claims to have physically sensed the situation described. This can be in opposition to one or both of the above senses (i.e. any other sense), or it can indicate sensory evidence that is not further specified (i.e. any sensory evidence).
(5) indirect evidence: the speaker claims not to have witnessed the situation, but does not specify further whether the evidence is reported or simply inferred.
questionGroup.words: I wasn't there but...

questionGroup.question: (6) reported evidence: the speaker claims to know of the situation described via verbal means, but does not specify whether it is second-hand, hearsay, or via folklore.
questionGroup.words: I heard that...

questionGroup.question: (7) second-hand evidence: the speaker claims to have heard of the situation described from someone who was a direct witness.
(8) evidence from hearsay: the speaker claims to have heard about the situation described, but not from a direct witness.
questionGroup.words: it is rumored that...

questionGroup.question: (9) evidence from folklore: the speaker claims that the situation described is part of established oral history (e.g., mythology).
questionGroup.words: according to our ancestors...

questionGroup.question: (10) inferred evidence: the speaker infers the event/action, but does not specify whether the inference is based on observable results or on a purely mental process.
(11) inference from results: the speaker infers the situation described from the evidence at hand (i.e. from the observable results of the causing event/action.)
questionGroup.words: from the results I would say...

questionGroup.question: (12) inference from reasoning: the speaker infers the situation described on the basis of intuition, logic, a dream, previous experience, or some other mental construct.
questionGroup.words: I figure that..., I conclude that...

item.name: Evaluator
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating who is evaluating the proposition.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate who is evaluating the proposition?
questionGroup.words: to, in my opinion
questionGroup.sentences: This job is very important <to> John.; The proposal looks good <in> my <opinion>.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that you heard what you are saying from someone else?
questionGroup.words: according to, rumor has it, they say, people say, there is talk of, apparently, supposedly, be rumored to be
questionGroup.sentences: <According to> John his business is doing very well.

item.name: Yes
item.descr: Use this domain for words that affirm or agree with the truth of something, or that answer a yes/no question in the affirmative.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to affirm the truth of something?
questionGroup.words: yes, yeah, yea, indeed, true, that's true, it is true, verily, agreed, certainly, of course, that's right, I guess so, that is so, a-huh, nod your head, affirmative, positive

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to refer to the action of affirming the truth of something?
questionGroup.words: affirm, affirmation, confirm, concur, agree, agreement

item.name: No, not
item.descr: Use this domain for words that negate or deny the truth of something, or that answer a yes/no question in the negative.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to negate the truth of something?
questionGroup.words: no, none, not, nay, uh-uh, no one, nothing, never, nowhere, no indeed, by no means, certainly not, most certainly not, absolutely not, shake your head, negative

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to refer to the process of denying the truth of something?
questionGroup.words: deny, denial, negate, negation, disavow, disavowal, contradict, contradiction, repudiate, repudiation

questionGroup.question: (3) What are the noun forms of these words?

item.name: Markers expecting an affirmative answer
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that an affirmative answer is expected to a question.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that an affirmative answer is expected to a question?
questionGroup.words: n't
questionGroup.sentences: You are going, <aren't you>? (The expected answer in English is, 'Yes, I am going'.); He's going, <isn't he>? (Yes, he is.); Are<n't> you going? (Yes, I am.); Did<n't> he go? (Yes, he did).

item.name: Markers expecting a negative answer
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that a negative answer is expected to a question.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to indicate that a negative answer is expected to a question?
questionGroup.words: n't...are you
questionGroup.sentences: You are<n't> going, <are you>? (The expected answer in English is, 'No, I'm not going.'); He is<n't> going, <is he>? (No, he's not going.); You're <not> going? (No, I'm not going.); He is<n't> going? (No, he's not going.)

item.name: Subordinating particles
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate a subordinate clause. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) subordinating: Often there are special verb forms or morphemes associated with the verb that occur obligatorily in subordinate clauses of certain types. The extent to which such morphemes can be said to have "meaning" varies, since they often co-occur with other markers of subordination. Their function is primarily to signal the type of subordinate clause.

(2) Complement clauses: A main verb may take as its direct object a clause. These are often referred to as "Noun clauses" or "Noun complements". The verb form of the subordinate clause is usually determined by the semantics of the main verb, so in this case, our meaning labels will just refer to the context. If a verb form occurs in the complements to words of thinking and believing, the meaning label will be complement to words of thinking and believing.
(3) complement to words of thinking
(4) complement to words of believing
(5) complement to words of saying
(6) complement to words of ordering (in English we use an infinitive with these words)
(7) complement to words of wanting (again in English these are done with infinitives)
(8) complement to words of emotion (surprise, regret, happiness, sadness, etc.; the complement proposition is presupposed to be true)
(9) complement to words of obligation
(10) complement to words of admonition
(11) subsequent: following a reference time in the past.
(12) subordinator: marker indicates that the verb is in a subordinate clause.

item.name: Adverbial clauses
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate adverbial clauses. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) There are a variety of adverbial clauses (other than conditional clauses) that sometimes require a special verb form. The meaning labels for these uses are coded according to the type of clause (purpose, concessive, etc.), whether any particular temporal deixis is part of the meaning, and under "co-occurrence restrictions," whether a particular conjunction is present. The types of clauses we might run into are:
(2) purpose: the clause states the purpose for which the main clause action is taking place. Often called a "final" clause: 'He was saving his money so that his son could go to college'.
questionGroup.words: so that

questionGroup.question: (3) concessive: translated in English as 'although, even though, despite the fact that': 'She was saving her money, even though she was a wealthy woman'.
questionGroup.words: although, even though, despite the fact that

item.name: Case
item.descr: Each verb has a set of semantic case relations. For instance in the sentence 'I gave flowers to my wife' the verb give has three case relations. 'I' is the Agent, 'flowers' is the Patient, and 'my wife is the 'Recipient'. In this sentence the only word that marks a case relation is 'to'. English often marks case relations by their position in the sentence. Some languages mark case relations by affixes, prepositions, postpositions, and sometimes special verbs. To completely describe a language, each verb must be investigated, all its case relations must be identified, and all the ways in which these relations are marked must be described. Since verbs are often unique and unpredictable in their case relations, this information should go into the dictionary. This section should be used to classify the words and affixes that are used to mark case relations. This domain should be used for technical terms that refer to case.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to refer to case?
questionGroup.words: case, declension

item.name: Primary cases
item.descr: Use this section for primary cases.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the subject of a sentence?
questionGroup.words: (no words in English)

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate the object of a sentence?
questionGroup.words: (no words in English)

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate the indirect object of a sentence?
questionGroup.words: to

item.name: Beneficiary of an event
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark the beneficiary of an event. The sentence "John built a house for his father" is ambiguous. If the house was for his father to live in, then "for" would mark the 'Beneficiary of a patient', meaning that the house was for the father. If, on the other hand, the father was intending to build the house to sell, but couldn't due to an injury, then "for" would mark the 'Beneficiary of an event', meaning the father benefited from the building of the house.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words mark the beneficiary of an event?
questionGroup.words: for, for (someone's) sake, for the sake of, for (someone's) benefit, for the benefit of
questionGroup.sentences: John held our coats <for> us.; John manages the business <for> us.; John invited some older couples to join them <for> his parent's <sake>.; <For the sake of> his parents John invited some older couples to join them.; <For the benefit of> the children we included a trip to the zoo.; Because you are sick, Mary has offered to cook <for> you.

item.name: Instrument
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark an instrument used to do something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words mark the instrument used to do something?
questionGroup.words: with, using
questionGroup.sentences: John hit the dog <with> a stick.; John caught the rat <using> a trap he built.

item.name: Means
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the means by which something is done.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the means by which something is done?
questionGroup.words: by, by means of
questionGroup.sentences: John travels to work <by> bus.; He intends to get there <by means of> his wits.

item.name: Way, manner
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the way or manner in which something is done.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the way you do something or the way something is done?
questionGroup.words: way, manner, style, fashion, how, thus, mode

questionGroup.question: (2) What question words ask for the manner in which something is done?
questionGroup.words: how
questionGroup.sentences: <How> does he talk? (quietly, slowly)

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is done in a particular way?
questionGroup.words: in a ... way/manner/fashion, with, like, along ... lines, as if, as though, with an air of

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate the way in which something happened?
questionGroup.words: in
questionGroup.sentences: John recovered the use of his leg <in> stages.

item.name: Attendant circumstances
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the attendant circumstances in which something happened.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate attendant circumstances?
questionGroup.words: in
questionGroup.sentences: The president resigned <in> disgrace.

item.name: Spatial location of an event
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the spatial location of an event.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the location of an event?
questionGroup.words: at
questionGroup.sentences: John ate lunch <at> a restaurant.

item.name: Source (of movement)
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark the Source (original location) of something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the Source of movement?
questionGroup.words: source, from
questionGroup.sentences: The <source> of our water is a deep well.; Our drinking water is <from> a deep well.; John brought the wood <from> the forest.

item.name: Path (of movement)
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the Path of movement.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the Path of movement?
questionGroup.words: via, course, route
questionGroup.sentences: We traveled <via> the highway most of the way.; What <route> will you follow?

item.name: Goal (of movement)
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the Goal of movement.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the Goal of movement?
questionGroup.words: to, destination
questionGroup.sentences: We traveled <to> New York.; Our <destination> is New York.; John moved the wood <to> the back of the house.; John sent David <to> New York.

item.name: Origin (of a person)
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark the place where someone was born or the place where they have been living.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the place where someone was born?
questionGroup.words: from, be from (the tribe, or country)
questionGroup.sentences: John <is from> New York.; I<'m from> California.; <from> the tribe of; <from> America

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to the place where a person is from?
questionGroup.words: home town

item.name: Semantically similar events
item.descr: Use this section for words that join semantically similar events into one sentence. Each sentence is actually reporting two or more situations, which may differ in one or two respects. The words to be included in these domains indicate that two situations are being reported, or mark the differences between the two situations.

item.name: Together
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating when two or more people each do the same thing and do it together, or when they do it separately.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that some people do something together?
questionGroup.words: together
questionGroup.sentences: John and David went to town <together>.; We all went <together>.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that some people do something separately?
questionGroup.words: separately
questionGroup.sentences: John and David went to town <separately>.

item.name: With, be with
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a person who accompanied the subject of a proposition.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate a person who accompanied the person who is the subject of the clause?
questionGroup.words: with, be accompanied by, company, in someone's company, in someone's presence, contact, along with, together with
questionGroup.sentences: John was <with> me at supper last night.; John was there <along with> David.

item.name: With, do with someone
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a person who does something with another person who is the subject of the sentence.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate someone who goes somewhere with another person?
questionGroup.words: with, along
questionGroup.sentences: John went to town <with> David.; We will go <with> you.; We wanted to go to town and John decided to go <along>.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate someone who does something with another person?
questionGroup.words: with, in conjunction with, in partnership with, in collaboration with, side by side with, shoulder to shoulder with
questionGroup.sentences: John was working <with> David in the field.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate someone who does something bad with another person?
questionGroup.words: in league with, in collusion with, in cahoots with, hand in glove with

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to someone who does something with another person?
questionGroup.words: partner, companion, fellow (student), sidekick

item.name: Each other
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that two or more people do something to each other.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that two people do something to each other?
questionGroup.words: each other, one another, each...the other, exchange, trade, reciprocate
questionGroup.sentences: They helped <each other> with their work.; We all helped <one another>.; <Each> accused <the other> of causing the problem.; We <exchanged> glances.; They <traded> insults.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words describe something that people do to each other?
questionGroup.words: mutual, reciprocal, two-way
questionGroup.sentences: The feeling is <mutual>.; The two countries signed a <reciprocal> trade agreement.; Effective communication is <two-way>.

item.name: In groups
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that the subjects of a clause do something in groups.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is done in groups?
questionGroup.words: in, by
questionGroup.sentences: The participants entered two <by> two.; The students lined up class <by> class.; We lined up the shoes <in> pairs.; The guests were seated <in> groups of six.

item.name: Patient-related cases
item.descr: Use this section for cases that bear a relationship to the 'Patient' of a proposition.

item.name: Beneficiary (of a patient)
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark the beneficiary of the Patient of an activity. The Patient is often expressed as the object of a sentence. In the sentence "John built a house for his parents," the house is the Patient. It is the house that benefits the parents, not the building of the house.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words mark the beneficiary of a Patient?
questionGroup.words: for
questionGroup.sentences: John built a house <for> his parents.

questionGroup.question: (2) In English the Beneficiary can be the object, but many languages do not allow this.
questionGroup.sentences: John bought Mary some medicine.

item.name: Recipient (of a patient)
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark the recipient of the Patient of an activity. The Patient is usually expressed as the object of a sentence.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words mark the recipient of a patient?
questionGroup.words: to
questionGroup.sentences: John gave a ring <to> Mary.

questionGroup.question: (2) In English the Recipient can be the object, but many languages do not allow this.
questionGroup.sentences: John gave Mary a ring.

item.name: With (a patient)
item.descr: Use this domain for words that mark a second Patient that accompanies the primary Patient of an activity. In this type of sentence there are actually two Patients, but one of them has more prominence than the other. The primary patient is usually expressed as the object of the sentence. The second Patient may be marked by an oblique case or preposition/postposition. For instance it may be conceived as accompanying the first Patient.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words mark something that is used with another thing?
questionGroup.words: with, together with, combined with, in combination, in conjunction with, alongside, along with
questionGroup.sentences: John drank coffee <with> milk.; John sent flowers to Mary <along with> a birthday card.; He paid back my money <with> interest.

item.name: Connected with, related
item.descr: Use the domains in this section for words that indicate a logical relation between two or more words or sentences. Use this domain for words that indicate an unspecified logical relation between people, things, or situations.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that two things or situations are connected somehow?
questionGroup.words: be connected (with), be related (to), be linked (with), be associated (with), there is a link between, there is a connection between, be bound up with, go hand in hand, relate, relation, be a relationship between, relationship, have something to do with, be something to do with, be intertwined, tied, pertain, be relative to
questionGroup.sentences: What is the <relation> between the two?; How are they <related>?; The <relationship> is complex.; What does this <have to do with> that?; The two <are related> somehow, but I don't know in what way.; The distance an arrow flies <is related to> the angle at which you shoot.; My science class and the smell of sulfur will forever <be associated> in my mind.; I don't see the <connection>.; There must be some sort of <correlation> between them.; I'm sure there is <a link between> the two, but I haven't found it yet.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that two people are connected somehow?
questionGroup.words: be connected with, have links, have connections with, be linked with

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that two things are connected because they are similar in some way?
questionGroup.words: related, associated, allied

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that several things are connected somehow?
questionGroup.words: interconnected, interrelated

questionGroup.question: (5) What words refer to showing that there is a connection between two things?
questionGroup.words: connect, link, associate, make a connection, establish a link, establish a connection, relate, correlate

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to something that connects two things?
questionGroup.words: connection, relationship, link (between), point of contact, association, tie, relation, correlation, interplay

questionGroup.question: (7) What words indicate that there is no connection between two things?
questionGroup.words: no connection, unrelated, unconnected

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that something someone says has no connection with the topic being discussed?
questionGroup.words: irrelevant, be beside the point, have nothing to do with, be nothing to do with, be neither here nor there, doesn't come into it, be a red herring

item.name: Coordinate relations
item.descr: Use this section for words indicating coordinate relations. Do not put any words in this domain. It is only for organizational purposes.

item.name: And, also
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that you are adding another thought to a previous thought. Words in this domain may indicate a variety of relationships between words, phrases, clauses, or sentences. For instance the words may join two clauses that are the same except that the subjects are different, or the objects are different, or the verbs are different.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that you are adding another thought to a previous one?
questionGroup.words: and, also, too, besides, besides this, as well, so do I/so has she/so are they, in addition, not to mention, likewise, both...and, and also, again, further, in addition to, not only...but also, some...others, first...then, let me add
questionGroup.sentences: Mary washed <and> ironed the dress.; Mary washed the dress <and also> ironed it.; Mary <and> Laura washed the dress.; Mary washed the dress <and> Laura washed it <too>.; Laura <also> washed the dress.; Mary washed the dress <and> the shirt.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that you are adding something new to what you just said?
questionGroup.words: and, also, furthermore, moreover, what's more, besides, by the way, incidentally

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that you could add more things to the end of a list?
questionGroup.words: and so on, and so on and so forth, et cetera, etc, and whatever, or whatever, and the like, and suchlike

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that you are adding another in a list of thoughts?
questionGroup.words: first, second, third, firstly, secondly, thirdly, in the first/second/third place, first of all, to begin with, to start with, finally, lastly, to conclude, in conclusion, last but not least

item.name: Or, either
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating an alternative relation between two things or propositions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate alternative relation?
questionGroup.words: or, either...or, alternatively, nor, otherwise, alternative, optional
questionGroup.sentences: You have two <alternatives>, keep quiet <or> leave.

item.name: Association
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating an association between two things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate association?
questionGroup.words: with, among, together with, between...and, be one with, in common, in union with, union

item.name: Combinative relation
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a combinative relation between two things.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate combinative relation?
questionGroup.words: with, together with, combined with, mixed with
questionGroup.sentences: We eat vegetables <with> our rice.; We used mud <mixed with> a little cement to plaster the wall.

item.name: But
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a contrast between two thoughts that are different in some way.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that someone wants to do something, but is not able to do it?
questionGroup.words: but, however
questionGroup.sentences: I want to do something, <but> can't do it.; I tried to do something, <but> couldn't do it.; I promised to do something, <but> didn't do it.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something seems to be true, but is not true?
questionGroup.words: but, however
questionGroup.sentences: Something seems to be true, <but> isn't true.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is true in spite of facts or problems that make it seem unlikely?
questionGroup.words: but, yet, still, nevertheless, even so, anyway, all the same, in spite of this, despite this, for all that, though, although
questionGroup.sentences: This is true, <but> that is also true.; This is true, <although> that is also true.

questionGroup.question: (4) What words indicate that an opinion is different than the opinion you have just given?
questionGroup.words: but, however, on the other hand, at the same time, having said that, mind you
questionGroup.sentences: I think this is true, <but> I also think that is true.

questionGroup.question: (5) What words indicate that something is true of one person or thing, but not true of another?
questionGroup.words: but, however, whereas, while, by contrast, conversely
questionGroup.sentences: Something is true of this person, <but> not true of that person.

questionGroup.question: (6) What words indicate that although one person or thing is similar to another, there is a difference between them?
questionGroup.words: but, only, except, except for the fact that
questionGroup.sentences: I am like you, <but> we are different in this way.

questionGroup.question: (7) What words indicate that something could happen, but something else prevented it from happening?
questionGroup.words: but, only, except
questionGroup.sentences: I could have done this, <but> you stopped me from doing it.

questionGroup.question: (8) What words indicate that the opposite of something is true?
questionGroup.words: on the contrary, contrary to, in contrast, as opposed to

item.name: Except
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is an exception to a group, rule or pattern--something is true of all the things (or people) in a group, but it is not true of one thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is not included in a group, rule, or pattern?
questionGroup.words: except, except for, apart from, aside from, bar, excepting, but for, but, with the exception of, but not
questionGroup.sentences: All of my family was there <except> me.; Everyone went <except> John.; John spent everything <except for> ten dollars.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to something that is not included in a group?
questionGroup.words: exception

item.name: Instead
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is true of one thing (or person) instead of another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is true of one thing instead of another thing?
questionGroup.words: instead, rather than, in place of, in preference to, in favor of, in lieu
questionGroup.sentences: I couldn't do that, so I did this <instead>.; I did this <instead of> that.; I want this <rather than> that.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is true of one person instead of another person?
questionGroup.words: instead, in someone's place, for, on someone's behalf
questionGroup.sentences: I couldn't do this, so he did it <instead>.; I went <instead of> him.

item.name: Dissociation
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating a dissociation relation between two things or propositions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate dissociation?
questionGroup.words: without, not with, no relationship to, apart from, independent of, from, free from, separated from

item.name: Distribution
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that an event is distributed throughout a group, area, or time span.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate distribution?
questionGroup.words: throughout, through, from...to, after, each, apiece
questionGroup.sentences: The disease spread <throughout> the population.; He went <from> town <to> town.; He applied for admission year <after> year.; He placed them in piles of ten <each>.; They received ten dollars <apiece>.

item.name: Equivalence
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating equivalence between two things or propositions.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate equivalence?
questionGroup.words: that is, that means, i.e.

item.name: Dependency relations
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is dependent on another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words express the fact that something is logically dependent on another?
questionGroup.words: to depend on, that depends, depend upon, dependency, dependent, hang on, tied to, lean on, stand on, supportive relationship
questionGroup.sentences: It all <depends>.; This <is dependent on> that.; It all <hangs on> whether we finish on time.; Prosperity <is tied to> government regulations.

item.name: Derivation
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something derives from another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words express the fact that something is derived from another?
questionGroup.words: derive, derived from, derivation, rooted in the past
questionGroup.sentences: The word 'goner' <is derived from> the root 'go'.

item.name: Limitation of topic
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating the topic that is being talked about.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the specific area or topic that is being talked about?
questionGroup.words: specify, specified, specification, specifically in regard to, with regard to, in the case of, concerning, in the area of, in, with, between...and, as touching, particular, particularly, more especially
questionGroup.sentences: He is rich <in> land.; He is a leader, <specifically in regard to> strategy.; <In the case of> a disagreement we will seek arbitration.; What does that have to do <with> me?; There might be a problem <between> our decision <and> his.

item.name: In general
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is generally true, but not true in every case.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something is generally true?
questionGroup.words: in general, generally, mostly, on the whole, in most cases

item.name: Relations involving correspondences
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating relations involving correspondences--a situation in which one thing is the same or similar in some respect to something else.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that one thing corresponds to another?
questionGroup.words: correspond to, correspondence, in accordance with, in relation to, according to, in line with, in proportion to, to apply to, to regard as applicable to, in keeping with
questionGroup.sentences: We will submit the file <in accordance with> the law.; He will be judged <in accordance with> his crime.; His grade <corresponds to> his performance.; You aren't acting <in line with> your beliefs.; You will benefit <in proportion to> your contribution.; What I have said <applies to> myself as well.

item.name: Basis
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is the basis for another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that one thing is the basis for another?
questionGroup.words: basis, foundation, on the basis of, in view of, by virtue of, be the basis of, form the basis of, on what basis? What do you base your...?
questionGroup.sentences: His promise <is the basis of> my hope.; His work <formed the basis of> all subsequent developments.; He was convicted <on the basis of> circumstantial evidence.; <In view of> the current situation we should think about moving.; <By virtue of> the authority conferred on me I pronounce you man and wife.

item.name: Cause
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that someone or something is the cause for an event or state, that one event is the cause for another event or state, or that an event or state is reasonable (having sufficient cause). For instance in the sentence, "John caused David to fall," "John caused" is an enabling proposition that brings about the primary proposition "David fell."

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that someone caused something to happen?
questionGroup.words: made, cause
questionGroup.sentences: His father <made> John hoe the field.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is the cause or reason for an event or state?
questionGroup.words: cause, reason, source, because, because of, for this reason, for the above reasons, for the following reasons, first cause, origin, breed (v), gives birth to, due to, owing to, thus
questionGroup.sentences: I did it <because> I wanted to.; I did it <because of> him.; His statement is <the origin of> all the confusion.; The <source> of the problem is a lack of motivation.; Laziness <breeds> hunger.; The storm <caused> a lot of damage.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is reasonable?
questionGroup.words: reasonable
questionGroup.sentences: His request <is reasonable>.

item.name: Reason
item.descr: Use this domain for words that reason why someone does something.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words reason why someone does something?
questionGroup.words: reason, motive, motivation

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a reason that explains why something happened?
questionGroup.words: reason, explanation

item.name: Without cause
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that an event or state has no cause or reason, or is unreasonable (has insufficient cause).

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something has no cause or reason?
questionGroup.words: without cause, unreasonable, without basis, absurd, for no reason, by itself
questionGroup.sentences: He did it <for no reason>.; There is <no basis> for your claim.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that something is contrary to reason?
questionGroup.words: contrary to reason, absurd
questionGroup.sentences: It is <unreasonable> to assume that anything will come of this.; What you are saying is <ridiculous>.

questionGroup.question: (3) What words indicate that something is self-caused?
questionGroup.sentences: The door opened <by itself>.; Goodness <is its own reason>.

item.name: Result
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something is the result of another thing.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the result of something?
questionGroup.words: result, outcome, end, to result in, to lead to, wages, to end up being, have as a consequence, therefore, so then, consequently, as a result, for this reason, with the result that, so that as a result, to cause, which caused, so that, that, accordingly, then, hence, and so, yield, has the effect of

item.name: Without result
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something had no result.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that something had no result?
questionGroup.words: without result, without effect, in vain, to no avail, with no result, have no discernible effect, pointless, useless, worthless, be left with nothing, not yield

item.name: Purpose
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something was done for the purpose of another thing happening.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate the intended purpose of something?
questionGroup.words: for, for the purpose of, for the sake of, with the purpose of, to, in order to, so that, to show that
questionGroup.sentences: Do something <with the purpose of> something happening.; Do something <for the sake of> something happening.; Do something <for the purpose of> causing something to happen.; Do something <in order to> cause something to happen.; Do something <to> cause something to happen.; Do something <in order that> something might happen.; Do something <so that> something might happen.; Do something <to show that> something would happen.; Do something <for> some reason.; This medicine is good <for> malaria.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words indicate that the purpose is so that something will not happen?
questionGroup.words: in order that...not, so that...not, lest
questionGroup.sentences: Do something <lest> something happen.

item.name: Without purpose
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that something had no purpose.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that there is no purpose to an action?
questionGroup.words: without purpose, for no purpose, in vain, purposeless, senseless, chance, indiscriminate, meaningless, pointless, undirected

item.name: Condition
item.descr: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate a clause in a conditional sentence (If this is true, then that is true). The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

questionGroup.question: (1) Conditional sentences: Conditional sentences consist of two clauses, the 'if'-clause or protasis (which is a subordinate clause) and the 'then'-clause or apodosis (which is the main clause). Both of these clauses may take special verb forms. (Interestingly enough, they sometime both take the same special verb forms.)

(2) There are at least three types of conditional sentences. (Labels, explanations, and examples from Li and Thompson 1981): [Li, Charles N., and Sandra A. Thompson. 1981. Mandarin Chinese: A functional reference grammar. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press.]
(3) reality condition: a conditional relation between two propositions referring to the so-called real world: 'If you see my sister, you will know that she is pregnant'.
(4) hypothetical: the situation is unreal or imagined, but one that could be true: 'If we moved, we could have a garden'.
(5) counterfactual: the proposition describes an unreal or imagined situation that could have been true but was not: 'If you had taken algebra, you would know this formula' (but you did not).
(6) The verb forms that occur in these sentences will be coded according to the type of sentence, and according to which clause of the sentence they occur in.
(7) Example: the English 'had' + past participle would be coded as:
(8) meaning label: protasis
(9) meaning label: counterfactual
(10) Since the conjunction 'if' obligatorily occurs in the protasis, there will also be the following:
(11) Co-occurrence restriction: 'if'
(12) This indicates that a morpheme meaning 'if' obligatorily occurs in the protasis. If no such morpheme is necessary, then there will be no co-occurrence restriction.
(13) What words indicate the condition of a conditional sentence?
questionGroup.words: condition, if, if indeed, if at all, whether...or, or else, otherwise, unless
questionGroup.sentences: <If> you do this thing, something bad will happen to you.

item.name: Concession
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that the speaker is conceding a point in a debate.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that the speaker is conceding a point?
questionGroup.words: concession, although, though, even though, and yet, even if, nevertheless

item.name: Discourse markers
item.descr: Use this domain for conjunctions and particles that function on the discourse level, and whose meaning and function is uncertain.

questionGroup.question: (1) What discourse markers are in your language?
questionGroup.words: just, you know, OK, yeah, like

item.name: Markers of transition
item.descr: Use this domain for conjunctions that simply move the discourse forward without any specific relationship indicated between what comes before and what comes after.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to join two clauses or sentences without specifying the relationship between them?
questionGroup.words: and, then, but, now, it happened that, it came to pass that, one day, my next topic is, my next point is, now about

item.name: Markers of emphasis
item.descr: Use this domain for words that indicate that the phrase or sentence is particularly important.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words indicate that a phrase or sentence is important?
questionGroup.words: then, indeed, surely, so, certainly, in fact, actually, how, you know, really, sure, just, you know don't you that, how much more, emphatically, absolutely, without question, no way, of course, obviously, you've got to be kidding, it is just that, the only thing is, one thing that, in reality, only that, as it were, just as you can see, as you know, without a doubt, don't you remember, I am convinced that

item.name: Prompters of attention
item.descr: Use this domain for words that are used to get someone's attention or direct the listener's attention to something. These may use a verb meaning 'look' or 'listen'. Some may be a word specifically referring to attention. Others may be a greeting. Others may be words that refer to non-verbal communication such as clearing your throat.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to get someone's attention?
questionGroup.words: you, you there, hey you, hello, excuse me, attention, attention please, may I have your attention please, pay attention, listen up everybody, now hear this, and now for an important announcement, and now for a word from our sponsor, just a moment, wait a minute, lend me your ears, look here, ahem

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to direct someone's attention to something?
questionGroup.words: behold, look, will you look at that, get a load of this, (point)

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to warn someone of danger?
questionGroup.words: watch out, look out, heads up, hit the dirt, get out of the way, here it comes, oh no, (scream)

questionGroup.question: (4) What non-verbal means are used to get someone's attention
questionGroup.words: clear throat, whistle, raise hand

item.name: Markers of direct address
item.descr: Use this domain for words that the speaker uses to refer to the person he is addressing. These words are usually used when you start talking to someone, but can be used during a speech or conversation to refer to the person you are talking to.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used when you start talking to someone?
questionGroup.words: O, sir, ma'am, ladies and gentlemen, men and brothers, (look) you, (listen) all of you
questionGroup.sentences: <O> king, live forever.; Excuse me, <sir>.; Pardon me, <ma'am>.

item.name: Markers of identificational and explanatory clauses
item.descr: Use this domain for words that begin a clause that identifies a specific case or example of what has just been said, or that explains what has just been said. Specific case: I have just mentioned a general class of things or a general idea and want to give a specific example of what I am talking about. Explanation: I have just said something and I think people might misunderstand, so I want to explain what I mean. Digression: I am talking about a particular topic, but want to say something that does not fit into my topic, so I say something that is about a different topic.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used to identify a specific case?
questionGroup.words: that, namely, namely that, that is, i.e.

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to introduce an example?
questionGroup.words: for example, e.g., as follows, as below, such as, let me give you an example, to illustrate

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to introduce an explanation?
questionGroup.words: what I mean is, that is to say, let me add, allow me to explain, it's like

questionGroup.question: (4) What words are used to introduce a conclusion?
questionGroup.words: which shows that, so we find, so we see

questionGroup.question: (5) What words mark a digression?
questionGroup.words: let me just insert, as an aside, this is off the subject, oh by the way

item.name: Markers of focus
item.descr: Use this domain for words indicating that one of several things is in focus.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words focus especially on one of several things?
questionGroup.words: especially, particularly, particular, most of all

item.name: Hesitation fillers
item.descr: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses when he hesitates or pauses while he is speaking in order to think about what he is saying.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words are used when a speaker hesitates or pauses to think?
questionGroup.words: um, uh, er, hmm, yeah, let's see, hold on a minute, let me see, let me think

item.name: Honorifics
item.descr: Use this domain for words that the speaker uses to show respect or a lack of respect to the person he is addressing. Some languages have elaborate systems of honorifics. Other languages have none. Languages with a stratified social structure often use honorifics. Egalitarian societies generally lack them, but some egalitarian societies may use them. For instance in Nahuatl there are four levels of honorifics. Level 1 is how one addresses intimates, small children, and pets. Level 2 is for strangers and persons treated formally. Level 3 is for respected persons, the dead, and God. Level 4 is for obsequious respect, as for the archbishop in an interview with a priest, and for ritual kin. (Jane H. Hill and Kenneth C. Hill. 1978. Honorific usage in modern Nahuatl: the expression of social distance and respect in the Nahuatl of the Malinche Volcano area, Language 54:123-155.) In Japanese, which has a stratified social structure, a person uses one set of words and affixes when speaking to someone below you in the social hierarchy, such as your wife, children, and pets. A different set of words is used when speaking to peers. Another set is used when speaking to a superior. A fourth set is used when speaking to the emperor. English used to have two pronouns for second person singular. 'Thou' was used for equals and inferiors, and 'you' was used for superiors. Your language may have special honorific words used as (1) pronouns, (2) affixes, (3) particles, (4) terms of direct address, (5) greetings (6) requests, (7) apologies.

questionGroup.question: (1) What pronouns are used to show respect or a lack of respect?
questionGroup.words: thou (archaic), you (archaic)

questionGroup.question: (2) What affixes are used to show respect?
questionGroup.words: (none in English)

questionGroup.question: (3) What particles are used to show respect?
questionGroup.words: please

questionGroup.question: (4) What terms of direct address are used to show respect?
questionGroup.words: sir, ma'am, your honor, your majesty

questionGroup.question: (5) What words are used in greetings to show respect?
questionGroup.words: hey, hi, hello, pleased to meet you

questionGroup.question: (6) What words are used in requests to show respect?
questionGroup.words: may, can

questionGroup.question: (7) What words are used in apologies to show respect?
questionGroup.words: sorry, excuse me, I beg your pardon

item.name: Name
item.descr: Use this domain for general words referring to proper nouns--the name given to a particular person or thing to distinguish it from other things like it. Proper nouns are often not included in a dictionary, or are included in an appendix at the front or back of a dictionary. This is because there are so many of them, they are sometimes difficult to define, and it saves space in the dictionary. For instance place names can be included in a map. So it might be good to type the proper nouns into a special file.

questionGroup.question: (1) What general words refer to the name of a person, place, or thing?
questionGroup.words: name, proper noun

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to giving a name to someone or something?
questionGroup.words: name (v), call, christen

item.name: Name of a person
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the name of a person. Each culture has a system of personal names to identify individuals and kin groups. The subcategories under this heading should reflect the cultural system. If your language has a special set of names that do not fit any of they domains given here, then set up a special domain.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the name of a person?
questionGroup.words: name, proper name, proper noun, first name, given name, personal name, middle name, last name, family name, father's name, surname, maiden name, initial, title, identity

questionGroup.question: (2) What words refer to a name your family or friends use for you that is not your real name?
questionGroup.words: nickname, pet name

questionGroup.question: (3) What words refer to a name you use for yourself that is not your real name?
questionGroup.words: false name, pseudonym, pen name, stage name, alias, a.k.a. (also known as), under the name of, under an assumed name, go by the name of

questionGroup.question: (4) What words are used to refer to someone when you can't remember what they are called?
questionGroup.words: what's his/her name, whatchamacallit, whatsit, so and so

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe someone whose name is not known?
questionGroup.words: anonymous, unnamed, unidentified, incognito, unknown, nameless

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to discovering or stating the name of someone whose name has not been known?
questionGroup.words: name, identify

questionGroup.question: (7) What words are used to indicate a person's name?
questionGroup.words: someone's name is, be called, be known as, named

questionGroup.question: (8) What words refer to giving someone a name?
questionGroup.words: name (v), call, be christened, give a name to, choose a name, pick a name, call him/her 'name'

questionGroup.question: (9) What words refer to the reason why someone is given a name?
questionGroup.words: be named for, be named after, namesake

questionGroup.question: (10) When is a name given?
questionGroup.words: naming ceremony, christening

questionGroup.question: (11) What words refer to writing your name?
questionGroup.words: sign (your name), signature

item.name: Personal names
item.descr: Use this domain for those names that are given to people, that people use to call to each other and to talk about each other.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the given names used by people in the language group?
questionGroup.words: John, David, Mary, Elizabeth

item.name: Family names
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the families that exist within the language community. If your culture does not use family names, just leave this domain empty.

questionGroup.question: (1) What names are used by all the members of a family?
questionGroup.words: Smith, Jones, MacDonald, Johnson

item.name: Clan names
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the clans that exist within the language community. The distinction between family, clan, tribe, and nation is based on politics and emotion. Our purpose here is not to make political statements, but merely to list the names. There may be no distinction between family and clan, in which case ignore this domain and use the domain 'Family names'.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the proper names of the clans?
questionGroup.words: Hatfields, McCoys, Bear Clan

item.name: Tribal names
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the tribes that exist around the language community, including the name of your own tribe. These tribal names may or may not correspond with the names of countries.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the proper names of the neighboring tribes?
questionGroup.words: Saxons, Scots, Welsh, Picts, Irish, Normans, Vikings, Brits, Americans, Aussies, Kiwis, Sioux, Cherokee

item.name: Names of languages
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the languages that are spoken in the area around the language community, including the name of your own language. These language names may or may not correspond with the names of countries. Do not try to include every language name in the world, only the neighboring and important ones. For instance you might want to include the languages that border your own and the national language. Give the form that you use. For instance the German people call their language 'Deutsch', but in English we call it 'German'.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the languages spoken in the area?
questionGroup.words: English, Gaelic, Irish, Welsh, Dutch, German, French, Spanish, Pidgin English

item.name: Nickname
item.descr: Use this domain for common nicknames--an additional name given to a person later in life, often descriptive. Also include general names used to call or refer to someone when you don't know their name

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the common nicknames?
questionGroup.words: buddy, buster, guy, gal, bro, sis

questionGroup.question: (2) What names are used to refer to someone when you don't know their name.
questionGroup.words: John Doe, Jane Doe, Joe Blow, GI Joe

item.name: Terms of endearment
item.descr: Use this domain for terms of endearment--a name used by lovers or spouses to express love or intimacy. Some languages may have special names used by close friends.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the terms of endearment?
questionGroup.words: sweetheart, honey, dear

item.name: Name of a place
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the name of a place.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the name of a place?
questionGroup.words: place name

item.name: Names of countries
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the countries that exist around the language community, especially those countries where your language is spoken. Include the name of your own country. Do not list every country in the world, unless your language has developed special names or pronunciations for those countries. Include any country that you refer to in your language, especially those names whose pronunciation you have adapted to fit your language. Give the form of the name that you use, rather than the official spelling. For instance the Japanese refer to their country as 'Nihon', but in English will call it 'Japan'. So 'Japan' is an English word and should go into an English dictionary. But 'Nihon' is not an English word and should not go in the dictionary.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the proper names of the countries where your language is spoken?
questionGroup.words: Great Britain, United States of America, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Ireland

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the proper names of the neighboring countries?
questionGroup.words: Netherlands, Germany, France, Spain, Mexico

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to refer to a citizen of these countries?
questionGroup.words: Brit, the English, American, Canadian, Aussie, Kiwi

item.name: Names of regions
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the regions within your country or language area. Some of these may be political regions. Others may be informal terms. Give the local pronunciation, rather than some foreign spelling. You may want to limit this domain to just those areas within your language area. However if you have special names for areas outside of your language area, for example 'the Mideast', you should include them.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the regions in the area?
questionGroup.words: Yorkshire, California, Midlands, Midwest, the South, outback

item.name: Names of cities
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of cities, towns, and villages in the language area. Include the names of important cities outside of the language area if your language has a special name for the city or a different pronunciation for it. It might be good to use a map for this. In fact it is good to include a map of the language area in a published dictionary. If your language area is very large, there may be hundreds or thousands of cities, towns, and villages. In this case you will have to decide which should be included in the dictionary. Or you could decided to list them in a special section.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the cities in the language area?
questionGroup.words: London, Washington D.C.

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the names of districts within a city?
questionGroup.words: Westminster, Chelsea

item.name: Names of streets
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of highways, roads, streets, and trails in the language area. If there are many such names, only include the important names (e.g. King's Highway) or commonly used names (e.g. Main Street).

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the streets in the language area?
questionGroup.words: King's Highway, Highway 66, Main Street, Piccadilly Square, Oregon Trail

item.name: Names of heavenly bodies
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the heavenly bodies.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the planets?
questionGroup.words: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the names of the constellations?
questionGroup.words: Milky Way, Big Dipper, Orion, Pleiades, Southern Cross

questionGroup.question: (3) What are the names of the stars?
questionGroup.words: North Star, Morning Star, Betelgeuse, Alpha Centauri

questionGroup.question: (4) What are the names of other heavenly bodies?
questionGroup.words: Halley's Comet

item.name: Names of continents
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the continents. Only include the names of continents if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the continents?
questionGroup.words: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

item.name: Names of mountains
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the mountains in the language area. Only include the names of mountains outside the language area if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the mountains in the language area?
questionGroup.words: Mount Rainier, Mount McKinley

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the names of the mountain ranges in the language area?
questionGroup.words: Rocky Mountains, Sierras, Appalachian Mountains

item.name: Names of oceans and lakes
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the oceans and lakes in the language area. Only include the names of oceans and lakes outside the language area if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the oceans?
questionGroup.words: Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean, Indian Ocean, Arctic Ocean, Mediterranean Sea

questionGroup.question: (2) What are the names of the lakes in the language area?
questionGroup.words: Lake Superior, Lake Michigan

item.name: Names of rivers
item.descr: Use this domain for the proper names of the rivers in the language area. Only include the names of rivers outside the language area if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

questionGroup.question: (1) What are the names of the rivers in the language area?
questionGroup.words: Thames, Mississippi, Missouri, Hudson

item.name: Name of a thing
item.descr: Use this domain for words related to the name of a thing. Many cultures give names to particular buildings, ships, airplanes, organizations, companies, schools, and other things. If your language has hundreds of names for some kind of thing, it is best to not try to list them all. But if there are a few important names for one kind of thing, set up a domain for them.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to a name for something?
questionGroup.words: name, proper name, designation, label, nomenclature, tag, title

questionGroup.question: (2) What words are used to indicate the name of something?
questionGroup.words: be called, be known as, be entitled, be termed, go by the name of, so-called

questionGroup.question: (3) What words are used to refer to something when you can't remember what it is called?
questionGroup.words: what's its name, thingy, thingamajig, whatchamacallit, whatsit, such and such

questionGroup.question: (4) What words refer to a name that is not correct?
questionGroup.words: misnomer

questionGroup.question: (5) What words describe something that has the name of something but not its qualities?
questionGroup.words: nominal, in name only

questionGroup.question: (6) What words refer to giving something a name?
questionGroup.words: call, name, rename

item.name: Names of animals
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the name of an animal. Some cultures give names to domesticated animals or to animals in stories. Think through each kind of domesticated animal.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the name of an animal?
questionGroup.words: Br'er rabbit

questionGroup.question: (2) What names are given to dogs?
questionGroup.words: Lassie, Fifi, Toto

item.name: Names of buildings
item.descr: Use this domain for words referring to the name of a building.

questionGroup.question: (1) What words refer to the name of a building?
questionGroup.words: White House, Capitol

item.name: Monologue
item.descr: A text with a single participant, typically a narrator addressing an audience

item.name: Narrative
item.descr: An account of events, a text that describes or projects a contingent succession of actions

item.name: History
item.descr: An account of real events

item.name: Fiction
item.descr: An account of invented events

item.name: Traditional Narrative
item.descr: A traditional account of events of unknown historicity

item.name: Prophecy
item.descr: An account of events that are projected to happen at a later time, typically involving a supernatural agency

item.name: Procedure
item.descr: A text that describes or explains a process

item.name: Descriptive Procedure
item.descr: Describes how something was done

item.name: Prescriptive Procedure
item.descr: Gives instructions about how to do something

item.name: Behavioral Text
item.descr: A text that motivates or describes behavior without a framework of contingent succession

item.name: Hortatory Text
item.descr: A text intended to motivate the audience to do something or to act or to believe in a particular way; a.k.a. Motivational Text

item.name: Normative Text
item.descr: A text intended to express the norms of a society for the purpose of motivating someone to conform to those norms

item.name: Promissory Text
item.descr: A text in which the originator promises to do something or to act or to believe in a particular way

item.name: Behavioral Description
item.descr: A text, such as a Eulogy, that describes the accomplishments of a person without a contingent succession of actions

item.name: Exposition
item.descr: A text that explains something other than a behavior, a process or a succession of events; typically it explains facts or ideas

item.name: Projection
item.descr: A text dealing with projected facts or planned status (not a proposal for action, which would be Hortatory; not focusing on human or divine agency, which would be Prophecy)

item.name: Descriptive Exposition
item.descr: Exposition that describes an object, location or situation in static terms

item.name: Didactic Exposition
item.descr: Exposition specifically intended for teaching another person about a body of facts

item.name: Dialogue
item.descr: Literal speech between individuals or quoted text that uses quotation formulas (typically using the verb 'to say')

item.name: Conversation
item.descr: Dialogue involving mutual cooperation between the speakers

item.name: Verbal Conflict
item.descr: Dialogue in which the speakers resist mutual resolution of one or more propositions

item.name: Negotiation
item.descr: Dialogue in which a speaker seeks to obtain a benefit from the other speaker

item.name: Drama
item.descr: Acted out speech or quoted text that does not use quotation formulas

item.name: Word List
item.descr: A list of words used for language research or documentation

item.name: Paradigm
item.descr: A list of well-formed words, typically arranged according to inflection

item.name: Ill-formed Words
item.descr: A list of words that are not well-formed in the language, e.g. an anti-paradigm or list of common misspellings

item.name: Metrical Category
item.descr: Genre according to metrical form (versus content)

item.name: Prose
item.descr: Non-metrical arrangement of the text, typically using the grammar of ordinary speech

item.name: Poetry
item.descr: Metrical arrangement of the text, typically employing rules for rhyme and rhythm

item.name: Unspecified Complex Form
item.descr: A complex form that hasn't been labeled as a specific kind of complex form.

item.name: Compound
item.descr: A stem that is made up of more than one root.

item.name: Contraction
item.descr: A combination of two lexemes that are phonologically reduced.

item.name: Derivative
item.descr: A stem that is made up of a root plus an affix that adds a non-inflectional component of meaning.

item.name: Idiom
item.descr: A multi-word expression that is recognized as a semantic unit.

item.name: Phrasal Verb
item.descr: A combination of a lexical verb and a verbal particle that forms a single semantic and syntactic unit.

item.name: Saying
item.descr: Any pithy phrasal expression of wisdom or truth; esp., an adage, proverb, or maxim.

item.name: Unspecified Variant
item.descr: A variant form that hasn't been labeled as a specific kind of variant.

item.name: Dialectal Variant
item.descr: A variant of a lexeme, characteristically used by a specific demographic subset of the language.

item.name: Free Variant
item.descr: If two forms are free variants, the same speaker might use either one in the same setting. The more frequent form would be considered the basic form.

item.name: Spelling Variant
item.descr: A variant spelling of a lexeme.

item.name: particle
item.descr: A particle is a word that does not belong to one of the main classes of words, is invariable in form, and typically has grammatical or pragmatic meaning.

item.name: infix
item.descr: An infix is an affix that is inserted within a root or stem.

item.name: prefix
item.descr: A prefix is an affix that is joined before a root or stem.

item.name: simulfix
item.descr: A simulfix is a change or replacement of vowels or consonants (usually vowels) which changes the meaning of a word. (Note: the parser does not currently handle simulfixes.)

item.name: suffix
item.descr: A suffix is an affix that is attached to the end of a root or stem.

item.name: suprafix
item.descr: A suprafix is a kind of affix in which a suprasegmental is superimposed on one or more syllables of the root or stem, signalling a particular morphosyntactic operation. (Note: the parser does not currently handle suprafixes.)

item.name: circumfix
item.descr: A circumfix is an affix made up of two separate parts which surround and attach to a root or stem.

item.name: clitic
item.descr: A clitic is a morpheme that has syntactic characteristics of a word, but shows evidence of being phonologically bound to another word. Orthographically, it stands alone.

item.name: enclitic
item.descr: An enclitic is a clitic that is phonologically joined at the end of a preceding word to form a single unit. Orthographically, it may attach to the preceding word.

item.name: proclitic
item.descr: A proclitic is a clitic that precedes the word to which it is phonologically joined. Orthographically, it may attach to the following word.

item.name: bound root
item.descr: A bound root is a root which cannot occur as a separate word apart from any other morpheme.

item.name: root
item.descr: A root is the portion of a word that (i) is common to a set of derived or inflected forms, if any, when all affixes are removed, (ii) is not further analyzable into meaningful elements, being morphologically simple, and, (iii) carries the principle portion of meaning of the words in which it functions.

item.name: bound stem
item.descr: A bound stem is a stem which cannot occur as a separate word apart from any other morpheme.

item.name: stem
item.descr: "A stem is the root or roots of a word, together with any derivational affixes, to which inflectional affixes are added." (LinguaLinks Library). A stem "may consist solely of a single root morpheme (i.e. a 'simple' stem as in man), or of two root morphemes (e.g. a 'compound' stem, as in blackbird), or of a root morpheme plus a derivational affix (i.e. a 'complex' stem, as in manly, unmanly, manliness). All have in common the notion that it is to the stem that inflectional affixes are attached." (Crystal, 1997:362)

item.name: infixing interfix
item.descr: An infixing interfix is an infix that can occur between two roots or stems.

item.name: prefixing interfix
item.descr: A prefixing interfix is a prefix that can occur between two roots or stems.

item.name: suffixing interfix
item.descr: A suffixing interfix is an suffix that can occur between two roots or stems.

item.name: phrase
item.descr: A phrase is a syntactic structure that consists of more than one word but lacks the subject-predicate organization of a clause.

item.name: discontiguous phrase
item.descr: A discontiguous phrase has discontiguous constituents which (a) are separated from each other by one or more intervening constituents, and (b) are considered either (i) syntactically contiguous and unitary, or (ii) realizing the same, single meaning. An example is French ne...pas.
